author: {'steamid': '76561198001090338', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 556, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1712243858}
review:
If you hadn't told me this game was from 2015 I would have assumed it was one of the classics from the late 90s that I hadn't played. The art and soundtrack really sell an interesting world, and the voice acting is amateurish in a way that makes it feel older rather than badly made.
Very little backtracking, and the story is interesting as well. Overall a very nice package, hope the dev makes something new eventually.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024155723', 'num_games_owned': 402, 'num_reviews': 205, 'playtime_forever': 520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 520, 'last_played': 1682974531}

author: {'steamid': '76561199548803030', 'num_games_owned': 10, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 369, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1712366826}
review:
Answer these 3 questions for yourself:

1) Do you like cyberpunk?
2) Do you like adventure games?
3) The fact that the game's author chose a character in a mask for his logo DOES NOT concern you, and you are not deterred by the possibility of encountering "current thing" elements within the game's narrative

If you answered affirmatively to all three, then yes, it is definitely worth buying this game

author: {'steamid': '76561199089221715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1710602824}
review:
Game was going great, then they sneak in some present-dayism for no good reason, just to let you know they think the future will be like the BS we're being told is normal today. Really bummed, took me right out of the experience. 

"Wait, isn't that an all boys school"
"I used to be a boy.."

Huh, we're solving a murder... now my female partner is telling me about the advanced procedures that allowed her to magically not be a him anymore through mutilation and "science"

Guess I'll go back to Kings Quest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158098242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1703445702}
review: Point and click cyberpunk masterpiece!

author: {'steamid': '76561199551389892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 614, 'last_played': 1710139465}
review:
I recently played Shardlight, also published by the same studio, but compared to this, Shardlight was quite bland. This one doesn't feel like a budget adventure game, though it was probably also done in AGS.
The script is a lot deeper with less plot holes. The characters and their motivations - more complex, more emotional and relatable. The world (despite the limiting art style) feels more vibrant and full. Voice acting is better as well... And the soundtrack is just amazing. I've always had a thing for dystopian/cyberpunk settings and the music is what hits that setting the hardest. The only thing off about this game is it's title. I've always found the name kinda goofy.
Anyway, like Shardlight, this game was not difficult. I only needed help with cheesing two achievements. xD

author: {'steamid': '76561199201509651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 911, 'last_played': 1707067644}
review: Nice traditional point-and-click with mainly interesting story. I did not get certain reactions from the player characters, especially the central motivation for one of them and why it was so important, but I guess the writing did reveal it towards the end to be a pain point for the character. Otherwise very nice mood, setting and plot. Execution is good, pacing great, music nostalgic and UI mostly a breeze.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095668425', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 859, 'last_played': 1707044898}
review:
Encore un bijou de WadjetEyeGames !
Intrigue dans un monde cyberpunk, le point fort est comme d'habitude chez eux la qualité d'écriture de l'intrigue.
L'ambiance est parfaitement travaillée, et le doublage parfait (VO uniquement).
Les sous titres FR disponibles par des fans est nickel également, et bienvenu vue la quantité de dialogues pas toujours simples.
Durée de vie entre 10 et 15h suivant la facilité/difficulté/chance à résoudre les énigmes, bien construites et logiques.
A réserver toutefois aux amateurs de "pixel art" et de click'n point à l'ancienne.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061969450', 'num_games_owned': 109, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 874, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 874, 'last_played': 1706840791}
review: I've recently revisited Technobabylon (ahem, tonight) and while I was impressed upon it's initial release and play through years ago, coming back is even more impressive. While point-and-click adventures may not be one's "bag", this game is indeed a lot of fun. Great story telling, impressive (and properly humorous) voice acting, and a mystery that gets you IN. The solutions are numerous and you'll WANT to solve this who-done-it. And there are quite a few ways to do so. No on-rails, "gotta do it this one way" game here. The care taken to even the "wrong" leads is outstanding. This is definitely a classic that will, and should, be visited and revisited.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036069401', 'num_games_owned': 440, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1674254044}
review: We need more developers that upgrade the game engine 8 years after the release so that it works better for tablet users. And when this breaks things under special circumstances, they quickly provide a bugfix.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040058157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1706121088}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970690702', 'num_games_owned': 1175, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1705528223}
review: It took me 9 years to get around to finishing this. I was saddened to see there hasn't been anything from Technocrat games since, a shame since this was a very solid freshman effort. The voice acting is a little varied in quality, some of it is fairly amateurish, but it doesn't detract from a fun and brisk cyberpunk/biopunk story. The visuals are mostly well done tho there's some inconsistent pixel sizes, and AGS continues to be a baffling entity in my eyes, with an 85hz option "for CRTs", which seemingly has no effect on the actual framerate of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198863518480', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1115, 'last_played': 1705378434}
review: Great Point & Click adventure in old-school style, well-thought-out Sci-Fi/Cyberpunk story, extremely good atmosphere, good voice actors, subjectively some quite tricky puzzles. Fun to play. Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198098004504', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1705107509}

author: {'steamid': '76561198068207360', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1704111552}
review:
Wadjet Eye klasik 90'lar başı Point & Click meraklılarına hitap eden bir firma. Blackwell serisi haricinde oynadığım belli başlı oyunları Primordia (çok iyi) ve Strangeland (başyapıt). Technobabylon'u fazla bir beklentim olmadan oynamaya başladım ve açıkçası çok memnun kaldım. Karşımızda harika bir point & click var.
Öncelikle hikayeden başlayayım. Technobabylon tahmin edeceğiniz üzere bir cyberpunk thriller. Evet, çok kez yapıldı ve tarzın klişelerinin büyük kısmı (sanal gerçeklik, zihin kontrolü, ajanlar, gizli güçler, politik komplolar) bu oyunda da var. Ancak hikaye o kadar iyi kurgulanmış ve vurucu ayrıntılar ile desteklenmiş ki bu klişeler gözünüze hiç batmıyor. Karakterler iyi işlenmiş ve birbirleriyle ilişkileri son derece gerçekçi.
Oyun tıpkı bir roman gibi bölüm bölüm ilerliyor. Her bölümde farklı bir karakteri yönetiyoruz. Bölümler çok güzel tasarlanmış, zaman atlamaları ve flashback'ler yerinde. Oyun aslen bir çeşit interaktif roman tecrübesi sunuyor. Bu da bence iyi Point & Click oyunlarını güçlü kılan en önemli özellik. Asla boş boş deneme yanılma yöntemi ile bulmaca çözmeye çalışmıyorsunuz.
Oyun dedektiflik / bulmaca çözme dengesini çok iyi kurmuş. Hikayeyi diyaloglar üzerinden çözüyorsunuz ancak bulmacalar da çok yerinde ve bir kısmı o kadar akıllıca tasarlanmış ki şapka çıkarmamak elde değil (bkz. vücut sıcaklığı bilmecesi). Bilmeceler asla kendini tekrarlamıyor, öyle ki bir bölümde ilerlemek için 3 karakteri birden ayrı ayrı yönetiyorsunuz. Kısacası platformun olanaklarını yapımcılar sonuna dek kullanmış. Oyunun belirli yerlerinde yapacağınız seçimlerin finali etkiliyor olması da hoş ayrıntı.
Oyunun görselliği bana özellikle Beneath A Steel Sky ve Fate Of Atlantis'i anımsattı. Seslendirmeler güzel. Müzikler de fena sayılmaz.
Oyunla ilgili söyleyeceğim olumsuz bir şey yok. Baştan sona tamamlamam 11 saat sürdü ve bu gayet iyi bir süre. Neticede türü sevenlere şiddetle tavsiye ederim. Son 10 yılın en iyi birkaç Point & Click oyunundan biri.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029602249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1703891386}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198018321511', 'num_games_owned': 236, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 885, 'last_played': 1703799824}
review:
Очень интересная игра с очень интересным миром и хорошим сюжетом.

Не вижу смысла расписываться все плюсы и минусы, обзоров много, и информации об игре в них тоже достаточно.
Из того, что показалось для меня действительным важным:

+ Шикарный мир игры, который легко прочувствовать и понять, его хочется изучить, каждая мелочь становится не излишком информации, а отличным дополнением к сюжету и диалогам.

- Отсюда и минус, мир игры ты в какой-то момент становится так понятен, что загадки начинают решаться быстро и без раздумываний... Но те загадки .который внезапно нарушают логику происходящего, решаются очень тяжко и буквально душат посреди какой-нибудь главы.

Короче будьте готовы. Но свои "крайне положительные" игра полностью заслужила несмотря ни на что. Рекомендую!

author: {'steamid': '76561197985474992', 'num_games_owned': 1310, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1703786297}
review: Sadly the pixalated font is just too straining to enjoy this game. I've never had a problem like this in other games, but this is just too much. Playing the game felt exhausting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079751473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1703101253}
review:
I struggled to decide between a thumbs up or down for this game. In the end I decided that if a friend were asking me for input on whether to play the game I would rattle off so many negatives and only one positive, so in the "no" camp it goes.

The positive: the puzzles are really good. Other than at the very end when the game gets buggy and the objectives unclear, they are solid retro puzzles like the best of the Lucasarts era. Despite my distaste for the rest of the game I finished it because the puzzles were that satisfying.

The negatives:
- For me, the story is not compelling. It's self-consciously bleak and the characters are boring cliches. I had trouble keeping some of the minor characters' motivations and origins straight in my head. 

- The game has odd pacing. Some of the chapters are flashbacks where there is no meaningful gameplay, just clicking on characters to reveal some backstory. The chapters didn't feel balanced in length or difficulty.

- Probably the largest negative: the humor in old school moon logic puzzles is, to me, fundamentally incompatible with the gratuitous gruesomeness of the game. The game requires you to kill or maim many NPCs. There's pointless gore, shocking deaths, even gross sound effects. I'm not a fan of that kind of ambiance in and of itself, but juxtaposed with the (wonderful) silliness of the puzzles it felt really crude and disturbing. This is really the main reason why I wouldn't recommend the game to others.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972666068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 780, 'last_played': 1702514325}
review: Excellent. Another great point and click from Wadjet Eye exploring some interesting themes with a plot that is twisty enough, but possible to figure out along the way as well. Great dialogue and voice acting as always.

author: {'steamid': '76561199060535367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1705786183}
review: Addicting for those of us missing old school point and click problem solving and  lucasarts and sierra graphics of the mid 80s. 4.5 hours in and I need to stop and actually go do my dishes. If you liked Space Quest, darkside detective, or thimbleweed park then this fits right in.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995384996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3588, 'last_played': 1702171869}
review: Every now and then I replay this and I still enjoy it.  Really well written story and characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019755761', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 518, 'last_played': 1700773753}
review:
Technobabylon has a cool cyberpunk world, an interesting story and a great soundtrack but what really stands out are the amazing puzzles. Unique, logical, challenging yet never too hard or straying into "moon logic" territory, multiple solutions for some puzzles... It's some of the best I've seen in the point and click genre, at least from the ones I've played.

Easy recommend for fans of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012601749', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1485, 'last_played': 1700736400}
review:
I got this on the sale on a punt.

I am SO glad I did. This game had me hooked from the beginning. It reminded me of Beneath a Steel Sky and the Bladerunner point and click adventure games of the 90s. It didn't feel old though. The makers of this game have created a fleshed out world and have made brilliant use of the pixelated graphics to create this world and let your imagination fill in the rest. They were able to do so much with so little, just like those old developers of the point and click games of the 80s and 90s. Definitely worth a try and I will be going through their back catalog for more.

author: {'steamid': '76561199170186464', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1671909283}
review:
A very cool point-and-click adventure set in a futuristic Blade Runner-esque setting with challenging (and sometimes obtuse) puzzles. 
Although the voice acting can sometimes be tacky, the world-building is fantastic. 
Definitely check this out if you enjoyed Beneath a steel Sky or the cyber punk genre overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561198352623484', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1079, 'last_played': 1695517079}
review:
Grand point'n click! le scénario de science fiction est très travaillé avec plein de concepts intéressants: les wetware, l'IA administrateur public, les droids, le restaurant de viande synthétique, la trance ou encore le stagiaire du labo qui se simule les symptômes de maladies disparues! Un jeu prenant avec un belle intrigue policière.

Les énigmes valent ce qu'elle valent, un moment il faut toujours regarder les soluces!

author: {'steamid': '76561198105492478', 'num_games_owned': 1001, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1596357540}

author: {'steamid': '76561197979409161', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1612259493}
review: It's very good. Good story, good atmosphere, good puzzles, interesting characters. Easily one of the better point & clicks. I can't think of any flaws big enough to be mentioned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120592582', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 680, 'last_played': 1619854439}
review: A great point and click with competent sci fi writing. Good balance of exploring speculative concepts and keeping the plot tight. Good robot content. Enjoyed overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025427129', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1693690525}
review:
It is fun and interesting game!
Not as good as Blackwell or Unawoved, but still enjoyable and with great voice acting (as usual with WadjetEye's games).
I think the game could be a bit shorter, some parts seemed like puzzling for the sake of puzzling (especially Mandala's parts), but overall I enjoyed Technobabylon.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970807436', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 812, 'last_played': 1693106538}
review:
Honestly it just gets annoying & buggy. 3/5
Worth it if it is 5 $ or less.

Story: Good
Music: Good

STARTS OFF GOOD (first half) BUT...
I hope you like reading and reading and reading while you click as fast as you can through sooo much dialogue.
It started off cool but then suffered from the same pitfall as some other point and click games, where the thing you're supposed to find is so obscure I promise you won't ever find it unless you look it up.
Not great puzzle design toward the end.
3 out of 5 because some of it was cool and the ambiance was good as well.
By the end it feels more like a chore than a pleasure.
Also, that guy should not have infinite ammo. Kills the realism.

I recommend instead: Myst, Space Quest 6, Kings Quest 7

author: {'steamid': '76561198051333590', 'num_games_owned': 713, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1690640435}
review: Overall, I didn't enjoy this game, which is a shame because there are a lot of great elements. The puzzles are generally great with the exception of the final big puzzle and the interactions for a puzzle around at the start of the second act involving a holding cell/waiting room, the voice acting is amazing as pre usual for Wadjet Eye published games, the story and world are very good conceptually with a lot of very well-written news articles and item/object descriptions, and the art style is incredible. The writing overall is also pretty decent. However, the pacing of the story, some of the dialogue in the mid-game, the character portraits and text colors, and the last couple chapters in general kinda ruined the game for me. I feel like this story would fit better as a book than a game, but maybe the problem is me, considering most other reviews about this game praise the story. I don't know, I wish Steam had a mixed option cuz the game itself isn't awful, but the cons outweigh the pros for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025598384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1603731381}
review:
There are two major themes in Technobabylon: 

“I’m Mengele but like...sad about it?”

And:

“I [i]could[/i] uphold the status quo!...[i]or[/i] I could uphold the status quo [i]but worse[/i].”

For all the moody neon set dressing and cool mechanics, Technobabylon really takes the punk out of Cyberpunk. Fun to play and worth a try? Yes. Still kind of a let down? Unfortunately, also yes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970695202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1691336419}
review: Great Story so far...!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198116533936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 795, 'last_played': 1690711550}
review:
This is a very good point-and-click adventure with intriguing cyberpunk lore and good story, but unfortunately it suffers from some bugs (at least on game breaking) and some quality of life features. 

The puzzles usually make quite a bit of sense unlike many other games in the genre. However, puzzle quality can be a bit inconsistent from chapter to chapter. Especially the stealth puzzles are a bit silly with blind and deaf NPC's, but overall, they are logical and fun to solve. I only had to look for solutions in a few occasions when I was really stuck. A hint system could have been helpful, as well as a note taking system for useful information. 

The story is quite captivating, but towards the end some of it turns into a noodle. 

The VO is mostly top notch with the exception of a few mediocre sounding side characters.

I enjoyed this game throughout, and it was hard to stop playing. My review would have been much more positive if I haven't encountered a game breaking bug at the last act [spoiler](the drone wouldn't move)[/spoiler], and other glitches as well, but overall I recommend this game for the fans of point and click adventures and Blade Runner-esque cyberpunk which explores topics like AI, synthetic humans, consciousness, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976955550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 588, 'last_played': 1690733909}
review: Pretty neat game made in adventure-game-studio by the Wadjet Crew. The writing, premise, story and all that sort of stuff is the best part of the game. Graphics capture the sci-fi dystopic vibe well too, if you like the pixelated style (I don't mind it). I believe one of the let downs of the game is that there is no proper hint system and some of the puzzles (ex: the last act with 3 controllable characters) can get a bit complicated requiring wading through a walk-through just to see you missed an item that was showing for 5 pixels two rooms ago. Still, its an admirable adventure-puzzle game and I like Wadjet Eye so I'll thumbs up this badboi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007845342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 370, 'playtime_forever': 2218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2218, 'last_played': 1689274467}
review:
Technobabylon is a worthy addition to the cyberpunk genre
and one of the best point & click games (perfect as entry for newcomers).
 
The game has a compelling story, solid characters and great voice acting.
You rotate between 3 playable characters: old-school doctor/engineer Regis, Femboy uwu partner Max Lao and internet-addict junkie Latha (literally me).

Devs Technocrat and Wadjet Eye have delivered a "succulent" world that introduces various Sci-Fi topics that are usually rarely questioned. Cyberpunk is supposed to be futuristic dystopia, not just Sci-Fi action and superficially touching some technology-related issues. Technobabylon has 10 chapters and each introduces new concepts. This I like!



P.S.
that Gravball mini-game is shiat, even devs have difficulties completing it. The fk are we then supposed to do?
P.P.S.
Playing it during vacation with constant interruptions and leaving PC on in hotel was a mistake. 37 hours :O

author: {'steamid': '76561199155567575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1689121555}
review: Technobabylon has a good story, strong voice acting, and nice art. There are several achievements to obtain and many that are decision based. If you're playing through to collect the achievements you can either consider multiple runs or simply save before each one and then reload the file. This can be helpful when you make your final decision. If you do it this way, then the game will have little to no replay value. It's really up to you on how you would like to approach it. If you're a fan of cyberpunk, noir, and point and click games then this should have everything you're looking for.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986964654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1155, 'last_played': 1691343536}
review:
LOTS OF TECHNO, NOT MUCH BABYLON

If you like 90s point'n'clicks and equally obselete genres like cyberpunk (since it just became "an accurate descriptor of the current state of affairs), this game is gonna ROCK YOUR FUCKIN SOCKS.

The puzzles are just the right amount of head scratching without forcing you to turn to a guide.
The characters are vibrant and I'm going to be thinking about them for years to come.
And I've seen both endings and legitimately have a hard time telling you which is the "good ending" and I love this game for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561199109430076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1687884290}
review:
Belle bande son et les doublages sont réussis (version anglaise). Les visages des personnages changent d'expression lorsqu'ils parlent, en adéquation avec leurs émotions : c'est assez rare dans ce genre de jeux.
Je n'ai joué que 3 heures, mais l'intrigue est assez intéressante. L'univers rappelle celui de Blade Runner.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025230476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 783, 'last_played': 1686111757}
review: What an incredibly well-written game.  Has interesting characters, well thought-out world building, and a gripping plot.  For the most part, the puzzles are good, although the lack of hotspot visibility meant that there were a few times where I got stuck because I didn't realize I could interact with some object.  Not too much else to say other than that this is an easy recommend, and even easier if you're into the sci-fi/cyberpunk genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198212693465', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 655, 'last_played': 1686318207}
review:
This adventure draws you in with its excellent pixel art, gentle atmospheric soundtrack and a fairly well-paced story. The voice acting is spot on, and the many details and dialog options all contribute to make you feel part of the game's world. 

The puzzles are just the right amount of challenge, and while you can die at certain spots, the game will just bring you back to the moment before you had made your misstep.

The endings, of which there are two, are probably the weakest part and feel a bit rushed. Some of the puzzles at the very end also are a bother.

The positives outweigh the negatives by far though, so I highly recommend you to try Technobabylon!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993719173', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 816, 'last_played': 1685704692}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042276572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 677, 'last_played': 1685184386}
review:
This is a case where I'm not quite happy with the upvote/downvote option. For me, Technobabylon is somewhere in between. But since I cannot fully recommend the game, I've decided to give it a thumbs down, since there are so many other options out there. But if you love dystopian, retro Point & Click Adventures like Gemini Rue, Whispers of a Machine or Primordia, then you probably won't regret playing Technobabylon.

First of all, I love Point & Click adventures and I love the 1990s (S)VGA optics. Overall, Technobabylon does do a good job capturing the look & feel. There are a few inconsistencies with some of the models which are more detailed than others, too detailed compared to the rest, which does feel out of place. 

The world this game takes place in is intriguing and relatively well fleshed out without spending too much time on exposition. The story starts out interesting enough and one can tell that some thought went into the different factions and their motivations. However, in the end, it just doesn't seem to come together and the story somewhat peters out. Particularly the motivation of what turns out to be the main villain is unclear and possibly a bit contrived. 

The puzzles are adequate, sometimes also a bit contrived, but mostly fine. Towards the very end, it became a bit tricky and unclear. Especially one puzzle was totally uncleear to me and I had to consult a walkthrough, which I hate to do.

A significant part of the game takes place in the "Trance", a "Matrix" style virtual reality where people can plug in to. It's a neat idea, though the execution feels a bit off. The appeal of the "Trans" which turns many of the inhabitants of the world into addicts just does not translate onto the screen. It feels boring and mundane and one wonders why it's so popular within the universe of Technobabylon.

All in all a okay game with an adequate length, not as short as many other smaller Point & Click adventures. For fans of the genre it's worth giving a try. For everyone else, I'd recommend to give it a pass.

All-in-all it's a very nice old-school adventure game, that offers an intricate story, interesting characters and an impressive cyberpunk atmosphere, but the gameplay lacks a bit. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2952705527 https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2886328546

author: {'steamid': '76561199021946750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3820, 'last_played': 1686473655}
review:
Hands down probably one of my most favorite games! 

The story arc was very well-done -- it was great to play as multiple characters. I personally enjoyed seeing how the various distinct story lines ultimately converged. 
All the characters were quite interesting in their own way. Cheffie the chef was one of my favorites :). I replayed the opening sequence several times just to hear all of her responses. 

Also, the soundtrack was very beautiful. Looks like Nathan Allen Pinard did this one as well, not surprised with how amazing his music is. 

I couldn't recommend this game more to anyone who loves point-and-click games and cyberpunk settings! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198003278137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1683754309}
review: Really great point and click adventure. Excellent story with twists and turns that held my interest throughout. Interesting characters who on the whole were various degrees of well voice acted. Fascinating premise and setting. It's a pixel art game which I know bothers some, if so fair enough, I like it and this was a pretty good example of it. The puzzling is on the whole quite fun, not a turn your brain off and click continue type of puzzler but not a tear your hair out because you missed a pixel to click on 20 minutes ago and find yourself lost and confused as a result either. Highly recommend for point and click adventure fans and fans of story driven games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165646772', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 855, 'last_played': 1683420897}
review: I enjoyed it a lot. It has clever puzzles and stands out for its plot and sense of humour.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987565903', 'num_games_owned': 577, 'num_reviews': 220, 'playtime_forever': 1208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1208, 'last_played': 1682884209}
review:
Another great point'n click by Wadjet Eye Games.

Like their other titles, gfx are deliberately low res, giving it that old-school style of adventure games. This one is set in the somewhat near future. A world in which AI and virtual reality is quite common. Yet, the game doesn't go overboard with techno nonsense and instead keeps it pretty down to earth.

Voice acting, music and gfx style is all great. And the puzzles are quite good as well. Most things make sense considering the world this is set in. The characters are likable and act realistic while the use of AI in general has a more humorous approach and actually made me laugh out loud on several occasions, in a good way.

The game is also quite lengthy. Divided into ten chapters, with three playable characters, there's plenty of diverse scenery and story to uncover.

I really liked this one, oh my yes!

author: {'steamid': '76561197998071407', 'num_games_owned': 502, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1683328069}
review:
I love a lot of the games that come out under Wadjet, and this one was no exception! The story and *characters* and voicing are amazing--and there're some tricksy, unique things you can do in it, above and beyond normal point-click fare. (AI personality splitting, amirite?? The best part of the game LOL. Outside of Liam's voice/dialogue hahah <3  All of the AI-related stuff was really interesting, tbh.)  

I am really impressed at how there are usually multiple ways of accomplishing things, all of which make perfect logical sense, and never any puzzles that are baffling or dead-ends. There's definitely replayability, especially if you're an achievement hunter, but I was really satisfied with my first playthrough--how it went and how it ended. I'll probably give it a few months until I don't remember it as well, then replay. ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561199309748757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 927, 'last_played': 1683312718}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970040506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2877, 'last_played': 1683412109}
review:
TLDR?: Buy it, perfect gateway drug into Point and Click adventures.

Technobabylon is one of those game that technically has no right to be as good as it is. What you have is essentially a one person developer, albeit with an excellent publisher and two extremely talented artists. And yet out of this Technocrat Games have created one of the most concise, gripping and well-crafted worlds I have ever encountered in a video game. No dialogue, no item description is wasted. Everything tells you something new - and out of all these pieces of information the game's world begins to form, a somehow utopian and simultanously dystopian vision of the future. But even if you decide to focus mainly on progression, the game has a gripping detective adventure story in store, which twists and turns at every corner.
Visually the game drop dead gorgeous. The limitations of pixel graphics are transformed into quite the opposite: Here we have screen after screen where every spot of colour is deliberately chosen, from the gentle blue glow of technology, the pulsing orange of expanding neural network to the concrete brutalism of an abandoned robot factory.
The voice acting is - as is now the norm for Wadjet Eye Productions - stellar. The actors seem to have an excellent read on their characters, which gives the game world an additional layer of credibility.
I could talk ad nauseam about the story, but I feel that anything I could say here would detract from first plunge into the game. All I will say is that here is a staggeringly diverse cast of characters, perfectly integrated so that it feels completely natural. See if you can figure out where on earth the game actually takes place and you will know what I am talking about.

Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198345321584', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1683593298}

author: {'steamid': '76561198378598655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 940, 'last_played': 1682275430}
review:
This was a great experience! Good story, good writing, good voice acting, good music, good puzzles, and amazing pixel art. The science fiction is really immersive, and they've done a great job with plot and world building. The puzzles were engaging and challenging, but never annoying. It's the only adventure game I've played where I didn't get tempted to google for walk-throughs as soon as I got stuck, because there's always some cleverly placed clue in art or dialogue if you look for it.

If you're looking to solve thrilling mysteries set in a complex and intriguing future, through a classic pixel-style point'n'click adventure game, then this is the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991465987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 278, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1681588241}
review:
Technobabylon is pretty darn close to a perfect sci-fi adventure game - however, it's one fault was nearly terminal early in the gameplay.
Despite being developed by an independent (initially one-man, later slightly extended) studio, Technobabylon shares a lot with other games published by Wadjet Eye Games. The low-res, but very tastefully done visuals go a long way establishing the atmosphere for the futuristic, can't-quite-decide-how-dystopian story. The writing is great, the characters are interesting, and the eventual story is quite compelling, although a lot remains shrouded quite close to the end. Special commendations must go to the excellent soundtrack, and another strength of Technobabylon's are its puzzles, which are refreshingly unique at places, often make you work hard but to achieve some difficult ends, and they distinctly lack the oh-so-often-seen trap of adventure game puzzles where the game makes you work for 30 mins to open a cupboard - which then hides a 2 dollar screwdriver.
So if everything's so great, then what is the big issue? I did say the puzzles are great, but the way the game presents them are often not. In general, it took a little getting used to how the game expects you to click everything both left and right, including your inventory. Then, given the difficulty of some of the puzzles, there could have been more hints / clues, because at some times, the game acts very poker-faced. And finally, and most intriguingly, there are situations where the game carefully guides you towards a solution - which in the end isn't feasible. This last thing was played a couple of times early game, and nearly made me abandon Tecnobabylon in Chapter 100 (which is in binary, so #4). Luckily, I persisted.

All in all, Technobabylon is a brillant adventure game and a memorable experience. And its one weird quirk described above makes it even more unique :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198132276974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1681248332}
review:
Compared to my recent couple ventures with 90s point n click games, this game was a breath of fresh air.

Technobabylon is cyberpunk adventure game that is 'almost' a detective thriller. I say 'almost' because there are three playable characters in the game but only two of them are detectives. The game takes place in the year of 2087 in the fictional locale of Newton City which is governed and partially policed by an experimental AI known simply as Central. The primary character of the playable trio is Dr. Charles Regis, a former bio engineer turned detective working for the city's police organization, CEL.  He is joined by fellow detective and networking specialist, Dr. Max Lao, and together they must hunt down a dangerous serial killer known only as the Mindjacker for his tendency to rip the information out of the heads of his victims and overloading their brains. Unrelated to the other two for most of the game is Latha Sesame, our third playable character and a destitute internet-addict living in government housing. Her part of the adventure has to do with being hunted down by a criminal organization with nebulous goals.

One thing I have to say right off the bat is that this game is really well-written. The big twist in this game is something that would be extremely obvious in any other game, but the story does a good enough job aiming your attention elsewhere and not giving you more obvious clues until later on in the game, almost until right before the reveal. Similarly, the characters are also quite good. Regis makes for a good protagonist as a cynical older man  with a troubled, bitter past, and Lao as a younger, more level-headed, and more technologically-inclined woman acts as a great foil for him even if there's not much personally going on with her. Despite being separated from the duo for most of the game, Latha is a pretty great character in her own right, being a younger person who is part of a younger generation that has a greater understanding of the VR-inclined internet generation of the future. Typically characters like that are written by older folk with an air of derision, but this game handles the younger generation better than most. Most of the people you meet on the internet are not written entirely as jokes but people running away from their problems or hyper-obsessed with one particular topic or hobby, and the community that comes with it, which is kind of how it can be in real life. Latha herself can come off a little hip at times but her dialogue never takes away from the seriousness of her situation and most of the time her attitude is more relaxed and inquisitive.

I really like the world in this game. Cause it's technically cyberpunk but it's not so far in the future to feel like a complete displacement. After all, it's only 60 years into the future and stuff like limited corporate AI running our machines, 3D printers for food, and cargo transported by airship aren't exactly completely out of left field. Regis, as a man who looks to be in his forties, being somewhat awkward around gay and trans characters also makes it clear that old ideas and prejudices haven't died off completely even if the world has made a lot of progress. The most far out concepts are probably neurologically linking your brain to the internet and robots who are able to completely mimic humans, but even those feel as if advancements made in science and robotics that would make these creations possible are right around the corner these days and the technology isn't portrayed as being necessarily perfect in game.

The game design was refreshingly good as well. The game is very segmented, being split into a number of chapters, each with its own self-contained puzzles. Thankfully the majority of these puzzles are designed well right up until near the end of the game when a couple of them felt rushed and unclear. The majority were designed to actually give you the information needed to solve them instead of just trying everything on everything as usual.

The only couple complaints I would have are the aformentioned rushed puzzles towards the end, specifically the cargo puzzle, which was extremely unclear about how to do it, and the final puzzle with the wrench which doesn't have any hints that I could see and is not something that is obvious to think to do. I feel like it was just a bit unnecessary obfuscation right at the end. The VO, while fairly good for the most part, as felt a little flat and awkward for much of the game. It never got in the way of the story's emotional moments and the budget and manpower this game was developed on make it perfectly understandable.

I really enjoyed Technobabylon. It was a great adventure game that did a good job of balancing having a serious and narratively satisfying story with joking around and having fun with itself. It was also set in the future, but never forgot it as tends to happen, introducing new science fiction concepts and extrapolating on them often without ever taking away from our characters' personal stories. Between this and Primordia, Wadjet Eye are looking to be my favorite new adventure game developers. I'm eager to take a look at the rest of their library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010077003', 'num_games_owned': 500, 'num_reviews': 375, 'playtime_forever': 937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 937, 'last_played': 1681161097}
review:
5/5
Ottima avventura grafica con ambientazione cyberpunk. Storia intrigante investigativa con omicidi, fazioni rivali e intrecci per nulla banali. Molto bello inoltre il fatto che ci siano diversi dialoghi completamente opzionali per chi è interessato ad approfondire le informazioni. Molto bello il cyberspazio e come è usato per risolvere certi enigmi. Se si vuole trovare un difetto questi non sono particolarmente impegnativi e a volte la difficoltà maggiore è capire cosa bisogna fare in un dato luogo perché non sempre chiaro.
Assolutamente consigliato a tutti, specialmente gli appassionati.

author: {'steamid': '76561198200192783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 625, 'last_played': 1681081659}
review: Vraiment une excellente histoire de science-fiction. Les puzzles sont généralement bien faits et pas trop compliqués. Ce jeu est une très bonne surprise, je le recommande à tous les amateurs de SF. Il faut quand même être confortable en anglais par contre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023600447', 'num_games_owned': 1224, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 530, 'last_played': 1680724366}
review: Take control of three characters, all living in a technologically advanced metropolis run by an AI. You'll explore everything from restaurants for the rich to depressing and dirty "drug" dens.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962856335', 'num_games_owned': 527, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1679958037}
review:
This does the cyberpunk genre much more justice than Cyberpunk 2077, that's for sure.
It's a beautifully crafted adventure game, about 7 hours worth of gameplay. It actually has a couple story branches that yields achievements and change some dialogue options, so there's also some replay value. And it has multiple "endings" that are easy to replay through.

All in all, great writing and dialog, great voice acting, fantastic world-building and generally a really fun experience. Puzzles are challenging but not impossible, they ramp up with the story and don't get repetitive. Music and soundscape are also very well made and click great with the rest of the game.

Worth purchasing at full price if you're into point-and-click adventures. Definitely pick this up if it goes on sale!

author: {'steamid': '76561198201887661', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1689449209}
review:
So far the most disappointing Wadjet Eye game for me.
First there's a gay couple (old white man & young black man) and then you find out that the girl who is your police partner was a man before?!
Even though everyone is entitled to have his own opinion I'm strictly against developers / publishers trying to force their own questionable agenda(s) upon their audience.
I'm playing video games to be entertained and not to be indoctrinated with some political agenda that currently seems to be in vogue in certain circles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111507425', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 998, 'last_played': 1679865515}
review:
I was late to finish this and realise that most of my friends who love point and click will have already enjoyed it so I am just adding some love to this amazing project.   I loved it, such a brilliant (yes, at times frustrating) game experience but YAY,  I got through  most of the puzzles unaided and I know that I will play it again.

 If you HAVEN"T played it ,  OMG , do! It has a compelling plot, amazing characters and altogether is a brilliant game.  I really felt for all the characters but especially Charley .  I wish that there was another Technobabylon 2 .

author: {'steamid': '76561197964193466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1679070447}
review: Amazing story, characters and setting. Among the top 5 adventure games ever made.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991893085', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1653909772}
review:
By far, my most favorite "serious" point and click adventure.

The writing, the world building, the music, the characters (both playable and not), the voice acting, all top notch.
I truly hope that Technobabylon 2 is still in the works - I have replayed this game several times just because I love the ambiance so much.

Really really highly recommended!!

(I own the game outside of Steam, but bought it here just to support the devs a bit more)

author: {'steamid': '76561198071461334', 'num_games_owned': 809, 'num_reviews': 304, 'playtime_forever': 694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1678824339}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970237665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 259, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 585, 'last_played': 1676406887}
review:
TLDR: Meaty story, excellent world building, and morally grey. Technobabylon is a fantastic tale, though its gameplay mechanics are a little clunky. 

[b][u]General Thoughts/Overview:[/u][/b]

Brooding, thought provoking, and, at times, dark. Technobabylon (Henceforth TB) is everything you could want from a morally grey, dense story. Set in the distant future, TB is a point and click adventure that follows a small ensemble of characters as they find themselves caught up in a story much larger than themselves, as stakes grow and right and wrong begin to blur. 

Being the story lover that I am, TB really scratched that itch. The gamer in me, however was often frustrated, and I even had to resort to a walkthrough on several occasions, often discovering I needed to do something that wasn’t telegraphed well at all.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list][*] The story is extremely well written, tight, and interesting. I didn’t find it predictable while playing, but it was very obvious in hindsight, which is something I appreciate. There was, however, a gaping plot-hole that I will address in the con’s. 
[*] The world building, atmosphere, and lore is lovingly sprinkled throughout, giving a vibrant feel to the game that gives the story a depth and setting that makes it extremely engrossing. 
[*] There is a variety of solutions for many puzzles. While linear and not affecting the outcome of events, beyond achievements, it was nice to see multiple solutions to many puzzles, as well as the minor, but very different, responses you can get from doing things in a different way. 
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list][*] The game is [i]terrible[/i] at both teaching you how to play, and telegraphing what has changed. For example, I needed to resort to a walkthrough [i]in the tutorial[/i] because it never occurred to me to try and download attachments. I also had multiple points where I didn’t know what I was meant to be doing, and sort of wandered about aimlessly, hoping the plot would progress or I’d work out what I needed to do next by finding things I could interact with. 
[*] The game has a massive plot hole. I spent almost 2 hours trying to beat a stupid minigame (and ended up resorting to spamming mouse clicks as quickly as possible and hoping) because I didn’t think of any other solutions, and the game hadn’t told me that things had changed, I therefore did not discover a new npc needed to progress the game in the way you’re meant to (by cheating at the minigame, because HOLY FUCK ITS HARD.) and therefore did not buy a specific item from him used to cheat… But in the next scene with the character, the game assumed I had cheated, and had altered my inventory accordingly.  
[*] The game has quite a few QoL issues. No pause means when I needed to do stuff for the kids, I missed out on dialogue, the menu isn’t great, with no aspect alterations, and the game needs a double click move to next screen.  
[/list]

[b][u]Suggested improvements:[/u][/b]
 [list][*] Solve QoL issues.
[*] I’d like to see the dialogue choices throughout have an impact on the ending, more than it did. 
[*] A god damn sequel, please.
[/list]


[b][u]Overall Recommendation:[/u][/b]

TB is a good point and click. It’s almost a rare “worth it at full price” game, but its slightly more expensive than I’d be willing to recommend it at. Even 10% off would make it viable. My only real complaint regarding the game as a whole is I don’t see the reference to Babylon, historically, or mythologically. No tower of babel, no men becoming gods, and I don’t see any relation to the mythos of the Babylonians either. 
TB is for dense sci-fi story lovers (which I am), it is for point and click enjoyers (though I say that hesitantly, the pnc mechanics are not tight), and it is for people who enjoy a morally ambiguous story. 

TB is NOT for newcomers to sci-fi, as it contains huge volumes of technobabble, it is not for people who want tight mechanics, and is categorically not for people who skip the dialogue… given that a good 5 hours of the 8 it took to play through the first time were solid dialogue reading and listening. 

Overall, I think this is a healthy addition to a games library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014365767', 'num_games_owned': 883, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1676398559}
review:
Despite this game being developed by Technocrat Games (mostly just by one guy it seems), it sits perfectly alongside the games that the publisher, Wadjet Eye, usually develops. Like the other Wadjet Eye games, the puzzling is rarely challenging, but the writing is of the highest quality. The world-building has me wanting much more in this setting, but given that this game is now 8 years old, I think that's now unlikely.

I really think this style of game would translate over to VR very well with current tech, and this game in particular would be perfect for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198327981936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 5776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5524, 'last_played': 1676308211}
review:
Excellent adventure game, with a credible and captivating sci-fi plot, good puzzles, great characters, and excellent graphics. It basically has no flaws. The puzzle structure is linear, but the puzzles themselves are good. The game starts a bit slow and confusing, but becomes much more interesting later on.
The second-to-last puzzle (about understanding where a certain power source is) was too hard, and under-hinted, but very good in itself. 
The ending was so good it was even a bit moving.
This is an absolutely excellent game. I look forward to more from James Rearden.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002793981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1221, 'last_played': 1675121398}
review:
I usually never play point and click adventures but I decided to give Technobabylon a try.
The definite highlight of this game is the writing. The story is engaging and tense from the first moment. The puzzles are not too difficult and have a satisfying payoff. 

The only downside I can see is the fact that the game itself does require some familiarity with the Sci-fi jargon and lingo (I did read though that there is also the option to toggle the commentary that mitigates that issue somewhat - I played without it). 

TLDR: I don't play point and click. Made an exception. Enjoyed it. If you are thinking whether to buy and enjoy sci-fi, buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040610789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1674433877}
review:
Very Enjoyable game over all. 
Reminded me of when I played Point and Click adventures way back in the day when these pixelated graphics were the most advanced tech around.

Good Challenges and Puzzles.  Just the right amount of difficulty.  Though I do miss the Sierra Humour.

Also like how this game did Diversity right.  The Cast of Characters are diverse as diverse can be without being Woke at all! 

Will be looking at getting this developers other games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198163432214', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1679401753}
review: Amazing atmosphere and cool puzzles. Haven't finished yet but its been a blast so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198894665109', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 858, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 845, 'last_played': 1673365957}
review:
I don’t play too many adventure games, but I had a lot of fun with Technobabylon, and I would recommend to almost everyone. However, there are 2 big negatives I think might cause players to be dismayed: the story and a few very hard puzzles.

On the positive side, the characters and voice acting are great. Lots of dialogue that helps with the world building and character backgrounds. Most puzzles make logical sense once you understand the futuristic environment. The graphics are bad even for pixelated standards, but luckily it doesn’t affect the gameplay.

Now the problems: 1.) This is a classic point and click game with no new mechanics. That being the case, the storyline is going to be a big motivator to progress. Unfortunately, the story has HUGE plot holes. We’re talking Kaiju-sized, gaping wide plot holes. It’s approached from 3 different perspectives, and I thought by the end they would come together to a resolution. It did not. In fact, I would say most of the story makes no sense at all, and that left me so unsatisfied that I have no desire to replay it.

2.) There are a couple of “impossible” puzzles, at the very beginning and very end of the game. There is 0% chance I would have finished the game without looking up a guide. Maybe I’m just dumb, so it might not be a problem for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029423244', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1600, 'last_played': 1672807917}

author: {'steamid': '76561198015351405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 682, 'last_played': 1672755361}
review:
An old fashioned point and click adventure, with a modern touch.
A nice story, which masterfully unfolds before your eyes in this dystopian and somewhat dark world.
The puzzles are fair, never too hard, unless you are completely new to the genre maybe.
A taste of another era, when games where made with passion and love.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994660060', 'num_games_owned': 434, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1673235131}
review: old school point and click. plays amazingly on the steam deck. highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960425408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 875, 'last_played': 1672338580}
review:
Behind its pixels is a gloriously mature Cyberpunk game. The characters / voice actors are superb; moments of anger, sarcasm, surprise, futility. There's never a dull conversation.

Some nice out-of-the-box puzzles using future tech and consoles. A perfect moody soundtrack. Occasional hilarious jokes ( poor soldiers! )

If you happen to like point n'click adventure games and Cyberpunk this will be your game of the year.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009448882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2743, 'last_played': 1672257598}
review:
In terms of writing, pacing and puzzle design, I think this is somewhere in the top 5 point-and-click adventure games I've ever played, and I compare this to legends such as Indiana Jones & The Fate of Atlantis, Space Quest, Monkey Island etc. The puzzle difficulty is spot-on, and only three times did I find myself looking at a walkthrough to find something I'd missed in "pixel-hunting".

Extra points for:
+ Varied, intricate and constantly developing storyline
+ Interesting but not overly complicated puzzles
+ Dark humour

The only thing I could imagine improving UI-wise (which may be featured in later AG Studio versions?) is the ability to reveal clickable objects, so as to avoid pixel-hunting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049121918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 685, 'last_played': 1672042332}
review: Incredible story, great voice acting, and an in-depth, rich world! Doesn't have a ton of replay value, and I definitely needed a walkthrough, but I still [i]highly[/i] recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198088946812', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1670817986}
review: Amazingly well done

author: {'steamid': '76561198182731018', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 263, 'playtime_forever': 1883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1883, 'last_played': 1632606188}
review:
After completing this game for the first time around in 2019 I wouldn't have recommended it back then. After giving it a second go with the commentary in 2021, I change my mind as you can see. 

I think the main issue I had connecting with this game the first time around was there was a disconnect between me and the advanced sci-fi language which I wasn't used to at the time, being a learning curve to get used to figuring out what characters are explaining as well as understanding what to do to solve some puzzles. It didn't help that I wasn't much of a sci-fi wizard back then, well that's not much of an issue now as I became more familiar with the terminology. 

For others who aren't used to this type of genre, I consider you lot to not start this one yet before playing Whispers of Machine produced by the same company. It's more friendly with the sci-fi language making it easier to understand the plot without getting too lost. 

Other than that, Technobabylon is what you would want in a point-and-click adventure game, complex puzzles with a creative solution, beautiful realistic character portraits, and good convincing voice acting. And finally, as always the soundtrack is a banger as it has subtle mystery, technical jiggle beat to it that set the mood of the environment. 

Oh, and before I forget, not only is this game lore-heavy but also takes the sci-fi establishment to a whole level. Presenting a lot of interesting ideas, like terrorists implanting bombs in their bones undetectable, or someone giving themselves a temporary aphasia symptom because it's hip and retros funny enough. Quirky in that regard, and there are a whole lot of questions you may come out thinking about after finishing this game, like the morality of virtual reality (trance) vs reality, worldwide security supervision, AI, etc. Definitely worth the experience to explore if you're into these types of debates and theory crafting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011852165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1669070911}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009785376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1673407635}
review: A cyberpunk adventure game from the studio that brought you Gemini Rue and Blackwell! The year is 2087. Genetic engineering is the norm, and an omnipresent AI powers the city. Take control of three citizens of this world as they struggle to understand a deadly conspiracy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095263665', 'num_games_owned': 555, 'num_reviews': 407, 'playtime_forever': 727, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1669215202}
review:
Technobabylon is a point-and-click adventure game by Wadjet Eye, set in the cyberpunk futuristic, AI-managed city of Newton. You play as 3 characters, veteran cop Charlie Regis, his partner Max Lao, and Latha Sesame, a young woman addicted to Trance (basically this world's version of VR) but strangely more proficient in that field compared to most people. They find themselves entangled in a conspiracy involving the Mindjacker, a man stealing the minds of genius people. 

I played many P&C games, and honestly this one is the best so far. I love the cyberpunk setting, the mystery conspiracy story, the levels, characters, and soundtrack. Combine them all, it creates one amazing cyberpunk experience. I like how you can talk with characters, or read the news, for more background lore of the world. Be sure to try to talk to characters every chance you get for a bit more info. As expected, the voice acting is really good as well, with many familiar names and voices in the cast if you play these type of games.

The gameplay is the usual, gathering info and using items to solve puzzles. Some of these can be not kinda obvious, like you have to find the interactable spot, with no highlights. But an interesting thing is that several of these puzzles can be solved using alternate solutions, as you can see if you look up an achievement guide. Whether its a dialogue choice, using items, or whatever, these alternate methods can add some variation to the usually linear, fixed-solution nature of these games. Be sure to try them, especially if you're achievement-hunting.

Length-wise, its also a bit longer than your usual P&C game, but it's a good thing since sometimes, maybe almost all the time, I wished these games were longer. The only flaw of Technobabylon, for me, is that you cannot pause. The usual menu is always on the top left of the screen, but you cannot pause properly. Not really a big deal since there is no time-sensitive events, save for one minigame, but its annoying if you have to go in the middle of a dialogue scene, or when you open the Steam Overlay, as clicks you made in the web page still moves your character in-game.

But aside from that one flaw, Technobabylon is an almost perfect, point-and-click game with a thrilling story, cyberpunk setting, and memorable characters. Definitely give it a try if you're a fan of the P&C genre, be it the ones from Wadjet Eye, others done in similar style like Clifftop Games, or even different ones entirely. If you're just interested in the cyberpunk setting, give it a try and you might find a new type of game to love.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991214645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1668363978}
review:
I'd like to express 2 things beforehand:
- I've done 8 out of 10 chapters of the game, and frankly speaking, I wanted to finish the game before judging it. But it doesn't please me to do so. On the other hand, you could say I've seen a fair bit of the game to be able to publish an opinion about it.
- When to choose about good or bad about the game, I thought: would I recommand it, and would I recommand it to the point people do? Because there is no "neutral" option on Steam, sadly. I came to the conclusion I wouldn't, partly because I didn't enjoyed it that much AND because it was clearly not as positive as others review. But it was clearly not a bad experience.

Now about the pro:
- The art is cool, the ambiance, the music, thoses parts are really well made, nothing to say about that.
- The puzzle are USUALLY well made, maybe a little too easy in my humble opinion, but in that genre I would say it's more a positive point, because it's not USUALLY illogical as some others game. Also, to have from time to time multiple way to solve a problem is cool.
- As a DM of Shadowrun & CyberPunk 2022 (no, not RED or 2077, you young lass, I'm talking about the 1990 tabletop RPG), I can say the cyberpunk dystopia is overall 'well done', there is nothing new under the sun here, a few cool ideas, but don't expect something really innovative on that field either.
- The possibility to have the commentary of the devs during the different scene is really something I found cool.

Cons:
- The characters: you know, there is some games where the characters are so plain you can't identify to them, right? Well, this game go for the total opposite. There is basically 3 playable characters over the game and they are so specific that I can't identify nor feel sympathy for any of them... Except maybe Max Lao... That I've played for 1 chapter only out of 8... And said chapter was mostly about another character than her... Yeah.
Charles is a poor excuse of a cops tormented by his past and who can't let go of something that happened 20 years ago to the point he get BLACKMAILED about it and comply...
And Latha is... urg... yeah, no. I prefer not to talk about Latha. Sorry.
The characters would, to me, make for really good NPCs, but they will totally do a hit or miss on players. And for me it was a utterly total miss.
- Remember when I said most puzzle where well made? Yeah. Most. The ones who aren't are either "Hey, I hope you clicked that precise pixel to get this indispensable item to continue" or fall in the level of esoteric magic knowledge. I'm looking at you, Elysium tower, with your 2 pixels hanger, and your FUCKING PASSWORD to find. If you wonder to why I'm fucking pissed of by a password, imagine you're in a game, you have a password to enter, and the game show you a visual numpad you can CLICK in game. You're good? Well, that numpad don't work (and is of no use, it's just here to misguide you), and the password is made of LETTERS not NUMBERS. Yeah, you had to use your keyboard to enter keys that aren't proposed by the visual in-game without ANY hint you'd have to do that.
Oh, and if you're doing the game and remember this post, the password is [spoiler]PARIS[/spoiler].
As for Latha, her puzzles are usually easily resolved if you remember to use your wetware on everything you'll see.
- I'd say it as a cons, because for me it's one but... this game doesn't take a pecularly critic point on the world, which I would expect from a cyberpunk game. Plus there is nothing that would make me go "wow, that's something I didn't expect". So yeah, the game is overall good, but it doesn't make me want to know more of it, in one way or another. It's like a really good looking steak, but kinda bland.

I hope this opinion will be usefull to you, people. Anyway, have fun. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197990094789', 'num_games_owned': 1502, 'num_reviews': 254, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1668433090}

author: {'steamid': '76561198075726997', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1668507191}
review:
Wadjeteye are masters of modern point and clicks with captivating stories and without crazy puzzles (except for the box puzzle in Resonance, but that's another story). I completed the entire Blackwell series and Gemini rue with great pleasure.
This one is no exception. Strong characters. Great use of language. Detailed pixel art. Quality music. Love it.

Yes, it plays well on steam deck, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034711642', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 841, 'last_played': 1664809395}
review:
A great game! 
I started and finished this over a weekend, as I found myself pausing (for the sake of real-world living) - but then restarting the story over and over until I reached an end. 
Though this pixel-game is (severely) pixelated and most of the time you'll listen to text while you read it, it felt immersive, due to the plot and the characters. 
This game does have some recognisable cyberpunk genre elements, like darkness and shabbiness, ethical question marks, and hightech, but also feels rather retro in "tone", and this not only due to the pixels or the game's age.
There was only one thing I didn't like, which is, when you start the game, you can chose "start" or "restore", and because I expected a "load" button (instead of "restore"), I "started" the game by mistake too often. Conventional naming of buttons for users before they start a game? I'm in favour.
Other than that, the complex story was nice, and I although I know these games, I occasionally did need a walkthrough guide to solve a few things that I really didn't see on screen.
Support games like this one and buy it if you like pixelated point-and-click explorations with interesting plot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006604439', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1257, 'last_played': 1662920439}
review: Very good when you get tired of combat games. Interesting narrative and well designed often clever puzzles. A lot of adventure games have arbitrary and random puzzles I just can't handle. Here the puzzles are well integrated into the story and the environment and are mostly logical, in that you can solve them by asking yourself relevant questions, like "what do I need to do here for this to happen?" Also often there are subtle hints, either in dialogue or item interactions. (sometimes you need to right click an inventory item)

author: {'steamid': '76561198069056172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 788, 'last_played': 1662531691}
review:
I enjoyed this one. Classic pixel art point-and-click, but the puzzles aren't so ridiculous that you end up just randomly using everything on everything to get ahead. Instead, you can usually come up with a logical path of what to do next. Still, I wouldn't say this is an "easy" game. For me, it felt just right, but I had to look up the spoiler-free tips in the "guides" section of steam a handful of times. 

The story is intriguing and it tackles interesting aspects of a cyberpunk future without feeling stale. Voice acting was also done well, although I didn't like the male protagonist very much. He does grow on you over time, but even in the end, I was not really rooting for him. He tries to pull of the grumpy-but-likeable routine but often falls flat into self-absorbed-stick-in-the-mud territory. The other two main protagonists were fine, though.

One other thing that struck me is that different elements have different pixel resolutions. In the old games, everything was the same resolution, but in this, if the figures are standing further away, they are just scaled down and have finer pixels. Might be nitpicking, but it constantly reminded me of the artificial pixelation that is happening throughout the game. It makes some elements stick out so that the whole scene doesn't gel as one, but sometimes feels like a collage of random images collected from different sources.

And there is a scene where Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata is very prominently featured, and you can't turn it down even if you set the music volume to 0. I like this piece of music, but having it start over every time you change rooms becomes annoying. There is another scene at a biolab where you have a relatively relaxed conversation with a scientist, but the music in the background is quite hectic and loud.

Overall, these are minor gripes with a game that I whole-heartedly recommend to any fan of Sci-Fi and talking cooking appliances that evolve into... more capable appliances.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972779421', 'num_games_owned': 161, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1662072451}
