author: {'steamid': '76561198142554362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1660443682}
review:
[h1] Decepcionante y aburrido [/h1] 
Se busca plantear una historia en un universo de ciencia-ficción lleno de conceptos vistos en otros medios, que no tienen una cohesión lógica en la historia, en un afán de ser llamativos: chocando abruptamente en el intento. Introducir muchas cosas no te hace más complejo, más interesante, más inteligente, sino todo lo contrario. Technobabylon salta de un lugar a otro, soltando elementos que no van a ningún lado, planteando conceptos de ciencia-ficción contradictorios, con el único propósito de dar un telón de fondo 'adulto' que roza lo ridículo. Si bien la historia no es muy compleja, termina mareando y haciendo perder el interés, sumado a puzzles y diálogos lineales y poco creativos. Una historia olvidable y un final de delito. 

*Me tope un un error que me obligo a jugar en una versión anterior del juego. Lo cual, lo hizo aun más irritante de lo que ya era.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084905441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1661234997}
review:
Positive aspects: setting is fantastic, dark utopia science fiction as the name suggests, well written characters and world building

Negative: puzzles are very confusing at times, beginning level is very difficult by not explaining concepts such as the AI interaction with wetware, story runs then stumbles into an ending

Overall, a great story that is hampered by an ending that appears to have been changed last minute based off concluding events and character arcs.  I would recommend the experience as it does have some anxiety moments that should have been further explored including the threat of death, there are no consequences for failing a puzzle other than a momentary lapse.

author: {'steamid': '76561199002931318', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1660430230}

author: {'steamid': '76561198065561581', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1660458786}
review:
Uzun zaman önce "En iyi bilim kurgu oyunları" listesinde görmüştüm ancak oynamak şimdi aklıma geldi. Çoğu insan bu oyunu bilmiyor ve yeterince bahsetmiyor ancak bahsedilmeye değer olduğunu düşünüyorum. Ghost in the Shell ve Minority Report karışımı kurgusunu ve hikayesini çok beğendim. Elindeki hikayeyi çok iyi aktardığını da düşünüyorum.

Ancak oyun point & click ve hiç kolay değil (özellikle Telltale oyunlarıyla karşılaştırılınca, başka bu türde oyun oynamadım). Oyunun çoğunu yardım almadan bitiremedim. Ayrıca oyunun sonunda bazı şeyler çok havada kalıyor, birkaç karakteri üstünkörü işliyor, tam olarak kafamda oturmadı.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013847697', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 636, 'last_played': 1659684798}
review:
Technobabylon est un excellent point&click.

Techniquement, le graphisme pixel art est très bien réussi, plaisant à l'oeil, et joliment animé. Les musiques et sons d'ambiance sont aussi immersifs et agréables. Le jeu entre les trois personnages, et le passage de la trance au monde réel est également fluide et pertinent.

Le setting cyberpunk est une réussite, et l'immersion dans une ambiance post apocalyptique, futuriste, IA est immédiate. Les personnages sont bien trouvés, bien écrits, bien doublés. L'intrigue est rondement menée, très prenante, et ne se révèle que progressivement. L'histoire n'est, par ailleurs, pas si manichéenne que cela, ce qui est appréciable dans ce genre de jeu. Sa durée de vie est également tout à fait honorable.

En bref, technobabylon est une franche réussite, et je le recommande chaudement.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016386534', 'num_games_owned': 1950, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1659681481}
review: Great story! Should be made into a movie!

author: {'steamid': '76561198065819152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1659289577}
review: Another marvellously immersive point and click by Wadjet Eye Games. Technobabylon's writing is amazing but it isn't for everyone, the game comes with a staggering amount of gore and it's not just because you're playing as a detective. Playing Technobabylon for the first time is incredibly confusing. I myself got stuck in the very first room and gave up on the whole game, before coming back later to be amazed by what I had nearly missed out on. Technobabylon will test your patience, but it will be worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047484081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1659175875}
review:
I haven't finished the game yet, but I was almost immediately immersed in the game.

The setting is great (cyberpunk future) with some great characters. I really like that you can interact with a lot of things in a pretty unrestricted way. The developers have made those extra interactions give you hints on the actual interaction that you're supposed to do next, so anything you do will eventually lead to the right path - making you feel like you have agency, and the world feel more fleshed out and real.

I'm pretty new to point-and-click story games (this is first time I'm interested enough to play on), so I've had to take a look at a walkthrough when I got stuck. Some things are a bit unintuative, like being able to pick up digital data, as well as interacting with items with right-click when they usually give description of the item. I feel like the story is worth the trouble regardless, and it's much better in these aspects than some adventures from the 90s for sure!

author: {'steamid': '76561198189822922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 765, 'last_played': 1658538764}
review: Good puzzles, great story. The worldbuilding is done really well, too. Good experience overall. Definitely recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025184816', 'num_games_owned': 387, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1117, 'last_played': 1658495400}
review: Another must-play from Wadjet Eye Games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137304106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 899, 'last_played': 1657748273}
review:
This game has many nice aspects, Art, music and sound are good. I see that Devs had put many effort into making this, so for me its a thumb up. 
But please, stop making over-complex stories for no reason.
A game can be pretty much enjoyable also if the story is simple and quite linear.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035857157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 817, 'last_played': 1658252790}
review:
Bought Technobabylon during a steam sale because I was a fan of the Sierra/LucasArts games back in the early 1990's. Technobabylon feels a lot like what these games did back in that time.

The game took me about 10 hours to beat and I didn't get stuck very often on any of the puzzles. I did not have to check a walkthrough to get past any part. Usually within 20 minutes you can move on to the next part.

The dialogue was a little lengthy towards the end of the game. I did end up clicking through some of it to speed up and because I get a little bored if there is too much dialogue.

Overall, this is a good game to get on sale. It's one of the better point-and-click games that I've played in ages.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992364098', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 697, 'last_played': 1658131823}
review:
The characters and story were actually a little bland. The city didn't even get nuked, it was a mini simulation in a game that didn't have anything to do with the storyline. Most puzzles mainly comprise of scanning your screen for a hidden poorly drawn object that doesn't even look like an interactable item
I don't know how this game is rated as overwhelmingly positive. It definitely isn't a space quest or quest for glory.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082865405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 877, 'last_played': 1658092775}
review: Very good point&click adventure. The graphics and music provide great atmosphere. The story is good with interesting characters and puzzles. The Trance episodes (in cyberspace) are fun and interesting in this well balanced cyberpunk adventure. I'd love to see more of Latha's adventures in the Trance ;D

author: {'steamid': '76561198057295002', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1719, 'last_played': 1657900281}
review: Brilliant!  I read all the dialogue, not because I had to, but because it was so darn captivating.  All the characters were exceptionally voiced.  The pixel art was gorgeous.  This had just tied "Kathy Rain" for my favorite modern point-n-click adventure game.  (Very different genres of subject matter, same levels of awesomeness though.)  10/10  A must play for any pnc fan, in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201384721', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1657732287}
review: Great artstyle, fun puzzles and a nice story. Really felt the cyber-punk vibes. A solid 8/10 point and click in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198335400715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1657573653}
review: Love it. Wanted to play it for years. Wadjet-Eye is one of my favorite creators, so I had to play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198264096541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1095, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1095, 'last_played': 1656874076}
review:
Excelente aponte e clique cyberpunk. Diferente dos jogos da saga Blackwell, este é bem mais extenso, quase 20 horas de jogo no meu caso. 
A história é incrivelmente boa, com muita coisa bacana e uma série de situações de embrulhar o estomago sem precisar de qualquer efeito especial extravagante. Pra mim uma das melhores histórias cyberpunk que já vi, e gosto muito desse gênero.

author: {'steamid': '76561199230138805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1399, 'last_played': 1656718717}
review:
Un futuro distópico lleno de acertijos a resolver y con decisiones que van cambiando partes de la historia, incluyendo 2 finales (al menos los que pude descubrir). Recomendado para todo amante del point and click.
NOTA: 5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198399914027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1656303081}
review: Great story with great puzzles. Just an all-around good time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990246006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1656371886}
review:
I just didn't connect with this game like I've had others from the same publisher. Spoilers ahead:

The initial character is quaint, but you're in this scenario that screams "tutorial puzzle". The goal is to unlock a door. I don't know what narrative tricks Blackwell games or Primordia use for immersion, but they're not present here. Maybe it would help if I could remember this character's name.

Then the action changes to other two people. The puzzle in this screen is the elevator door is locked. You unlock it and enter an office where -surprise- you have to unlock a door. *sigh* Your game doesn't need the same puzzle in every screen.

Then you get an anonymous call threatening your frozen embryos you made with your dead wife, whom you've learned everything about just a second before because your partner popped up and asked you about her. This is so clumsy. Again all you can think of is "right, the game is telling me this man had a wife who died and they made embryos, which are now being used for blackmail". There's no involvement at all. When is this 50-odd years old widower planning to have those children anyway?

I advanced a couple more screens (and another locked door), till I had to fish a gun out of a jacuzzi using the convenient fishing rod I found on a shelf in the bedroom. Because of course there's a fishing rod in the bedroom. At this point I said "yeah ok, I'm not feeling it".

author: {'steamid': '76561198124014248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 409, 'playtime_forever': 1123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1123, 'last_played': 1655716635}
review:
I'm surprised that Technobabylon isn't more well known because it's one of my favorite adventure games. What I like the most about it is probably the writing, the setting feels very fleshed out thanks to the news bulletins and the topics that characters discuss with each other. It feels like there's a lot more going on in the world than what's immediately apparent. Not to mention the voice acting is rock solid.  
Besides that, the presentation is good enough to prevent pixel hunting and most puzzles are straightforward, so Technobabylon manages to avoid some of the most common shortcomings of point n' click adventure games. Some puzzles even have alternative solutions so that's neat.
What I didn't enjoy about the game is how depressing it can get. I guess that's an inevitable part of the experience since it's a cyberpunk setting, but it's just demoralizing how almost every character in the game is some sort of degenerate. I guess I'm ok with this sort of thing as long as there's a based dialogue option, but the game might be a bit too serious for some.  
Anyways, Technobabylon is great and I totally recommend it. Could even be a decent introduction to Cyberpunk video games in general.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053734082', 'num_games_owned': 1696, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 1496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1496, 'last_played': 1655593468}
review:
[h1]High highs low lows Technobabble[/h1]

As the most prolific publisher of old school pixelated adventures, Wadjet Eye became kind of a digital place of recluse for me. Where I'm guaranteed to relive good ol' past times and chill with some light cerebral point & click puzzles. Not sure exactly what is it about the pixels that does it for me. Reckon the blanks get filled by my brain better than hyper realism is able to. Anyway WEG did good to assist a highly skilled solo developer in enriching his gem as only it knows how because it turned out just as I hoped although the journey was not without trials and tribulations.

Story unfolds in city of Newton somewhere in Horn of Africa few decades into the future. If it weren't said one would think it's in the US. This world is highly globalized, technologically developed (duh), and in geo-political turmoil. Wars have been fought, cities destroyed (nuked), old alliances crumbled while new formed. Somehow our planet is still livable and thriving even, given numerous scientific breakthroughs. Only our morals had not the time to improve so the wealth is still distributed in all too familiar way. Surprisingly world is not dystopian as I've seen it described, at least not when compared to our present day. All of this is subtly revealed via optional news bulletins, e-mails, conversations, secondary or tertiary puzzle solutions. Pretty smart, cost-effective and believable way of doing it. Newton is also the first city to be completely governed by new experimental hybrid organic/silicon AI which of course becomes a major plot actor.

As with other WEG works, TB is a sight for sore eyes, with polished well developed aesthetic, audio and UI. Special mention goes to phenomenal voice acting which has to be the most abundant in any adventure game. Main character (Regis) is a joy to listen and reminds me of Robert Patrick from The Dig if anyone remembers. Not only everyone is great but quantity of it is absolutely baffling, oh my yes. Little was spared in leaving questions players may have go unanswered. Over half of the size of the game is speech and good chunk of it is developer commentary bonus which I recommend turning ON if you can spare a 2nd playthrough. It offers valuable lessons in game design among other interesting bits and great examples of executive meddling with which I all agreed with.
Highly detailed closeup character dialogues profiles also stood out in portraying personalities. Most have several emotional states (normal, happy, sad, surprised, angry) and it meshes pretty well with spoken lines. Impressive were the scenes with younger past versions of old characters where both the profiles and voices were remarkably faithfully de-aged. Certainly better than in The 'big kahuna' Irishman, lol. Huge props to Ivan.

Gameplay largely revolves around detective work and is roughly equally split between conversations and classic clickaroo. Goal quickly becomes solving a murder case which becomes more complicated as bodies start pilling up. Over the course you'll be controlling 3 different characters and not everything will have a chronological flow. There are 10 thematic chapters (aptly denoted in binary) that take an hour or two to solve on average.
I also very much fancied several moral choices sprinkled throughout. They don't carry much plot weight besides occasional reference later on but it only made them resonate more. Probably due to absence of familiar penalties or rewards to rely on, only your conscience as consultant and ever-present judge.
Puzzles are reasonably logical, not to hard not too easy, contrary to complaints I've seen. No trial & error click-fests either. Once an object fulfilled its purpose it is deleted from inventory so there's no clutter.

In contrast, presentation and pacing of the story as well as engagement with most characters is kind of messy (as it would be at the beginning of a very good book) but it pays off by the end, providing you have the patience and are good at adapting at new jargon. Conclusion is one of those rare fully satisfactory ones where every loose end gets properly tied.

* * *

Technically game is near flawless but to remove unfortunate mouse acceleration a [url=https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Technobabylon#Mouse_acceleration]visit to PCGW[/url] is recommended.
In full-screen system cursor bleeds in from pillar-boxed edges while the game comically tries to push it back in.
Savegame management is tiresome if you are an orderly fellow. Renaming existing saves is not possible unless you delete and re-save under a new name (in effort to preserve file naming increment within folder). Separate "New Save" option should have become a norm long ago and clicking existing saves should allow saving under a different in-game name (overwriting the same file).
Of course expecting perfection is ungrateful but it's interesting to see how modern AGS (Adventure Game Studio) gets personally tweaked from developer to developer for their distinct design and purpose. Early AGS games had but a simple UI variation of old Sierra adventures for example so we've come a long way.

With my nitpicking out of the way here are some gameplay issues that bothered me:
Starting puzzle already comes with a steep learning curve by poorly introducing a novel concept and unfamiliar slang, with little guide besides basic UI usage. Thought maybe there was a manual I missed. Didn't help the starting character came off as highly dislikable metaverse zealot at first.
What did help were small chapters consisting of 1 to 4 rooms. Eased managing puzzles by not overloading the player with possibilities but consequently made the world feel smaller and bit sterile even. Then the final counterweight to claustrophobia is richness and quality of dialogues as evident by complete absence of shallow black/white personalities in the entire game.

Increasing complexity of the case mixed with future jargon made it hard to follow. If you somehow pull that off it may become hard to maintain long-term attention because of warm/cold nature of tension building where most interesting bit ends along with the chapter, followed by starting over from scratch immediately after and in another character shoes.
It became difficult to return after starting a new chapter because I simply lost interest. WEG or not, I kept losing faith something good will come out of it. Longest break was 5 days at the start of Chapter 5 (Germination) and I'm certain I'd give up if game wasn't on Steam and I wasn't a completionist. Once I forced myself back it took 10 or so minutes before I was captivated again though.

Dialogue choices are often presented without logical order that would naturally expand information. There would be a non-related inquiry between two related topics or the follow up line would appear at random place on the list. Most topics being forever erased only to exist in player's memory also contributed to confusion overload.

Immediate ways to proceed and character motivations when the chapter starts are not always clear. You may find yourself fumbling about until a clue is given or found and even solve a puzzle or two in advance without having an understanding toward what goal you are working to.

* * *

With the power of hindsight I can say that with enough patience it will eventually deliver you to the promise land. After all it started as one-man freeware project before WEG took it under its wing so any leftover rough edges were only noticed because I'm a dinosaur gamer. In the end I'm happy to have stuck around since it all ties together in last two chapters far better than I could have anticipated. No cheap rabbit-outta-hat finale(s) here folks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151344565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 679, 'last_played': 1655417059}
review: At first, I was a bit shocked with the pixel-art-y graphics, but fortunately this is not the main thing I look for in an adventure game. I'm glad I didn't give up at that point, since the game turned out to be really awesome! The story is amazing and it's worth every second of game-time. There are also multiple endings, I've seen two and they were both great, so make sure you save the game before making any major choices on the last level.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972445688', 'num_games_owned': 426, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1291, 'last_played': 1472064006}
review:
I have played a decent amount of Adventure Games over the years and upon reflection I think this one has to be my absolute favourite.

It doesn't just make you think; it makes you feel. What more can you ask from a game than that?

author: {'steamid': '76561197975969805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1655429868}
review: Marvelously pixelated and classic game mechanics / story line

author: {'steamid': '76561198074450688', 'num_games_owned': 132, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1682778586}
review: An absolute masterpiece. Very thought-provoking. Most puzzles are well-designed. Interesting story.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993486084', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1655016394}
review:
I am really not sure about this ... the game isn't bad and most puzzles are solvable withouth the need of a walktrough but even though I kinda liked the characters but the whole story isn't taking me in at all, I didn't feel the drama about the Characters and I also couldn't understand several of the descisions the characters made.

Also I really like Pixelart but I also wouldn't mind it a little bit less pixelated, on a big screen it looks really bad while other games that use the same style manage to look good.

author: {'steamid': '76561199056249311', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 937, 'last_played': 1654856030}
review:
Gran juego! Con ganas de que llegue su continuación. Point and click de la antigua escuela! Lo he disfrutado en SteamDeck, totalmente jugable de principio a fin. 

Traducción no oficial al español: perfectamente traducido, sin embargo en una ocasion tuve que quitarla para poder continuar el juego (capítulo 3 llamada telefónica a S&S Synthetics). Algunos logros no pueden conseguirse con la traducción activa.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025834251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1386, 'last_played': 1471823062}
review: Amazing world, amazing point and click adventure game. Amazing cyberpunk. This is the cyberpunk game I compare all other cyberpunk adventure games to. 10/10 Can not recommend enough despite the questionable morality of some shoehorned in elements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198196130202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 686, 'last_played': 1654508508}
review:
일단 못 만든 게임은 아니라서 추천은 눌렀지만... 

우선 언어장벽이 여타 어드벤처게임에 비해서 다소 높은 듯 합니다. 

1. SF장르 특성상 용어가 너무 이해하기 힘듦.
2. 저해상도로 인한 폰트 가독성 낮음. 
3. 생각보다 빠른 대사 (아그래도 번역이 힘든데, 대사까지 빨라서 ㅡㅡ )

상기 이유로 전반적인 이야기 흐름을 정확하게 따라가지 못하다보니, 중반 정도에서 거의 반 포기를 하고 
walkthrough 보고 그냥 엔딩을 봤습니다.  (그런데도 이야기가 이해하기 어렵네요 ㅡㅡ 머리가 나쁜가....)

author: {'steamid': '76561198045141882', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 2371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1725, 'last_played': 1654382395}
review: Pretty fun point and click, a lot of tech talk and futuristic concepts.  I liked the characters and the plot was interesting.  Lots of diversity, which should piss off reactionary anti-sjw types which I enjoy.  Not SJWy enough I say!  I look forward to any sequels and future projects.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149783074', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1686593408}
review:
Пока пройдено немного, если мнение поменяется - изменю обзор. То, что я вижу на данный момент - очень круто.

Сюжет хорошо так интригует (в других отзывах пишут, что под конец сдуется - посмотрим).

Задачи пока более-менее логичны, разобраться без прохождения не слишком трудно. Но и посидеть на экране минут 10-20 можно.
Диалоги хорошие, актеры озвучили добротно.

Я скачал руссификатор и пробовал поставить, но на эту версию по состоянию на начало июня 2022 тот русик не ставится. Пришлось играть на английском. Благо, я его, как оказалось, неплохо понимаю. Конечно, я улавливаю не все детали, но смысл диалогов мне понятен, с этим проблем нет. Если у вас upper intermediate или уверенный intermediate - можете смело запускать в оригинале, заодно подтянете.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960484646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1655820323}
review:
I'm so happy i bought this game,
It's very well made fun and good game.

10/10, if you like point and click games this is as good as they get.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009532348', 'num_games_owned': 1419, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2115, 'last_played': 1653607353}
review:
OH MY YES !  
        
Uzun süre önce The Time Machine adında bir kitap okumuştum. O kitap da, Victoria döneminde yaşayan bir bilim insanının icat ettiği zaman makinesine binerek kendini bir anda 800000 yılların da bulmasını ve orada gördüklerini ve yaşadıklarını anlatıyordu. The Time Machine konu olarak oldukça ilgi çekici bir romandı, ancak benim için onu ilginç kılan diğer bir özelliği ise yazarın zaman yolculuğu aracılığıyla geleceğe dair yaptığı tahminler.


Bu tahminler onun gelecek algısını, gelecekte dünyayı ve insanları bekleyen sona yönelik öngörülerini içeriyordu. Kitap da anlatılan öngörüler, o zamanlar beni oldukça şaşırtmıştı. Bu öngörülerde medeniyetlerin sürekli bilim, sanayi ve teknoloji alanında ilerlerken aynı zamanda yavaş yavaş mutluluğu yitireceklerinden, kapitalist düzenin insanları daha sert sınıflara böleceğinden ve sınıflar arası farkın giderek açılacağından, rekabetin ve mutlak ilerlemenin medeniyetin sonunu getiren unsurlar olacağından bahsediyordu.


Kitap o kadar ufkumuzu açacak türden bir kitapdı ki, insan ister istemez kendi içinde sorgulamalar yapmaya başlıyordu. Gerçekten tüm bu hızlı gidişat ile aydınlanıyor muyuz yoksa daha karanlık bir zamana doğru mu gidiyoruz ! Gelişiyor muyuz yoksa uygarlıkla birlikte zehirleniyor muyuz !  Acaba yazar haklı mı ?  Böyle şeyler mi olacak gelecekte ?  Bilim kurgu eserlerinin en sevdiğim yanı bu olmuştur zaten. Farklı metaforlarla üstü kapalı mükemmel toplum eleştirisi yaparlar ve hayal gücünüzü inanılmaz zorlarlar.


Technobabylon tıpkı The Time Machine kitabı gibi gelecek tasviri yapan bir oyun. Ama bu sefer yüz binlerce yıl ileriye değil çok daha yakın bir tarihe 2087 ye gidiyoruz. Oyunu oynarken ilk fark edeceğiniz şey,  Oyunun yapan kişilerin çok ayrıntılı ve gerçekçi bir gelecek dünyası inşa etmeleri, yani ortaya koydukları kavramlar ve olgular sadece farazi ya da fantezi unsurları olmaktan ziyade hepsi oldukça inandırıcı ve olma olasılığı yüksek öngörüler.


Bu da açıkça gösteriyor ki, bu oyunu yapan adamlar sadece bilimi seven ve merak duyan insanlar değil, gerçekten bilimi bilen ve anlayan insanlardan tarafından yapıldığı. Bilim konularına aşına iseniz ve bilginiz varsa bu oyunu ayrı bir seveceksiniz, eğer yoksa bilimsel içerikler ve konuşmalar biraz bunaltıcı gelebilir.


Dediğim gibi yıl 2087 teknoloji almış başını yürümüş. Hologramlar, robotlar, şehirleri bile yöneten gelişmiş yapay zeka,  genetik mühendisliği ve İnternetin geleceği Trance, ( yani her şeyin mümkün olduğu bir sanal gerçeklik dünyası ), ama tüm bunlara rağmen dünya iyi bir yer olmaktan çok uzakta. Bir tarafta mega zenginler, diğer tarafta ultra fakirlerden oluşan bölünmüş bir toplum. Yolsuzluk, fiziksel ve ahlaki bozulma, eşcinsellik ve cinsiyet değiştirme herkes tarafından kabul görmüş normal bir durum Technobabylon dünyasında....Bu arada en yakın çalışma arkadaşınızın bir zamanlar erkek olduğunu öğrenmeniz hiç şaşılası bir durum değil buralarda...Hanı olur ya, niyeti bozar aklınızdan bir şeyler geçerse diye, uyarmak istedim.


Oyunu oynamayı düşünenler için bir kaç tavsiyede bulunmak istiyorum.Oyunda ziyaret ettiğiniz her alan oyunun geçtiği şehir olan Newton hakkında size bilgiler veriyor. Çevredeki hemen hemen her şeye tıklayarak bu bilgilere ulaşabilirsiniz. Karakterlerle yaptığınız konuşmalarda bütün konuşma seçeneklerini kullanarak bu dünya hakkında daha fazla bilgi sahibi olabilirsiniz. Ama baştan söyleyeyim bu yaptığınız konuşmalar, eğer muhabbeti uzatırsanız 10, 15 dakikayı bulabiliyor. 


Bir de belli aralıklarla telefonunuza düşen haber bültenleri var. Bu haberlerde politik, kültürel bilgilerin yanı sıra büyük şirketler ve güç odakları hakkında da detaylı bilgi sahibi olabilirsiniz. Bu dünya ilgili ne kadar çok şey öğrenirseniz oyundan alacağınız keyif de kat ve kat artacaktır. Bu yüzden hiç bir detayı atlamamak önemli. Diğer şey ise oyundaki bulmacaları yardım almadan kendiniz çözmeniz. Yalan yok, yer yer zorlanabilirsiniz ama yılmayın.  Sizden istenilen şeyi, elde edeceğiniz bilgilerle doğru ilişkilendirerek bunları çözebilirsiniz. Yapmış olduğunuz bu beyin fırtınası ve ardından gelen başarı ile inanılmaz bir tatmin yaşayabilirsiniz.


Oyunun oynama süresi de oldukça tatminkar, ama tabi ki de oynayan kişiye göre değişebilir. Eğer yukarıda söylemiş olduğun tavsiyeler doğrultusunda oynarsanız 30 saati devirirsiniz. Ama yok, uzun muhabbetler beni sıkar, çevredeki detaylar, bilgiler benim için önemli değil, bulmacaları da çözmekle uğraşamam derseniz 10 saat gibi bir sürede rahatlıkla bitirirsiniz oyunu. He o zamanda bu oyunun oynamanın bir anlamı olur mu ? Size bir şeyler katar ve hissettirir mi ? Hiç sanmıyorum. Sadece oyna'mış' gibi yaparsınız.


Oyun için eksi diyebileceğim tek bir yönü var. İyi bir ingilizce gerektiriyor. Aslında iyiden kastım, geniş bir ingilizce kelime ve deyim bilgisi istiyor. Günlük ingilizce de pek kullanılmayan  heuristic, chromatograph, aphasia, angiosperm, germination, euphemistic, botulism, extrapolate gibi  bilimsel ve tıbbi kelimeler içermesi. Anlayacağınız bazen sözlük karıştırmanız gerekebiliyor. Bu benim açımdan pek sorun değil aksine yukarıda saydığım  kelimeleri öğrenmemde faydası olduğu için olumlu bir şey. 


Allahım yeni çenem düştü ve yine uzun bir yazı oldu. Son cümle olarak şunu söyleyip bitiriyorum. Technobabylon, Wadjet Eye Games diğer oyunları gibi point-and-click adventure oyunu. Bu türe ilginiz varsa, hani derler ya taş gibi hatun diye... Alın size türünün en iyi  örneklerinden biri olan taş gibi bir adventure oyunu... Sizde, benle aynı hataya düşüp bu oyunu oynamak için fazla vakit kaybetmeyin derim. Şimdiden okuyan herkese teşekkür ediyor ve bol oyunlu günler diliyorum.

author: {'steamid': '76561198302208299', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 1177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1177, 'last_played': 1652937172}
review:
Technobabylon is a modern retro-styled Point & Click adventure game.  To me it seems to have a lot of inspiration or similar elements from things like 'The Matrix', 'Ready Player One', 'Minority Report' and VR/AR in general.  It's a Cyberpunk dystopian future setting which isn't a genre I really like, but it has a good enough story that's well written and I found it interesting enough to keep playing through.  The gameplay and even parts of the story remind me a lot of their other game 'Gemini Rue'.  They have a very similar vibe at times.  The alternating main character and eventual switching between characters is also a very similar design.

This game was longer and more complex than I had expected and it does have some of the pitfalls that some people hate in a point & click.  First off there is a fair share of pixel hunting.  While many modern point and click games utilize a hotspot option (usually one you can turn on and off or access by pressing something like spacebar), but this one unfortunately does not.  This leads to quite a bit of pixel hunting in the game to try and find all interactive spots.  Another one that many people may dislike is that some of the puzzles do not have enough clues to figure out or aren't intuitive to solve.  There's a lot of utilizing a communication device (traveler or wetware) in the game in addition to utilizing inventory items and dialogue to progress.  I don't know if I'd say the puzzles involved the dreaded "Moon Logic" of some 90's games, but there are definitely some parts that will either require a walkthrough or at least patience with exhausting every dialogue option as well trying everything in your inventory on every other item and hotspot.  This can be frustrating, but it can be worked through with a little patience.

This game does have Trans and Homosexual (possibly Bi-sexual) characters in it.  If you don't like that in your games I would say the amount of representation in the game is minimal and for those who do want and enjoy it, it's small but probably meaningful for them.  While in someways this game has a lot positive representations showing several Black and Asian characters as high powered and successful, or for example by actually making the setting of the game someplace in the Horn of Africa and showing Texas, USA as a warlord driven  backwards place.  However, for every positive representation there are also some that feel a little offensive.   For example, the Chinese character Ran Shou Man who embodies many negative stereotypes about Asians.  The character Jinsil is someones avatar but they choose to use a covered woman who uses Arabic words and belongs to a group called Jahiliyah (the term used for the pre-Islamic era in Arabic meaning ignorance).  Her character appears to be for all intents and purposes another portrayal of a Muslim Terrorist of sorts.  The character is a cover for someone who isn't Arab or Muslim but the representation still comes across as portraying that stereotype.  I'm a little torn since I really enjoyed hearing and seeing some Arabic/Arab/Muslim representation at all, but I didn't like the implications and stereotypes it played on.

There are 40 achievements in this game which is a decent amount.  The achievements also cover a nice array of story unlocked to specific action unlocked.  This game often gives you choices how to handle a situation and there can be 2-3 choices.  16 of the achievements are choice based from 7 different scenarios so the maximum you can collect of those on a single playthrough without using strategic saving methods would be 7 but you will unlock one of the option no matter what as they are part of the story progression.  10 of these are story progression unlocked by completing a chapter so 17 total are guaranteed if you finish the game.  I unlocked 26 through natural gameplay without a walkthrough.  Most are easy to pick up, but I did need to refer to a guide for 2 of them.  A single playthrough probably averages 10-12 hours.  My first time was around 12 my second time I was trying to pick up missed achievements.  I used strategic saves and still explored thoroughly and depleted all dialogue options.  That came close to 8 hours.  If you skip through all the dialogues you could probably complete it much quicker.  Though there are different approaches to problems and different dialogue choices available nothing really changes in the story other than a few minor details in the characters dialogues.  It's really more the illusion of choice but some choices will have a slightly different cut scene afterwards like how you deal with the bomber at the train.  Everything else proceeds the same.

Overall, if you like Point & Clicks you'll probably enjoy this game.  If you are easily frustrated by pixel hunting or puzzles... probably best to avoid.  If you enjoyed other Wadjet Eye games like Gemini Rue, you'll probably enjoy this as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115250784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1360, 'last_played': 1650448376}
review: Maybe Wadjet Eye games just aren't for me. Illogical puzzles and a convoluted storyline make this a frustrating and tedious experience. The art style makes it hard to see what you're supposed to do or read the (copious amounts of) text. And the game repeatedly refers to embryos as children and uses this to legitimate characters' actions, which is just bizarre. If you enjoyed the Blackwell games maybe you'll have a better time than me. (Play time is way off, I left the game running.)

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198116761228', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1211, 'last_played': 1648692388}
review: It's an okay story. The setting was the most interesting aspect of the game to me. On technical side I found a bug, where Regis goes out of the final room and back again. If you go out again, you won't be able to go back inside, despite the door being open. It's these technical aspects, that come with AGE limitations that are something that shouldn't happen at this stage in the industry. Music and artwork is immersive enough. The puzzles were tedious at times, but nothing extremely illogical.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987089584', 'num_games_owned': 3301, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1642951409}
review:
(Follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42150626-Jarl%2527s-Game-Treasury/]my curator[/url] for more reviews like this)

My favorite Wadjet-Eye published adventure game. The artwork is gorgeous, the writing is good and the story well-constructed.

In Technobabylon, you get to control three characters whose stories are intertwined: the police officers Regis and Lao, and trance-addicted bum Latha. The game's plot it kicked off when Regis is blackmailed into bombing Latha's apartment building. He only went along with the blackmailer because he thought the building was empty. Latha thinks the police wants her dead. And so you control Regis, his partner Lao, and the fugitive Latha in alternating chapters, trying to find out what's going on.

It's a well-told story with many plot threads that slowly unravel as you uncover more and more info with each chapter. There are plenty of interesting and beautifully illustrated locations in the game, both real and virtual: the Trance is the futuristic cyberpunk replacement of the internet, which you can enter through a wetware interface implanted in your brain. It's like descending into a shared dreamworld, and a lot of people are addicted to it, letting their bodies wither away while their minds roam the Trance. Very cool concept.

Puzzles are decently challenging but not too hard. Most of them are logical, and several allow for alternate solutions. An early puzzle that requires you to unlock a door has three different solutions, for example. It's very cool to see this in an adventure game because it adds a bit of replayability and makes you less likely to get stuck.

All in all, the mix of amazing visuals, interesting cyberpunk story, compelling characters and decent puzzles makes this my favorite of the Wadjet Eye adventure games. Highly recommended to any point & click fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009690713', 'num_games_owned': 577, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 998, 'last_played': 1647837136}

author: {'steamid': '76561198051614419', 'num_games_owned': 711, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 961, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 961, 'last_played': 1478633845}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996123525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1193, 'last_played': 1648337954}
review:
Technobabylon is an absolute gem. Superb writing, amazing voice work, mature worldbuilding and puzzles that actually make sense. The extra puzzle layer granted by cyberpunk tech works wonders for the point & click formula. 

Rating: five out of five Cheffie kisses.

author: {'steamid': '76561198187222357', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1598252365}
review: Absolutely superb. Such a joy to play. Short  - savor it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989280149', 'num_games_owned': 2540, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1643256414}
review:
While I wish the game were less pixelated, I have to admit the art was very good all the same; but of course you play a game like this for story, characters and setting, and I must say they were all very good (though I hated some of the main characters' decisions... but they are not me, really). The world building in particular was superb -- I read many of the "news stories" in the game which are there (mostly) just for atmosphere, and this world feels well-realized, full of things which are wonderful and scary at the same time. In other words, the world elicits exactly the feelings a good cyberpunk story should evoke.

Moreover, the puzzles are very logical, but not too easy -- a few were creative and even funny. I never reached for a walkthrough, but I had to think hard and try many different things a few times.

All in all, a good game, I'd love to see the sequel.

Score: 83/100.

author: {'steamid': '76561198273552285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1646530048}
review:
I really wanted to love this game, as I love Wadjet Eye Games. BUT sadly I lost interest in this game, and am not sure I will finish it. 
Like some of the others have already said, a lot of the puzzles make no logical sense, and it seems like there is a requirement of prior knowledge to how this world works. I honestly have no idea how people would get through this game without a walkthrough, or just a massive amount of patience pixel-hunting. But at that point, it sort of ruins the fun.

I also found there was too much dialogue. I am not even sure how to expand on that, but..it just felt unnecessary. I don't have the patience to click through all the dialogue options when I barely know what they're talking about anyway.

The game is BEAUTIFUL though. The pixel art, elements of the story, some of the puzzles, the characters...all very good.

I think if you're a sci-fi nerd with a lot of patience, you will probably enjoy this more. The game doesn't deserve a thumbs down, but since there isn't a neutral option I am sorry, it's getting the thumbs down.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998332408', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 1311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1311, 'last_played': 1646414514}
review:
Almost 7 years after Technobabylon's release, its vision of the future feels even more prescient than it did before.  James Dearden's story of AI, VR and conspiracy was another major win for Wadjet Eye as a publisher and is up there with their other best works like Primordia and Unavowed.

Ben Chandler's art is fantastic as always, the dialogue and interactions are extremely funny but also well written and interesting.  The voice acting set a new high watermark for Wadjet Eye and the characters, even minor ones, were always interesting and fun, with one notable exception.

I find the Mandala character to be underdevoloped, not particularly intesting and unfortunately probably the least well acted of all the characters in the game.  Not that she was really that bad (character or actor) but just compared to Regis and Lao (and their actors) she fell flat for me.

That and some major unanswered questions from the plot hold this one back ever so sligtly, though I am excited to find out if/how these get dealt with in the sequel.  It may make me go back and appreciate this game even more.

author: {'steamid': '76561199021129796', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 835, 'last_played': 1644682515}
review:
Hervorragendes Retro Point 'n' Click Dystopie/SciFi-Adventure. 

2087. Die Megacity "Newton" wird seit 20 Jahren von einer AI, "Central", gemanagt. Nicht alle sind glücklich damit, z.B. der Polizist Charlie Regis. Die junge Arbeitslose Latha Sesame hingegen nutzt die Grundversorgung durch "Central", um sich meist in einer Virtual Reality namens "Trance" aufzuhalten. Das findet ein plötzliches Ende, als ihr Zimmer in die Luft fliegt. Charlie Regis und sein Partner Max Lao sind unterdessen dabei, einen "Mindjacker" zu verfolgen, jemanden, der die Geistesinhalte Anderer stiehlt. Diese beiden Erzählstränge wachsen zu einer Story über eine Verschwörung zusammen. Und noch ein bisschen mehr.

Erzählt wird aus der Perspektive von Latha, Charlie, Max und Vicky, einer weiteren Protagonistin, die aber erst später dazu kommt. Die Story bietet mehrere Twists und zusätzlich mehrere Enden, je nachdem, welche Entscheidungen die Protagonisten treffen. 

Das alles ist spannend erzählt mit gutem Flow, gutem Voice-Acting und Aufgaben, die fair, also nicht so extrem schwer sind, dass der Fortgang der Story ewig blockiert wird, und die in der Regel auf mehreren verschiedenen Wegen gelöst werden können.

Unbedingt empfehlenswert

author: {'steamid': '76561198284687305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 972, 'last_played': 1652321662}
review: Been looking for this game for 10 years. god damn have i missed it. i remember when it was on gamejolt, if anyone knows where i can find the version where you have to stop i chinese woman from killing herself on the roof of a tower let me know, seriously i cant be the only one who remembers it right?

author: {'steamid': '76561198023879124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1643409565}
review:
A very competent point and click with an original take on the genere. This is not a frustratingly difficult game, but I think this is a plus in a lovingly crafted game like this. I really liked how they tied the puzzles to the story progression, locations, genere and the techology. This gives the game a really good flow, that kept me engaged in the story and what was going on. There was very little running around in an area that is too large, and losing track of what is going on. The only thing I wished for, was to follow each character for a bit longer at the time.

As someone who loves both cyberpunk and has played point and click adventures for 30+ years, this is an easy recommandation. I would like to say that the sum is greater than the parts, but that would be a bit harsh. Because this is a really good package, made by people who obviously have put a lot of tought and effort into all aspects of the game. They have taken some of the best aspects of the genere, and even made some of the worst aspects of the genere work in this game (I'm looking at you Sierra) without them being too punishing or feel like padding.

An easy recommandation, except if you want really difficult puzzles. This is an instant classic, and a must play for anyone who likes the genere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169261698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1499719189}
review: Dieses Spiel wurde mir vom Entwickler zur Verfügung gestellt. Dennoch muss ich Ehrlich sagen, dass das kein Spiel für mich ist und ich keinen Spaß daran finde es zu spielen. Was keinesfalls abwertend klingen soll, das Spiel hat sehr viel Liebe zum Detail, guten Soundtrack und man merkt, dass sich bei der Entwicklung Mühe gegeben wurde. Ich werde es Persönlich nicht weiterspielen Empfehle es trotzdem für jeden es einmal selber ausprobiert zu haben

author: {'steamid': '76561198060567786', 'num_games_owned': 397, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1050, 'last_played': 1642277931}
review: Top-tier cyberpunk point and click story

author: {'steamid': '76561197999045915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 725, 'last_played': 1641956287}
review:
A great little piece of science fiction writing- interesting setting and storyline, interesting and unique characters, and some really unique and interesting puzzles- and honestly the character portraits deserve a shoutout too for their diverse cast and great presentation of emotions. Unfortunately, it also comes with the standard issues of the genre and engine- poor conveyance on what are interactable objects and a few moon logic puzzles along the way.

All the same, well worth playing and enjoying for the story and character interactions- just don't feel hesitant to go pop up a walkthrough if you get stuck on a puzzle, most of the halted momementum comes down to poor conveyance more than a lack of logic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198284188784', 'num_games_owned': 143, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1641669836}

author: {'steamid': '76561197986527965', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 415, 'playtime_forever': 825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 825, 'last_played': 1641524639}
review:
Good point and click game. Plot is good, stories are interesting, characters are decent, dialogue good, some humor. Puzzles are almost all fair.

On the downside, graphics are fine for the most part but there're 1 or 2 spots where an object you need sort of blends in and is difficult to see. There will probably be two or three parts where it's difficult & timely to figure out what you're supposed to be doing.

Game can be a little bit buggy. One I ran into several times was that the dialogue/check screen would occasionally jump straight to the end and close out over and over, making it impossible to read/hear anything. A simple reload always fixed it. Also managed to bug out the door at the very end of the game making it impossible to go back into it. Again, a reload solved this problem.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986483347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 1332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 897, 'last_played': 1683655994}
review:
This is one of the best point & click adventures that I have played in a very long time. The story is very well written and there is a bit of nonlinearity in the gameplay, but (thankfully) it's mostly linear and understandable. The puzzles and riddles are mostly quite logical and simple, so I only had to look up in a walkthrough three or four times.

To put it shortly: if you like point & click adventures in a cyberpunk setting, then playing this game is a must have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012962211', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 172, 'playtime_forever': 916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 916, 'last_played': 1641262340}
review:
Okay, first things first: This game is the most 2021 game I've ever played...despite being made in 2015. The sci-fi dystopian setting often feels like the fever-dream of Progressive activists from present day NYC, with one of the MCs being a hard-done-by orphan refugee immigrant and another being a trans individual who has transitioned PERFECTLY and SEAMLESSLY; one case focuses on the murder of an interracial gay couple, and another on an attempted terrorist from theocratic Texas (blonde? check! white? check! imaginary villainous version of Christianity? check!) where apparently life begins at conception (the HORROR! the horror...) but children are modified in the womb to become living bombs...for...some reason? It's flat-out ludicrous. You can just feel the frothing ignorance-born hatred the game-makers have for America's "fly-over" country, as well as the flagrant condescension towards those they see as "disadvantaged" (women, non-whites, homosexuals, trans folks, etc.). Despite this game NOT being set in the USA, everywhere outside the USA is painted in broad strokes if at all -- and the portrait is rarely ever flattering, though apparently in this game's setting racial harmony has finally taken root in South Africa! It'd be hilarious if you couldn't feel the genuine HATE this team had for the people they depicted thusly.

That said, the game itself is the usual excellence we expect from Wadjet Eye. The mechanics are solid, the puzzles are usually challenging but intuitive (with one or two exceptions that required insane leaps of logic), the characters are generally interesting, the voicework is great, the mysteries are engaging (and in two cases legitimately surprised me -- a hard thing to do nowadays!), and if not for those weird "Current Year-isms" I mentioned previously, this would be an easy recommendation. Unfortunately, I just played "Whispers of a Machine" and that one did a lot of the same things, only with more subtlety, less bombast, and none of the hate. So this one's a cautious "Yes," as long as you can see past the hysteria that clearly blinded the creators.

review:
It has been ages since I last played a point and click adventure. This game holds to the high standards of the massive games of yesterday in the genre, and then some. 

The game is set in a future, cyberpunk setting. The story is mindnumbingly good! 

Must have game for everyone who like to jog their minds and solve difficult puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118469522', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1164, 'last_played': 1635974281}
review: Хотя другие игры из Dark Futures Bundle меня не разочаровали (хотя особых восторгов на контрасте с Primordia не вызвали, однако играть было всё равно очень интересно), данная игра мне вообще очень понравилась: прекрасный сюжет, его развитие, аудио- и визуальное сопровождение и т.д. В очередной раз благодарен студии: если раньше я хотел посмотреть хороший фильм, я искал по тегу, например, "Мартин Скорсезе" и получал если и не шедевр, то фильм не ниже определённой (высокой!) планки. Теперь же, если я хочу сыграть в какую-нибудь качественную сюжетную адвенчуру, я просто перехожу на страницу студии! Так держать, молодцы!

review:
Really fantastic adventure game with unusually good writing and story!
I enjoyed all the old classic P&C's as a kid, and recently got back into them with 'Beyond a Steel Sky' (also excellent).  Anyway, this is a perfect follow up - some pretty similar concepts but quite a bit darker and the ideas are pushed further and deeper.  Keen to try the other Wadjet Eye games now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027962229', 'num_games_owned': 1858, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 876, 'last_played': 1632314013}
review:
Рекомендую! Клевая вещь, куда интереснее, чем Gemini Rue.

Понравилось:
✔️Интересный сюжет, детективная история
✔️Озвучка у всех персонажей классная, подобраны актеры идеально, персонажи запоминающиеся, Шеффи - вообще шик
✔️Хорошие диалоги
✔️Есть юмор
✔️Атмосфера присутствует
✔️Звуковое сопровождение хорошее
✔️Это хоть и типичный point&click, лютого пиксельхантинга здесь нет, все действия логичны, и не надо тыкать все предметы на все вокруг, можно пройти и без подсказок


Не понравилось:
❌Тексты с пиксельным шрифтом немного тяжко читать 

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197983755104', 'num_games_owned': 903, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1113, 'last_played': 1630868005}
review:
Wadjet Eye is quickly becoming one of my favorite studios, all of their games I have played with so far have been really good (Gemini Rue, Primordia) but with Technobabylon they sealed the deal for me.

If you love old-school Lucasarts type point and click adventure games, murder-mysteries and cyberpunk settings, then do yourself a favor and buy Technobabylon. It's amazing!

And now excuse me, I have to go and buy my next Wadjet Eye game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964871634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 701, 'last_played': 1630801123}
review:
Story was good, characters were fine - but the real star is the setting. The writers built a detailed and realistic future world. And while a lot of games are made by science fans - this game was clearly made by people who actually know science. The concepts that are brought up aren't just speculative fantasy - they're grounded in hard science which, impressively, gets implemented in the game mechanics - like reprogramming robotic personalities or decoding messages hidden inside the DNA of bioengineered plants. It's a detailed look at a potential future for technology - and the societal consequences. It's cyberpunk - but updated to match what technology might actually be capable of a hundred years from now.

In terms of the game mechanics, I liked them - well-implemented. The puzzles weren't easy, but they also didn't follow any sort of weird dream logic that you sometimes see in point-and-click games. Dialogue options between characters is well-written and plentiful. And despite the seriousness of the story and setting, there's plenty of humor in there as well.

If you really, really have no head for science - you might feel a bit overwhelmed, because the game doesn't hold back on its science and tech. But I don't think it leaves people behind, either. And if you're really into science - then this really just is like diving into a sweet, sweet pool of science and seeing a vision of the future at the bottom of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004352613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 735, 'last_played': 1700106505}
review:
If you're a fan of cyberpunk literature and adventure games, you will almost certainly enjoy Technobabylon.
The writing is fantastic, but I won't get into too much detail to avoid spoiling anything.
As for the gameplay, it's a point and click adventure game, exactly what it says on the tin. It avoids the more frustrating trappings of some adventure games (e.g. nonsense puzzles, pixel hunting, letting the player soft-lock themselves).
Overall, it's great. Definitely worth the $15 if you're into adventure games and/or cyberpunk lit.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966874915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1630322018}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053304170', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1801, 'last_played': 1629740530}
review:
Excellent. One of the best 2D pixel art point and clicks I've played. It honestly feels a bit empty and foreign when you start since it doesn't exactly conform to the control set one might be used to. There are only two interactions, left click: use and right click: inspect. As you get into it you'll find it's surprisingly rich however.
There are also many environments and one can tell that a lot of love and hard work went into it.

Most importantly, as always, is the story. It takes you on a very immersive and beautiful ride through its futuristic setting. Every character is well thought out and believable and you find yourself empathising with each one's situation. The voice acting is also impeccable. The twists in the plot are also surprising and keeps the player engaged as they wonder what will happen next.

In terms of the puzzles, they are all pretty intuitive. Of course, you're in the future though, so sometimes you might have to think a bit out of the box to solve that puzzle that might not always be in your every day frame of reference.

The game is also very good value for money. If, like me, you inspect everything and try listen to every dialogue sequence you'll find the content is well worth the price.

If there's one thing that could have been better it's the programming of the dialogue tree. There are some instances where you might feel like characters are just saying the same thing they said before but in a different way or where dialogue options that you've already covered will remain until you run through them again. That's a minor issue though.

I'd give Technobabylon an 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198013502425', 'num_games_owned': 1816, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1629047610}
review:
A Sci-Fi adventure/story that manages to cover some genuinely interesting ideas without getting too heady. Some good humor, reasonably well developed world-building. It's great.

If I had one complaint, it would be that the pacing isn't always satisfying - when a chapter ended, I found myself wanting to close the game instead of being at the edge of my seat. And ultimately the 'reveal' of the motivations of the antagonist(s) comes way too late in the game. And it's not convincing that the antagonists did what they did for the reasons/motivations given.

Nevertheless - very competent point and click adventure in a creative SCI-FI setting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198320935826', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 741, 'last_played': 1628700926}
review: Smart and well written adventure game that got me hooked and immersed in its detailed world within the first couple of minutes. I can really recommend this game to anyone who's into story-heavy games with a lot of plot twist and clever puzzles. I must say though that some of the puzzles were so easy that it felt like an arcade game while other puzzles were extremely unobvious so I had to use a walkthrough. It took me 12 hours to play through so it's not too short and not dragging on too long. If you've played Beneath a Steel Sky you're definitely going to love this one as it has a lot of parallels.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972337172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 356, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1627883731}
review:
A point and click game mainly comes down to 3 factors:
1) Puzzles - Good, but nothing mind blowing
2) Story - Forgettable
3) Voice acting - Mixed (some characters are deadpan, most are done well)

Overall it's a decent point and click game. This is another "overwhelmingly positive" game that would get more mixed votes than thumbs up if steam allowed it. For a wadjeteye game, check out Unavowed if you haven't yet, it is much better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055662844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1089, 'last_played': 1626139192}
review:
Fantastic!
* Positive queer representation
*dialogue changes based on choices from several chapters ago
*riveting story

...eh
*dialogue options for finding out someone is trans have not aged well
*don't like either of the options for the Big Choice
*somethings have different functions depending on where you click

Overall I really loved this game.  There were some instances of 'I know what I need to do, but I can't find an object that does that' which was frustrating.   Even when I was stuck on a puzzle the captivating plot was more than enough motivation to keep at it.  If you are at all interested in point and click or cyberpunk give this a try!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970705717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1689111810}
review: An enjoyable cyberpunk romp that explores the ethics and potential of genetic engineering in a retro dystopic setting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997259645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1663995194}
review:
A few hours in and it's a very fair point-and-click (fair being "doesn't make you do totally illogical stuff). A lot of the choices feel impactful, the puzzles are really varied and can push the genre a little (there was a real-time stealth puzzle in the section I just cleared, and that's pretty novel for point-and-click); I've really enjoyed that.

Sound and graphics are great, the pixel art is really well done and the designers put it to really interesting use. Within the game there's a VR internet thing called "the Trance" and sprites/characters within the Trance are done in a lower res, more cartoony style than in the real world--it works really well given the pixel medium. 

Soundwise nothing has taken my breath away, but all the bleeps and bloops are where they should be. Actually, shoutout to the voice-acting, everything is well-executed and strikes a nice balance of humor and drama.

I've enjoyed the world, story, and characters. It's got a lot of detail and original content to immerse oneself in, but not so much that it feels tiring to do so. The mystery is still unfolding for me, but I really enjoy it so far. The game is very tasteful and diverse in its cast without ever feeling like it's tokenizing its characters--this is a huge deal, actually. I just feel like everyone's human, and I've never reached a point in the story where I've been bored or turned off. The main characters are even people I feel like I could care for.

Overall, I'm looking forward to finishing this game! It's been a blast.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993442001', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1625357861}
review:
Great point-n-click game! Writing, voice-acting, pixel-art, story are all top-notch. Some of the puzzles can be a bit frustrating and pixel-hunting-y, but nothing too obscene.

If you are looking for a point and click with gritty cyberpunk tone, this is a great game for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198063093962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 882, 'last_played': 1625361436}
review: I have mixed feelings about this game, but for the most part they are mostly positive. The pixel art is well done. The artists really focused on the small details, especially in the animation. The color palette and background images were beautiful. The music wasn't too annoying either surprisingly.  The story kept my interest during the first half, though later some inconsistencies made me lose interest for a while. I like that it was fully voice acted, but some dialogue points were too long. The puzzles were overall easy to figure out and the mechanics used to carry out solving them weren't too complicated. Later sections of the game had illogical ways to solve the puzzles or the way to solve them weren't easy to figure out. An example involves a puzzle with suspects and evidence where the final piece of evidence wasn't easy to obtain because the puzzle required the player to do something specific which is easy to overlook.  In the end, I feel the game was a fun experience and I will look for other games from this company in the future. However, it doesn't have much reason for me to replay it though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087950543', 'num_games_owned': 731, 'num_reviews': 206, 'playtime_forever': 915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 959, 'last_played': 1625338518}
review:
Ещё в прошлом году я приобрёл себе «Technobabylon» по нескольким причинам: издателем этой игры были «Wadjet Eye Games» (а они издали некоторые игры, которые мне зашли), оценки в Steam были высокими (какие тогда были – я не помню, но на момент написания обзора – 95% положительных обзоров), сеттинг будущего, а сюжет представлял собой детективную историю.

И вот только в этом году я смог пройти её. Получил ли удовольствие от прохождения? Честно говоря, не совсем. На мой взгляд, данной игре больше присуща средняя оценка, но т.к. в Steam этого до сих пор нельзя сделать, то я решил написать положительный обзор.

Из явных плюсов могу выделить дизайн локаций (понимаю, что не всем нравится пиксель-арт, но мне зашло) и квестовую составляющую: загадки не прям лёгкие, но решить самому возможно, хотя всё же бывали моменты, когда мне не было понятно решение, но благо, есть прохождения.

Из явных минусов:
[olist]
[*][b]Техническая сторона.[/b] Я уже привык к проблемам, которые возникают в играх, сделанных на движке «Adventure Game Studio» (или просто AGS), но это не отменяет того факта, что их надо отметить: нет нормальной поддержки широкоформатного разрешения (точнее, технически она есть, но по факту, изображение в 800*600 просто растягивается на ваш экран и никак не адаптируется), странные настройки лаунчера; ну и самое бесячее: часто бывают случаи, когда окна с текстом проигрываются на миллисекунду, и ты попросту не успеваешь прочитать их. Единственное решение – перезапустить игру (даже повторные загрузки сохранений не помогают). И в играх на этом движке есть костыль: просто в меню добавляется кнопка «Перезагрузить» (в «Primordia» точно такое было), которая позволяет сразу перезагрузить игру и продолжить с того момента, где остановился, а не постоянно выходить из игры и заходить в неё вновь множество раз. Вот только почему-то в «Technobabylon» такого нет, из-за чего приходится проделывать те последние действия, не забыв сохраниться перед этим.

[*][b]Отсутствие интерактивности.[/b] Да, технически она есть, но по факту, только в самом конце от того, [spoiler]выбрали вы «Central» или Нину[/spoiler], будет зависеть концовка; всё, что было до этого, влияет только на некоторые реплики и достижения.
[/olist]

На мой взгляд, главная загвоздка – в сюжете (он и вызвал смешанные эмоции). Многие в обзорах хвалят его, но честно, история тут хоть и неплоха, но назвать её интересной я никак не могу. Вот мои претензии:
[list]
[*][spoiler]Реджи с Лао в какой-то момент предполагают, что Кризел СЛУЧАЙНЫМ образом оставил себе часть воспоминаний Бакстера, из-за чего тот начал мстить Реджи. И вроде бы это звучит логично (и объясняет, откуда он знал многое про Реджи), вот только потом Кризел говорит, что ему настолько понравилась жизни Бакстера, что он решил оставить эту самую месть себе… Чем ему так понравился Бакстер (нам в игре дают минимум инфы про него)? Зачем ему эта вообще месть? Честно, этот момент вообще не понятен мне.[/spoiler]

[*][spoiler]Нина нам сообщает, что благодаря её значимым связям ИИ «Central» не замечает того, что происходит в ресторане. Конечно, нам потом говорят, что Нина стояла за разработкой «Central», и можно предположить, какие у неё связи… Вот только всё равно непонятно, как можно было обойти ИИ, у которого под контролем весь город находится и есть доступ к информации на всех людей?[/spoiler]

[*][spoiler]В самом конце «Central» рассказывает Лате, что он ничего не знал ни про неё, ни про её сродство с ИИ, и вообще, ей подменили данные… КАК?! Как у ИИ, который контролирует ВСЁ, могли подменять данные? В это верится с большим трудом.[/spoiler]
[/list]

В итоге мы получаем очень добротный квест с не самым хорошим (и не самым плохим) сюжетом, но всё же я получил удовольствие от игры, потому и оставил положительный отзыв.

author: {'steamid': '76561198813544562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 1186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1186, 'last_played': 1624580169}
review:
Lo mejor del juego es el trasfondo. La historia pone sobre la mesa la ética del manejo de embriones con preguntas que llevan la cuestión al límite: [spoiler]¿Está bien o mal usar un embrión para cosechar sus células? ¿cuál es la diferencia entre eso y gestar un humano sin cerebro y comérselo? Cuando apareció en el juego me pareció asqueroso, pero comprendo el propósito de mostrarlo[/spoiler].

Pasando del trasfondo, ideal para un libro (en serio, Technocrat Games tiene futuro en la literatura!), el juego arranca bien arriba y va bajando hasta hacerse pesado. Lo mismo pasa con otros juegos de Wadjet Eye Games, como el Resonance o Shardlight. Además la decisión de incluir diálogos tan largos, ocupando veinte minutos o más se hace tedioso. En serio, hay otras maneras de introducir contexto y profundidad.

En definitiva: es una obra interesante en su planteo, que te va a rascar la comezón. Vale la pena (nunca mejor dicho).

author: {'steamid': '76561197997402509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 609, 'last_played': 1624582007}
review: you can learn about the cyber future

author: {'steamid': '76561198044218218', 'num_games_owned': 479, 'num_reviews': 247, 'playtime_forever': 663, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 663, 'last_played': 1624406281}
review:
Technobabylon me trouxe a nostalgia dos jogos point-and-click dos anos 90, tais como The Dig e Full Throttle, que tanto marcaram minha infância. Com uma história envolvente, personagens carismáticos, visual meio cyperpunk e uma ótima trilha sonora, esse é um jogo que vai te desafiar com seus puzzles que às vezes são desafiadores e não tão óbvios.
Sem dúvida, algo que fez muita diferença na produção foram as vozes dos personagens que são extremamente bem feitas, com diálogos interessantes e até bem humorados. As vozes das personagens Dr. Lao e Latha realmente são um destaque, transmitindo muita naturalidade e emoção.

Apesar de ser uma produção mais modesta e contando com um time de desenvolvedores bem enxuto, Technobabylon é uma ótima aventura point-and-click para quem gosta de uma história inteligente e cheia de reviravoltas.
