author: {'steamid': '76561198121293545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1577307445}
review:
Old-school style point-and-click adventura s krásnou futuristickou grafikou plnou dronů a neonů, strhujícím příběhem, perfektním voice-actingem a vyváženou náročností rébusů (párkrát asi bude potřeba se podívat do návodu, ale jinak to odsýpá celkem rychle :) ). Hra je dlouhá.

Kdo má rád cyberpunk v knížkách/filmech/hrách, nebo někdy předtím hrál klasiku Beneath a Steel Sky, tohle je něco pro vás.

P.S. Hru jsem dostal v rámci nákupu Dark Futures Bundle, všechny tituly odtud jsou hrozně super!

author: {'steamid': '76561198167271759', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1978, 'last_played': 1571660794}
review:
Thank you for another excellent story, Wadjet Eye! 
For those of you looking to sink your teeth into a post-apocalyptic noir, this is for you. Enjoy a fully voice acted game that maintains the perfect level of mysterious tension to keep you engaged in the point and click experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960721626', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1577389725}
review: This is just a superb single player adventure game - bags of atmosphere and a smart story - a bargain.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101143616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1576589712}
review: A great point and click adventure with an engaging plot and fantastic vocal talent.  I think this is an improvement on 'golden age' adventure games as the puzzles are logical and linked to the plot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970138907', 'num_games_owned': 601, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 861, 'last_played': 1656700662}
review:
I think the game itself is very good. A throwback to the old LucasArts adventure games. Nice pixelated art (although there’s a lot of text, and less pixelated fonts would make reading less annoying). It’s long, and interesting, and just challenging enough to not have to go looking for a hint on line. There’s clear love behind it, 
But the tech upon which it’s built makes it playing very annoying. It runs on AGS 3, with is a twenty-year-old engine!  
It runs on 320x200 resolution, which would be fine except most modern monitors can’t display that. touch display doesn’t work, and wide and ultrawide screens generate a lot of problems.  
It’s supposed to look and feel like a 90s adventure game, but it’s clearly not. The game’s size is 1.28 GB. I’m sure a 90s computer would not be able to run it. 
In an effort to make it feel retro, it’s built for a hardware that doesn’t exist. Maybe never existed. So it’s really easy, for this 2015 game to give you technical problems. 
I see no reason for this game to have to run with such restrictive settings, other than the fact that the developer are comfortable with the workflow and don’t want to get outside their zone of comfort.  
Most modern retro-looking games are resolution independent and get their pixilated look in more consumer-friendly ways.  
I like the look. The feel is a bit dated (it feels slugish, but that’s what old 90s games feel, so I can’t blame them for that — although why iterate on the dated formula if not to continue improving it?). And I like the game. 
But the fact that I have to fight with this modern game like it was an old piece of abandonware, makes me hesitant to recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982650217', 'num_games_owned': 630, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 635, 'last_played': 1590120443}
review:
Gorgeous little cyberpunk adventure game, great visuals and soundtrack. Interesting story and world building that engaged me. The entire game being fully voice acted was unexpected from a smaller indie title but very much appreciated. 

Puzzles were interesting and occasionally stumped me for a bit and then "F-Yeah" when you figure them out, with only a couple of spots forcing me to look up due to moon logic or a new mechanic that was never explained. But that was only 2-3 times throughout the playthrough. 

Such a refreshing change to play a game that wraps up and ends in this age of always online live services.

author: {'steamid': '76561198436507114', 'num_games_owned': 106, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 792, 'last_played': 1575775000}
review: Good puzzles for a point and click game. Good story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034938743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1081, 'last_played': 1575762397}
review:
Pros:
- Good Art
- Good world building
- Interesting concepts

Cons:
- Clunky/slow movement that's tedious throughout the game
- If you click on a door by accident or change your mind, you can't cancel the long, slow walk animation
- Uninteresting/unengaging dialogue that drones on and on. (There's literally a scene where you don't do anything except talk to 5 people). Half the game is basically a reading simulator. Show, don't tell!
- Unlikeable characters
- Puzzles often involve pixel peeping which are 0% thought, 100% waste of time.
- Interactions are often inconspicuously blended in the background, which means it's easy to miss something unless you hover over every part of backdrop (tedious)
- Hamfisted story elements/convenient plot devices, like a bomb going off in a room full of people and basically no one dying

6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198011692791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1077, 'last_played': 1575479763}
review:
Nice sci-fi adventure game with great story and setting. 

The pixelated graphics and animation are not so good, I mean they are on par with the best and worst from Sierra... twenty years ago. (just an exception for the nice portraits). On the other hand the acting (voices) is very good and the characters are lively.

The game is not particularly difficult and you shall not loose too much time trying every combinations of objetcs. But I still had to look on the net twice to get me out of some situations.

Overall if you like sci-fi, AI, bioethics, networking and french maids... you should enjoy this game!

I can't recomend it enough for anyone with interest in mystery plots/ police procedurals or clasic point and click adventures.

review: Top notch story and voice acting in this classic style point and click adventure. Interface is like Kings Quest 5 and 6 with the disappearing icon bar a the top of the screen. Made me feel right at home. It has a few unique Sci-Fi elements that I think were well implemented. This one is a winner if you're looking for your next point and click binge!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972765153', 'num_games_owned': 1095, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1573944354}
review:
Insanely addicting adventure.

Nothing much negative to say. And all of it is related to the forced low resolution of 640x400.

-Some items are hard to identify
-Mouse gets weird accelerating after you reach a certain cursor speed.

Besides that, everything is great.

-Artstyle is great
-The plot is very well told and totally captivating
-Voice acting is INSANELY good
-Great Cyberpunk feel.

Play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037296125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1191, 'last_played': 1574019198}
review: I loved the story, the music, and the characters.  The puzzles aren't so hard that you have to cheat and the solutions are intuitive.  I can't wait for the sequel!

author: {'steamid': '76561198340473600', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1088, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1079, 'last_played': 1577323374}
review:
Hey, what can I say, it's a good game indeed. 
It has a few flaws in term of puzzle arrengment, and couple not so logical motif in characters motivation, but quite a few, it's not something that ruined whole experience, but without, game for me whould be much smoother ride. 
Any how - performance was great - left pleasent feel of visiting "another world" like good movie or a book. 
Voice acting for my taste was spot-on, graphics and animation solid with many pleasant details (exept couple backgrounds). 
Story on the other hand left me with number of questions, like lacking of "arch" of Dr. Baxter, as main villian he'd need more exposition. Even Nina got more. 
Adam motivation to literally choke Ms. Reagis is quite quastoning... 
And few other flaws that I have to leave unfold in a sake of "spoiler alert". 
BUT! 
It's not make a game worse "en masse" - play it, it worth every penny!)
- It's quite "noire" and grim, had superb soundtrack and feeld as complete, living and breathing wonder) 
So if you in to cyberpunk\quest - it will work for you) 

My greatest regards to developers - your child is a beauthy!;)

I managed to get through then entire game without using a guide once (which can be rare for these types of games). Definite must buy, I really hope the sequel actually gets finished and released.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074708541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3129, 'last_played': 1568575642}
review:
Loved this game! The story pulled me in almost immediately, and kept my interest all the way through.
Technobabylon is completely immersive with a great story line, seriously good artwork and some of the best voice acting I have heard. I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970414560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1568492167}
review:
Technobabylon ist für alle interessant die Old-School Adventures, Cyberpunk und ein spannendes Sci-Fi Setting mögen. Auf dem ersten Blick wirkt es optisch etwas abschreckend, sobald man aber in der Story drin ist, öffnet sich eine wunderbar gestaltete Welt. Eine Welt, deren Geschichte sich im Hintergrund entfaltet, ohne der sehr komplexen und spannenden Hauptstoryline im Weg zu sein. 
Die Rätsel sind größtenteils fair, gelegentlich sind Objekte mit denen interagiert werden kann nicht auf dem ersten Blick erkennbar. Optionales Objekthighlighting wäre nett gewesen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027102438', 'num_games_owned': 1328, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1568462880}
review:
Point & Clickers, while not a dying genre anymore, are not as easy to make nowadays as it was (relatively) in the past.
It now stands side by side with AAA+ titles with much more impressive technology and graphical capabilities, which demands much more acting and much less thinking of the player.
Part of the challenge is that nowadays we players are much less patient than in the past.
That required of modern games of the genre to be able to create that delicate balance between being interesting and new, yet with an old-school classic mechanics, and also being challanging just enough so that one can still feel a sense of progression during the game - not being stuck for TOO long on the same obstacle, yet on the other hand not feeing that it all comes way too easily..

Unlike many modern Point-n-clickers, Technobabylon manages to strike that delicate balance just fine.
I felt it has all the good qualities of the all-times-classics of the genre: Neat 2D cyberpunk landscapes & graphics, intriguing story, top-notch voice overs, good sound design.
It also manages to make it relevant to those "impatient modern players" I've mentioned (uhm uhm like me), by not giving away the solution TOO easilyt, yet not taking TOO much of your time to figure out what's going on next.
Sure, I did use a walkthrough from time to time, but mostly, I felt I'm making progress on my own.  And that's the most important key point in this kind of games in my opinion.

As much as I love the genre and the story-rich stuff, now when I don't have so much time to invest in video games in my life I'm losing patience myself many times and don't grab games of this type so often anymore,

Luckily I felt Technobabylon made the puzzles relatively versatile (there's some additional mechanics you'll discover besides just collecting items and using them on other items), with the difficulty being just right, and along all other aspects I've mentioned beforehand this was a very nice experience and definitely worth your time if you're into Cyuberpunk AND point & click.

Also, can't wait to see how the sequel turns out :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198096608094', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 827, 'last_played': 1568429075}
review:
It's not a bad game, but it isn't "overwhelmingly positive" levels of good either. The story starts strong but gets rather longwinded through the middle of the game, and the dialogue during the last major puzzle was incredibly clumsy, lacking any emotional consistency from one dialogue option to the next, at a time when two of the main characters really needed to establish their relationship. The ending cutscene (one of them, anyway, as I've not tried the others) did quite a bit to salvage it, but on the whole the writing didn't quite round out its exploration of its major themes, in the way e.g. Primordia did.

Some very clever puzzles that offer some great mechanical world building, but also some duds. Three times I got stuck wandering around, trying all possible item/environment interactions, etc. In all three cases the solutions required... not exactly pixel hunting but finding things that were very hard to notice. And where a lot of games give you amusing diversions when they present you with hard puzzles, this one had a lot of very sparse environments in terms of interaction. Might have been a budget limitation; all those extra snide comments about the scenery rack up a lot of voice actor hours.

Some LBGT inclusivity that came across as hamfisted. And it's unfortunate, because with a few changes of pacing it could have actually contributed to the world-building. Spoiler about this aspect, but not the main plot: [spoiler]One of the two CEL agents reveals she is trans, although as far as I can tell she is voiced by a cis woman, and certainly looks like one. After a moment's thought I realized that that was quite natural, since the high-tech genetic engineering of Technobabylon's world would certainly get used for sophisticated techniques of sex reassignment. Unfortunately, that revelation was cheapened by the fact that it came roughly two minutes after introducing the game's first gay characters.[/spoiler]

Some rather serious bugs... after awhile the automatic savegame name generation system stopped working, and as far as I can tell some of my saves have disappeared (never the most recent save, fortunately, but several immediately before it, which will make it irritating to play the other endings). Broken animations in a couple places; a contentious relationship with Windows 10's screen resolution manager that makes it aggravating to launch in fullscreen; mouse acceleration that can't be turned off; an interaction system that seems more committed to preserving the "use/observe" distinction between left and right clicks than it is to making the play experience more fluid.

And y'know, I'm still glad I played it, but when there are this many positive reviews I know there are going to be a few of you who want to find out what the catch is. So here you have it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017258187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1568250235}
review:
Technobabylon is a game that I probably would never find if I hadn't looked for it, it's a hidden pearl among all the other games available in the store. I was lucky to find it when I went on a detective/point & click spree search and I bought a couple of them.
In short, this game checks a lot of boxes, so here they are:

[h1]Writing/Story/World:[/h1]
The main reason you'd buy a game like this. It is really well planned, great pacing.

Trying to predict how things would develop with the information given was very rewarding.
The characters have well distinguishable and developed personalities, with good voice acting. Their stories are not forced onto the player, they appear naturally, as they should. Same thing happens with the world, once in a while giving us a bit how society works. Those little details gave the extra flavour that makes it a living world, not just a random setting.
It also picks on some of our own world's topics and puts it into its own's version of them.

Had some good laughs with the occasional humor too. Loved the different AIs, every time.

[h1]The puzzles:[/h1]
The second reason, I'm assuming, you'd get this kind of game. They are simple. Not a dead giveaway, just enough to make you think a bit on how to proceed, but not as much as to make you frustrated and wish for a guide. There's a good balance there.

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]
I like pixel art. It's not for everyone, but it fits just right. I usually connect Point & Click games with it, but maybe that's just because I grew up with them.
In terms of composition, the sceneries are well put together and feel rich. Simple and easy to read.

[h1]Sound:[/h1]
It either fits or doesn't fit. In this game, it fits just fine. Never felt odd or misplaced. It went along well with the story and each setting felt immersive.

[h1]Summing it up[/h1]
It's a really good experience. You'll finish it in one sitting or two, well worth the time and money.
Good job to the devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988260645', 'num_games_owned': 468, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1586208447}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990204173', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1164, 'last_played': 1567438510}
review: Extremely interesting setting and story. Main negative criticism: It is necessary to do some 'pixel hunting' towards the end of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091813179', 'num_games_owned': 76, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1565876533}
review: Another amazing pixel art story game from the publishers Wadjet Eye! I found this to be a deeply engaging and well written story, with characters that you come to know quite well by the finale. There was also a good dose of grey morality in the motivations of the antagonists, making me wonder if I would make the same decisions if placed in their shoes, with their circumstances. Also, I found the futuristic cyberpunk nature of this game quite intriguing, and often found myself wondering how much of this might actually be a glimpse into a future yet to come. Thoughts that would give me mixed emotions on whether this was progress in the right direction, or something else... but definitely some good takeaway points to think about personally. Overall, I would definitely recommend giving this game your time if some or all of what I mentioned has sparked you interest :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198135441018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1154, 'last_played': 1565438142}
review:
One of the best P&C games of all time, I would say. Great atmosphere, complex story, well written characters, professional voice acting as expected from Wadjet Eye Games. The time jumps and playing different characters depending on the scenes and some scenes where your choice actually matters makes it very fun to play.
I liked how they imagined a future world would be. It's very believable and relatable. 
Go get it, you won't regret your decision, especially if  you're a P&C fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980045060', 'num_games_owned': 3463, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1626408224}
review: Fantastic modern adventure game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022879562', 'num_games_owned': 2785, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 886, 'last_played': 1487987529}
review: One of the best adventure games I have played. Puzzles are just right difficulty and make sense. The cyberpunk future world is interesting and well thought out. The story and dialogs are very enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061821567', 'num_games_owned': 481, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1708504198}
review: Although Technobabylon is worth playing just for the Gravball minigame, it also manages to build a world with an impressive level of depth - one which could probably easily contain far more stories than the one you'll play in Technobabylon. As most point-and-click games do, the majority of the gameplay consists of solving puzzles - all of which make sense, except for a single item (which you have to use by itself in the item menu in order to toggle its settings - a one off occurrence).

author: {'steamid': '76561198050407235', 'num_games_owned': 545, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1563312101}
review:
Is this game worth owning and playing? In the words of my absolute favorite character, "Oh my, yes!"

There's layers and layers of conspiracy and mystery here, all taking place in an incredibly well-built fictional world. Technology is part of, and in control of, everything in this world. People have augmented their bodies to become one with tech, which will immediately give vibes of a Deus Ex game. My only gripe here is that the motivation for one of the main characters seems silly compared to the lengths he's willing to go to satisfy said motivation, but the rest of the story is excellent. Adding much more to my review will enter spoiler territory, but as someone who is absolutely awful at solving puzzles in adventure games, I only had to look at a guide a couple of times. This is my first Wadjet Eye game, but certainly not my last.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961160364', 'num_games_owned': 525, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1563751978}
review:
The story is good. The portrait art is great, the pixel art is blah. The acting is good. I really like the cyberpunk genre and I want to support some aspects of old school game revival, but I wish we could leave some of the frustrating aspects of the genre in the past.

It's going for old school point and click which is okay, but you don't have to include the aspects that made those game so annoying at times. The puzzles on this game aren't the worst I've ever seen, but some of them are sufficiently onerous that I needed to consult a walkthrough several times because I had no idea what to do and I don't have them patience to use everything on everything else. At one point there is a puzzle that requires you to set something to a very specific number which I think you're supposed to just know? That's pretty annoying. And some of the puzzles are typical adventure game puzzles where you have to just guess what creators were thinking. It gets better towards the end though, and a handful were actually pretty fun to figure out.

Aside from that, the interface is not great and the cursor moves really slow and then hyper fast so clicking what you want is a chore, especially on a game like this where you have to run the mouse over basically every pixel to figure out if it's supposed to be something. Some dialog is easy to accidentally skip. Also, there's no explanation of the controls which is fine at first, but I didn't realize right click was technically "look at" because for the most part right and left click have the same outcome. There is at least one point in the game where you can't progress without "looking" at something, so that would have been nice to know beforehand.

It's an okay game with a good story and it runs well on integrated graphics. It's dripping in cyberpunk, so I enjoyed that. All in all not bad. Worth a couple of bucks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971569035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 362, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1562465390}

author: {'steamid': '76561198071368294', 'num_games_owned': 337, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 530, 'last_played': 1562263678}
review:
I've been on a sci-fi game kick lately. Seeing as I recently played through all the Blackwell games as well as The Shivah and Primordia, I figured playing another Wadjet Eye Games game would fit both of my recent trends. I found Technobabylon to be an extremely satisfying experiences.

The plot revolves around the exploits of two police officers as they attempt to discover the identity of a "mindjacker" (stealing someone's personality through the wired connection in their head). The game is dripping with atmosphere and has the dingy cyberpunk feeling of something like Bladerunner. The story is the primary high point of the game. I found myself more engrossed in this story than any of the other Wadjet Eye Games games. 

The one deterrent I always have when it comes to point-and-click games is the occasional puzzle which seems to defy logic. It has been a problem for every single Wadjet Eye Games game I have played so far. Luckily, there are not too many points which made me consult a walkthrough. If you have persistence, you probably won't need a walkthrough. 

The only bug I encountered has to do with the engine I believe as it has occurred in other Wadjet Eye Games games. Whenever I tab out or bring up the Steam overlay, I have to quit out of the game because all the dialogue options are rapidly skipped. Overall, this isn't a huge deal since it can be fixed by simply restarting the game. 

Overall, Technobabylon is more than worth the money. If you want a story-rich game with an excellent atmosphere, you need look no further.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968153075', 'num_games_owned': 1115, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 477, 'last_played': 1561932791}
review:
One of the best adventure game I've played in recent years !
The story is amazing and I loved it a lot
The puzzles are always logical and never feel weird. I never felt the need to use every object on every spot to find a solution.
The voice acting is great. The old school graphics are very good and the cyberpunk/sci-fi vibe is present in each screen

If you're a 'point and click' fan, you need to give this game a try !

author: {'steamid': '76561198026001599', 'num_games_owned': 396, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1644166499}

author: {'steamid': '76561198049940473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 287, 'playtime_forever': 1802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1008, 'last_played': 1701669564}
review:
Very good, but not quite great. Compelling plot and other story elements drive you to keep going, which can exaggerate the comparatively weaker gameplay. Characters and dialogue are excellent but dialogue is on the heavy side, which can affect momentum.

The writing in general is commendable - lots of richness to the moral dimension of it all. Sets up well for a second game.

Edit: replaying years later, nah, definitely great, one of the better point & clicks around. I think "comparatively weaker gameplay" meant more the flow of the game than anything (as I was rushing to finish); there is a scattered approach to storytelling which, together with heavy dialogue and of course need to solve puzzles, can make you feel a bit encumbered at times... But playing a second time really emphasised how there's a lot of excellent stuff here.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961044795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 999, 'last_played': 1475174723}
review: One of the finest Adventure games to come out in recent years.  Engaging voice work, great art, cohesive, well-written and intriguing storyline, most of the puzzles aren't ridiculous and make sense within the gameworld.  If you are a fan of well made Adventure games then this title should be in your library.

review:
The game is great story vise. Just so smart and it's hard to stop playing it until the very end. Puzzles are solid. Neither hard nor easy.

The one downside is that the game age badly visually. It's not a great picture playing the game on 4K monitor. I know it's because how the game was made but I wish these pixel games were made in a way they can be scaled up to a higher resolution with only minor on non loss in quality. I love pixel aesthetic but currently playing these games on a big monitor is problematic.

Otherwise the game is great. Loved this adventure and story. Really hoping for a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994405912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1573867637}
review:
Summary: a fantastic cyberpunk story with some interesting exploration of sci/fi themes, with satisfying puzzle-solving marred slightly by erratic difficulty and taking a while to bring the threads together.  But when they do come together it's really something special.

The Good:  An amazing cyberpunk story told with nuance and subtlety. The setting is both interesting and amazingly creative, it dodges a lot of cyberpunk cliches while creating it's own world, one you will want to see more of.  

Amazing art that is pixel-esque without being part of the pixel game trend that's getting played out.  It feels retro in all the right ways, this game could have come out as part of the 90s cyberpunk boom, it would have felt right at home on the CD-I next to Burn:Cycle or on the Sega next to Snatcher (in fact the art is very snatcher-esque) but it retains some modern conveniences like right and left click for use and view and pop-up interfaces that leave the screen uncluttered and without a frame taking up valuable real estate.  Did I mention the storytelling? the characters are interesting, nuanced and have depth, they feel realistic.  The characters' emotional arcs feel realistic and don't suffer from "because the plot says I can't be mad you tried to kill me, I'm fine now" type issues.  

The puzzles have some real clever ones, which involve the "trance" net mechanic in clever ways, hopping in and out of the net to affect the real world and vice versa.  When using these mechanics the game really, really shines in a way few adventure games do.  They also, for the most part, limit inventory and number of things in a scene to avoid the typical "rub every thing against every other thing" brute force problem solving, or at least make it easier if you do have to resort to that.  Anything that can get you killed resets quickly so you can try again without a lengthy wait. 

The music is great, and very evocative of the mood of the game.  It never rains, either.  Which is a refreshing change from the dripping wet noir worlds of most cyberpunk games.

The Bad:  Some of the puzzles are a real "guide dang it" moment, though they never fall into total moon logic (they don't get Monkey Island on you, but some answers are obscure or require going back and re-using items).  Items are re-used frequently which adds combinatorial complexity (though when you're DONE with an item it does disappear, making it so you won't waste time on items that are no longer needed).

the ugly: nothing I can think of, honestly.

Buy if you like:  Classic adventure games, great cyberpunk stories, detective mysteries, great art.

Price it's worth:  Full price and then some, even for a game that's only about 10h long.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005755324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1043, 'last_played': 1569677374}
review: Overall I liked the game, I'm definitely glad I experienced it. It has a unique storyline, a really interesting mix of characters, good voice-acting, fun and often varied gamplay - where the puzzles weren't too obscure (apart for a couple of times), good music, and it looks nice. I had two major bugs in my playthrough though. They both involved puzzles or investigations that bugged out, where I had done everything correctly but the game did not recognized it. So I could not progress. I know I did everything correctly because I consulted walkthrough guides on each occasion to check if I had missed something, which I had not.  Each bug would have set me back several hours, since I would've had to re-load an old save and start the chapter over. I did use a console cheat instead (ctrl+c) to skip to the next chapter, since I was technically already done with the chapter. Another irritating issue - which I learned the hard way - is that the game does not allow you to move your save files around: if you move them from the install location, to another folder or drive for example, say to do a back-up save, the game won't recognize your save files afterwards. Even with these issues I still feel positive towards the game, so it's still a recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051848349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1564151869}
review: Played 30% of it and voice acting and story telling are top notch. Only con for me is font is a little hard to read, but I guess you can get used reading it in time before the game ends. Atmosphere is spot on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014086298', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1559164845}
review:
Bardzo solidna przygodówka point&click w klasycznej oprawie graficznej. Interesująca i wciągająca fabuła, sensownie zrealizowane zagadki, brak idiotyzmów i frustrujących dziwactw. Nie jest szczególnie trudna i skomplikowana, zdecydowana większość problemów jakie gra przed nami stawia jest całkowicie logiczna i nie są wymagane jakieś nieprawdopodobne zdolności intelektualne, postrzeganie pozazmysłowe albo wyższy stan świadomości. Owszem, znalazłem zagadki które mogą sprawić problemy, ale można je policzyć na palcach jednej ręki.  Klasyczne używanie wszystkiego na wszystkim oraz kultowy pixel hunting w Technobabylon nie występują (pomijając kilka kłopotliwych zagadek o których wyżej wspomniałem). 
Czy coś jeszcze nie przypadło mi do gustu? Fabuła jest interesująca i akcja toczy się dość żywo, ale jest jeden dość drętwy fragment. Ale nie chciałbym tutaj  spojlerować:)
Ostrzegam jednak że w grze jest sporo dialogów, nieźle zrealizowanych i z dubbingiem, ale jeśli ktoś nie lubi czytać to będzie musiał zmusić paluchy do ostrego klikania.

Ogółem: naprawdę warto zagrać, solidne 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198015527269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1053, 'last_played': 1558939343}
review:
整个游戏的设定足够拍一部硬核科幻了

各种小设定也极为有趣：克隆人肉餐馆（有钱人猎奇聚会的场所，品尝培养皿内可食用克隆人肉，可以设定人肉的性别种族，甚至可以食用克隆的自己）、人工生化人工厂、maladism（年轻人间流行的通过trance来使身体和大脑在短期内感染某种旧时代的疾病，例如梅毒、失语症、结核菌等等）、人类对生物基因各种肆意的篡改（新时代的人体炸弹、customerized的迎合各种客户需求的植物、可以在罪犯脑中设置抑制装置

游戏前景中人类对核武器的滥用导致了世界的混乱（亚洲三国互扔核武），剧情时间线中对于生物基因技术的滥用似乎预示着人类社会将会再一次面临灭亡

author: {'steamid': '76561198236799714', 'num_games_owned': 1068, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1495, 'last_played': 1703422269}
review: 如果你不介意像素画面诡异的英文字体和全英文文本语音，那么《Technobabylon》是不可多得的好游戏。库里的point and click解谜类游戏非常多，但《T》是其中能把氛围、音乐、美术、台词、配音结合的完美的典范。

author: {'steamid': '76561198020711630', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1558625220}
review:
Powinienem zacząć od tego, że zazwyczaj nie biorę się za recenzje gier, ale pomyślałem, że jeżeli ta opinia pomoże komuś w dokonaniu wyboru dotyczącego kupna tego tytułu to z całą pewnością napisanie tych kilku słów jest tego warte. Uprzedzam, że nie ukończyłem zbyt wielu gier przygodowych/point&click do tej pory - właściwie jedynie Najdłuższą Podróż, Syberię i kilka innych, pomniejszych tytułów. Z tego właśnie powodu nie mogę uważać się za eksperta, czy też znawcę tego gatunku gier, ale jeżeli jest coś co przyciąga mnie do tego rodzaju rozgrywki to jest to warstwa fabularna i sposób jej opowiedzenia.

Jestem pod niemałym wrażeniem tego jak umiejętnie twórcy zdołali zbudować tu klimat cyberpunku. Śmiem nawet stwierdzić, że zrobili to nie gorzej niż studia produkujące tytuły "triple-A". Jeżeli zastanowisz się chwile nad charakterystycznymi cechami gier czy ogólnie utworów czerpiących z tego podgatunku sci-fi (Albo po prostu je wygooglujesz), to mogę śmiało stwierdzić, że znajdziesz je w Technobabylon.  

VR - ✓
Dystopijna wizja świata - ✓ , 
Korporacje kontrolujące ludzkość - ✓ , 
Ciężkie, niejednoznaczne moralnie wybory - ✓ 
Implanty wzmacniające możliwości ludzkiego ciała -  ✓
(no i cała lista zerżniętą żywcem z Wikipedii)

Wszystkie te elementy budują naprawdę wiarygodną wizje świata przedstawionego. Szczerze? Mogłem się lekko zapędzić z dystopią, bo o ile można napotkać tu pewne jej elementy to klimat nie jest tak mroczny jak przykładowo w Deus Exie czy Blade Runnerze. Sam 'setting' nie jest  tak futurystyczny, jak można by się tego spodziewać - przypomina mi on nieco wspomniane wcześniej The Longest Journey, które świetnie łączyło znany nam świat z jedynie szczątkowymi elementami science-fiction.

Historia opowiadana jest z perspektywy trzech bohaterów, diametralnie różniących się miedzy sobą charakterem. Poznamy tutaj Charlesa Regis, członka organizacji CEL (odpowiednika dzisiejszej policji, czy też innej służby bezpieczeństwa,) który nie jest w stanie poradzić sobie z przytłaczającą go przeszłością i ma duży problem z adaptacją do nowego środowiska. Jest to zdecydowanie niepokorny typ z mocno ukształtowanym kompasem moralnym i awersją do wszechobencnej mody na modyfikacje ciała poprzez elektroniczne wszczepy. 
Towarzyszy mu Max Lao - partnerka z pracy, która w przeciwieństwie do Charlesa nie stroni od używania Trance'u (tj. technologii łączącej elementy VR ze znanym nam internetem) w celu odnajdywania poszlak i rozwiązywania zagadek związanych ze sprawami, którymi wraz z Regisem się zajmują. Młoda pani detektyw jest pewną siebie służbistką, doskonale obeznaną z technologią, jednak szanującą metody postępowania funkcjonariusza. Towarzyszy mu ona na każdym kroku, wspierając go tam gdzie ogranicza go jego 'nieulepszone' ciało. 
Ostatnią osobą z trójki bohaterów jest Latha Sesame - bezrobotna, aspołeczna, uzależniona od Trance'u dziewczyna, spędzająca większość czasu w wirtualnej rzeczywistości, gardząca wszystkim co realne. 
Sama fabuła skupia się na zamachach przeprowadzonych przez seryjnego zabójcę. Jego śladem podążają Regis i Lao. Brzmi jak typowy kryminał... i tym ta gra tak właściwie jest - świetnie wykonaną grą detektywistyczną z ciekawą, wciągającą narracją i kilkoma zaskakującymi plot-twistami. Plus cała garść dobrze napisanych dialogów i przyjemna dla ucha, klimatyczna ścieżka dźwiękowa.

Oczywiście żeby nie było zbyt różowo gra ma kilka problemów, które mogą przeszkadzać w jej odbiorze. Pixelartowa grafika może być urocza i przywoływać klimat lat 90-tych, ale jednocześnie bywa momentami mało czytelna. Zdarzyło mi się utknąć w kilku lokacjach tylko z tego powodu, że nie zauważyłem jakiegoś przedmiotu, a gra niestety nie posiada możliwości podświetlenia wszystkich znajdujących się w danym pomieszczeniu obiektów. Zdarzyło mi się również uciekać kilkukrotnie do solucji (zwłaszcza w ostatnich rozdziałach gry) i robić to co gracze point&click uwielbiają najbardziej - używanie każdego przedmiotu na wszystkim z czym można wejść w interakcje w nadziei, że uruchomi to jakiś skrypt, który popchnie akcje dalej.

Dobra, kończąc te moje wypociny...
Czy pomimo wspomnianych wad warto zaopatrzyć się w ten tytuł?
Jak najbardziej - zwłaszcza przy jego obecnych cenach na oficjalnym sklepie Steam, czy też promocjach na innych stronach (gdzie często można znaleźć go znacznie taniej). Nie będziecie żałować zakupu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118654437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 646, 'last_played': 1558436822}
review: I don't have a lot of experience with point and click games, so a lot of my experience was just getting mad and using a guide. Despite my idiocy I still really enjoyed the game. The story and characters were well written and the work of the voice actors really helped sell the personalities of the characters. I only had a few issues with the game, which was the font of the text that a majority of the game's screens uses, such as the news and email screens in the game. It's incredibly difficult to read what's written without straining my eyes and processing each word. This is more of an individual problem. I played the game for the story, and I was met with an amazing story that was a fantastic experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984440494', 'num_games_owned': 699, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1558302103}
review: This game has made me realize I actually love point & click games. I watched Ghost in the Shell recently and loved it and this is right up the same alley. Great story, great art, great music, great puzzles, creative "hacker" puzzles, and those who have played check that winners dont do drugs achievment hell yes

author: {'steamid': '76561198015812910', 'num_games_owned': 463, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1558169960}
review:
Превосходный представитель своего жанра, практически идеально стилизованный под эпоху времен его расцвета и вдохновленный в первую очередь "Бегущим по лезвию". Вот и всё, что нужно понимать для себя, принимая решение о покупке Technobabylon.


В очередной раз переключаясь со значительно более "простых" игр на квест, поначалу чувствуешь себя полным идиoтoм. Цель: расследовать убийство аристократа по просьбе хозяйки ресторана. Обстоятельство: подозрительное подсобное помещение без освящения. Как быть? Ну... попробую поискать фонарик, а еще лучше элементарно попрошу его у кого-нибудь из персонала. Вроде несложно? Хе-хе, конечно нет, в квестах так быстро не бывает, они живут в мире своих уникальных условностей. Поэтому сначала нужно найти банку, положить в неё приманку (не спрашивайте, где её взять), а потом поймать на это всё светящуюся рыбку из аквариума - получите переносной светильник. Логично?

Нет, порой и вовсе абсурдно, зато интересно! Я для себя это интерпретировал так: в этом далёком киберпанковском будущем высшие слои общества и подумать не могут, что у них где-то внезапно может отключиться свет. Странно, но это как-то даже слишком похоже на реальность.

А что, это может быть правильно, ведь киберпанк уже давно превратился из мрачного предостережения о "high tech, low life" во "всего лишь" кривое отражение настоящего. Кстати об отражениях - в этой игре есть одно зеркало, но оно не работает... нет, не шутка. Причина? Какая разница! Нелепость? Опять нет! Лишь небольшой пример искусственного переусложнения простых вещей и решений. Нам ведь тоже раньше не приходило в голову, что для запуска игр обязательно нужны будут лаунчеры. Более того, люди будут яростно спорить о том, для какого лаунчера им интереснее иконки коллекционировать. А ведь лет десять назад было бы смешно.

Еще пересечений с реальностью? Как насчет идеи "транса": виртуального места сотканного из мыслей, стремлений и мечтаний людей, куда каждый желающий может загрузить своё сознание, выбрать образ себе по душе и отправится в свободное и бескрайнее путешествие. Или наоборот огородиться ото всех цифровыми стенами у себя на выделенном сервере. Вот подумайте сами: серая, грязная, трудная жизнь или выдуманный, но почти осязаемый (может и осязаемый - о передаче тактильных ощущений ничего в игре не говорится) рай. Параноики скажут - матрица! А по мне обычный интернет, разве что самую малость гипертрофированный.

Иногда, впрочем, игра забегает достаточно далеко: как насчет искусственного мяса, товарищи вегетарианцы - отведаете? Нет, а почему? Его  теперь просто выращивают - нет больше вреда экологии, никаких пастбищ, болезней. Ну, подумаешь, иногда оно человеческое, но никто ведь ради него на самом деле не умер. Достаточная ли это с этичной точки зрения причина, чтобы оправдать синтетическое людоедство? Каждый сам для себя решит, но идея любопытная.


Пусть у Technobabylon есть привычные для многих квестов проблемы. Например, она иногда предлагает решать еще не возникшие затруднения. Я вот перебирая предметы у себя в инвентаре и тыкая ими во всё подряд случайно начал взламывать дверь еще до того, как мне дали понять, что она заперта. Плюс некоторые механики работают, что уж тут говорить, криво. Но почти на каждой большой сцене хочется ненадолго остановиться и поподробнее её разобрать. Какие-то небольшие внутриигровые новости, детали окружения, диалоги заставляют, так или иначе, достраивать у себя в голове картину мира. Противоречивого, иногда чужеродного, а иногда наоборот вполне родного. 

Very well written, господа сценаристы.


P.S.: Игру можно проходить с включенными комментариями от разработчиков. Очень рекомендую для второго раза. Тем более, что, помня порядок действий, много времени это не займет.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045736635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 1982, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1982, 'last_played': 1557862008}
review:
恩 雖然故事不錯 還有配音
但是作為一個滑鼠點點點型的遊戲
最大的缺點
就是最基本的"點擊"沒有做好

無法hilight物件就算了
問題是這像素粗到這種程度
東西都快糊成一片了 物件還不做得清楚一點
謎題雖然不難 但是卻因為物件太難被看到 而卡了老半天
我最後只好去看攻略 才知道在一堆屍塊中有一根衣架
即使我有把所有資訊都看過 我知道地板下的機關被卡住才打不開
但是我本來以為是屍塊搞得 在那段卡了快一整晚

第二大缺點
是其中一個成就的設計很爛
那個打虛擬壁球的遊戲
對方球都到身後了還打得回來
相對我方只要求超過手臂就沒救了
把速度調到最低 影響的只有我方的速度
對面的擊球動畫都只剩一條光線了還是照打
不覺得自己是被對手打敗 而是被智障設計打敗的

再來一些小缺點
沒有章節選擇
不是所有已互動過並且不再繼續被需要的物品都會被拿掉或不再能互動
設定中沒有無邊框視窗的選項

劇情其實不算長 有很大一部份在看腳色對話
也就是說解謎要素偏少

優點的部分

除了對話中不行之外
其餘時間基本上可以隨時存檔

對話可以按左鍵快速掠過

劇情還可以 雖然分支不多
除了結局之外 也沒有重大差異
但是在某些對話中有做出差異
像是在處理自爆炸彈客的時候有三種解決方式可以走
我為了解成就把前段到中段玩了兩次
(因為太晚察覺到沒有章節選擇
而我又沒有一直存新檔的習慣)
採取不同的方式 後期遇到夥伴時 她對主角的心理解釋也會不一樣

幽默感也還算可以

老實說
這款的優點 與其說是優點
不如說是一個好的滑鼠點點點遊戲本來就應該要做到的

但缺點卻不是"有比較好 沒有也沒關係"的缺點
而是"根本不應該做成這樣"的缺點
至少兩大缺點要是能改掉 我覺得至少能再多拿個一兩分

以目前來說
給個及格的6/10是我的極限

author: {'steamid': '76561198196521454', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 176, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1557730637}
review: good story & characters. The best Wadjet Eye game I've played so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994397124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 665, 'last_played': 1557601197}
review:
Quality voice acting and writing: check.
Both easy (compared to the average point'n click game) and logic puzzles: check.
Meticulous pixel art graphics: check. Last but not least, the music helps a lot with the atmosphere and fits the game perfectly.

Imho the only minor drawback is the story. It is good, but eventually (around two thirds of the game, maybe ?) became too complicated / obscure for me. I think it is meant to be open to interpretations, however it eventually got me confused more than anything.
Not much more to say. I have had this game sitting in my library for a while and did not expect it to be so nicely written and fun when I started it, so much that I am thinking about doing a second playthrough later, maybe that will help me fill in the gaps.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054438418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 281, 'playtime_forever': 993, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 993, 'last_played': 1557441203}
review:
+Good writing: captivating story and plot twists, memorable characters, interesting and witty dialogues.
+Stellar work by Voice Actors, my oh my!

=Puzzles can be very complex at times. Luckily, there are solutions on the internet.

-Pixel hunting can be tedious, oh my.
-Both endings felt as a slight let down. Barely good enough to not ruin the whole thing.

All in all, it's a very good adventure, my oh my!

author: {'steamid': '76561198814120763', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1075, 'last_played': 1556163693}
review:
Worth the AUD $21.00!
Very good story line, with room for story-line play and plot change.
Great depth to the covers and plot. Could do with more endings though.
Nice Sci-fi drama with injections of dark and dry humour.
Unfortunately it will leave you wanting more.
If they do not do a sequel, then it is a huge injustice!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038207320', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 627, 'last_played': 1555701976}
review: Good work, devs! Enjoyed it all along.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012363945', 'num_games_owned': 2121, 'num_reviews': 409, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1555181070}
review:
This one is definitely one of the top tier adventure games i have played in a long while. 

A quick Pro/Con list: 
+ Good story. Deus ex style conspiracy in a futuristic environment.  Never gets old if properly done. This one has a protagonis cadre that are in no way 'superhuman' yet they seem to get involved into something bigger than life. 
+ Linear enough/Limited areas to explore. I dislike games where you carry around a ton of items and the game screens are just filled up to the hilt with stuff to interact with.  Because of this i was able to play this one through mostly without looking up too much stuff.  Difficulty is easy to medium with a few really tough ones put in that i would not have guessed myself. 
+ Lines are spoken so even though game looks old it has proper voice acting

Con
- Graphics might not be to some people's liking
- Some people may not like that quite often the play area is just a room or two your are trying to escape from.  
- Ton of missable achievements. Early game there is even a way to prevent yourself from advancing in the game if you choose wrong dialogue. 
- Getting 100% on achievements is a real chore. Didn't bother with that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011810582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1555153892}
review: What can I say: I love Wadjet Eye Games. The story is always good, as are the riddles and the gameplay. If you love their games, you are gonna love this. I really liked the dark twists and am looking forward to the sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063533861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1554230805}
review: On par with Primordia. Some mechanics take a while to get used to (wetware), but once you figure it out this game is awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001196392', 'num_games_owned': 275, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 942, 'last_played': 1590284099}
review: What a beautiful game and story. A joy from start to end and an interesting vision of the future. Worth your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040253538', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 832, 'last_played': 1632244922}
review: It's a really great point and click experience, and I love how there are multiple ways through the puzzles. The voice acting adds to the experience instead of detracting from it, the art is amazing, and the music fits and adds to the ambiance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009135681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1558140145}
review:
A detective might enjoy this game. There are many apparent possibilities to solve problems, but only one is correct.

A creative thinker might find this game very frustrating. Solutions that would have worked in real life don't work in this game because they were not programmed to do so. You're not Macgyver: the vast majority of objects in the room are useless to you. You're not looking for creative solutions, but the one obscure solution the author had in mind.

The story has meat to it; it's too bad the shell is so hard and tools to open it are so blunt and scarce.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995244940', 'num_games_owned': 1095, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1064, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 782, 'last_played': 1679895245}
review: Technobabylon is a solid adventure and great science fiction that does an excellent job of imagining different subcultures that technology makes possible. You might need to refer to a hint file for the trickier puzzles every now and then, but it's worth it to see how the story wraps up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042585260', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1466672079}
review: I absolutely loved playing Technobaylon! The interface was easy to learn and the puzzles were challenging and enjoyable. I really thought the wordbuilding and character development was both complex, and was fluidly revealed through character interactions, which combined to make for a very compelling and thought-provoking sci-fi setting!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053744908', 'num_games_owned': 1006, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 880, 'last_played': 1551540747}
review:
[quote]As an enjoyable cyberpunk point and click adventure with satisfying puzzles and an interesting and original narrative, Technobabylon succeeds. Offering around 8-10 hours of gameplay spread across 10 chapters, and with three different characters to control, it weaves an interesting story of murder and deceit. Its world feels a little flat however, and once or twice objectives are not immediately clear, but as a complete package Technobabylon is a fun ride for those who enjoy dystopian tech-noir adventures.[/quote]

There’s a distance to travel between idea and finished creation, and the transformative process that bridges those points is crucial in achieving the designer’s goal. Can the greater idea be broken down into its component parts and reproduced into exactly what was originally intended? Consider a simple sentence that can be understood in two different ways (It was the least I could do to give a small example). The writer immediately knows how to interpret that sentence, but if additional texture is added by stressing a word with italicisation, the meaning is clearer to all. In a game where detail and atmosphere is critical, does Technobablyon match its ideal form?

Technobabylon is a point and click adventure in the cyberpunk mould, occupying a dystopian future in which an electronic overseer known as Central shepherds the populace of the city of Newton. With the help of a human police force (CEL) and technology that allows direct interface with machines in a virtual environment (the Trance), life should be relatively easy for the people. Unfortunately for Central, a spate of killings by a Mindjacker (a murderer who literally steals a person’s mind killing the in the process), a rise in the number of biological terrorists (humans genetically engineered to explode) and a potential CEL agent gone rogue, indicate that there’s a bigger picture to be revealed. Plot wise it’s an interesting mix and certainly encourages the player’s curiosity.

The game plays out through the viewpoint of multiple characters – Latha Sesame, a young woman seemingly addicted to the virtual world of Trance space, Dr Charles Regis, an experienced CEL agent with a background in genetic engineering and an extreme dislike of technology and Dr Max Lao, a young newly promoted CEL case officer with no such prejudices. Control is handed to each as the story dictates, with only a very brief section that permits hotswapping between the three, and this division roughly splits the plot into two converging tales. The characters are generally likeable, with Max far and away the most endearing of the trio, but with only snippets of background information on Max and Latha, and with Regis seemingly disconnected from his past, it becomes very hard to care for any of them. This drains the story of dramatic tension, which is a shame given the course of the narrative...it’s hard to care for these people we barely know.

There are echoes of Blade Runner in the mix of shabby run down environs and gleaming high tech labs, with a soundtrack that delivers on the premise of each location, be it industrial ambience or electronic bounce. The pixel art is also neat and expressive, although on occasion certain hotspots don’t seem as obvious as they could be. The music also serves as a suitable complement to the game, but sadly is not memorable beyond those confines. 

However in terms of world building, we see very little of the Technobabylon’s city, and only a tiny cluster of people; Newton feels unpopulated with the omnipresent Central markedly absent unless called upon. The assumption would be that the world is supposed to feel dreary and oppressive, dystopian in a cyberpunk way, but it doesn’t because we never really see enough of it working outside of the confines of the story. As a result the environment never feels alive, never captures the essence of the tech-noir it strives to emulate.

The voice acting is admirable though, each voice different and effectively reflecting the personality of the character speaking. Once again Max’s VA is a highlight, but across the board it’s solid with generally believable scripting and despite not being overtly humorous, at times there’s a dark satire bubbling under the surface. It’s also a nice touch that whenever a character is talking a lovely pixel art style portrait is displayed, giving a more detailed representation of that person, complete with a range of different expressions. There’s also an excellent developer commentary feature which provides a lot of interesting insights about the development process, although there are some small spoilers in those tracks so beware listening to these before a full first run.

But a game like this lives or dies on the strength of its puzzles, and thankfully on the whole they’re good, bordering on excellent. Technobabylon boasts a standard inventory system allowing item combination and examination, and generally most of the obstacles that the player will face on their journey are logical and frustration free. There are a couple of irritants however, where important items are not readily visible against the background or when the player is assumed to have knowledge that the characters who inhabit the world may have (the rules of Wetware hacking still seem muddled to me…). This is worse towards the end of the game, but whilst it’s unsatisfying that there are a couple of choke points, as a complete work the point and click logic is generally good. Less satisfying are the more action oriented tasks, such as evading a guard by hiding behind moving crates or a version of future pong (although admittedly the game intends for you to cheat).  Perhaps the most egregious sin that Technobabylon commits is occasionally abandoning a player to stumble upon the next story beat, which once or twice left me wandering around in circles with no idea what I was supposed to be doing next.

So, let’s get back to where we started. Technobabylon is an enjoyable experience and certainly a fun point and click adventure. It’s got an interesting story, good puzzles and looks and sounds nice. But frustratingly it lacks a certain something, some atmospheric punch that would bring the world to life and elevate the game to something really special. It’s apparent what the developer was aiming for, and it’s almost tangible given any past exposure to dystopian scifi or cyberpunk adventures, but Technobabylon just falls short of providing a glimpse of the living, breathing world that something like Primorida succeeds in describing. Next time maybe use more italics…

author: {'steamid': '76561198048648906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1551235100}

author: {'steamid': '76561198016755811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 871, 'last_played': 1551197117}

been playing adventure games since the golden age and this feels like one of those classics,

keep em coming wadjeteye

author: {'steamid': '76561197975581866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 676, 'last_played': 1539301837}
review:
Pros:
-A great adventure game from a developer with a solid track record
-Enjoyable sci-fi story
-Wonderful art
-Likable characters

Cons:
-No glaring flaws

author: {'steamid': '76561197995129622', 'num_games_owned': 3102, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1550963715}
review:
Fun point and click game. Some absurd choices to make, but once you get the hang of it, not too hard.

Story has a lot of loopholes and seems something forgettable. But it had some nice enough chapters that made playing the game worth it. 

6.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198106512564', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1550855928}
review:
Wow. I have not had a point and click experience like that since playing some LucasArts and Sierra games back in the day.  All I can say is just. buy. it!!!!

 (well, actually I can say alot more...)

Pros
--------------------------------------------------------------
-Fantastic Sci-fi story.  This is where the game shines most of all and is probably the most crucial piece of any good game/movie/tv-show or any kind of media.  Probably one of the most immersive Cyberpunk adventures I've ever played (think Beneath a Steel Sky meets Neuromancer) I always like a game that introduces sci-fi concepts that are original and creative and there are several in this game
-Beautiful graphics.  Wadjet Eye Games most visually engrossing game that I've played so far.  
-Top quality voice acting.  Combined with well written characters, it adds up to some really enjoyable roleplaying 
-Puzzles are a near perfect balance between challenging and non-interrupted by absurd esoteric problem solving.  A very difficult thing to achieve in any point-and-click adventure, the puzzles in this game have been described by another review as "organic" and I definitely agree
-Atmospheric soundtrack
-Forgiving of screw-ups with auto rewind feature and autosaves
-Stable, had zero issues or crashes (unlike other Adventure Game Studios games I've played in the past
-Good value in terms of dollars per hour played.  Came in at over 9 hours for me and I picked it up on sale.  But even if I didn't its still a good value at full price not even considering the fact its an amazing game.


Cons
--------------------------------------------------------------
-I ended up saving way more than I typically do and it ran out of space at approximately 50 saves.  Not really a huge complaint as its just my playing style....buttttt it is the 21st century shouldn't we have unlimited saves by now? I attribute this to an AGS programming limitation (but maybe I'm slightly biased against AGS....)
-Puzzles were a NEAR perfect balance....two or three puzzles I absolutely never would have figured out with out a check in to a walkthrough.  Again a minor complaint as it is typical to have a few hang ups like this in any adventure game but overall I stick to my Pros comment,  holistically its practically a perfect balance.
-One or two visual bugs (pipe in den, game play during pong game in VR)

This is probably one of my favorite point and clicks I've ever played and I've played ALOT of adventure games.  This will be one of my go to examples when I talk about the "point and click Renaissance" as I like to call these modern takes on the  classic adventure game style of the 90's.  A must purchase for any point and click aficionado! Go buy it now!!!;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198000564950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 585, 'last_played': 1550530766}
review:
A fun and one-day-play length adventure game.  Many of the puzzles have multiple solutions and there is only one puzzle that comes to mind that's works on "adventure game logic".  The voice acting is suprisingly nice.  The art is good and with the exception of some CG effects the pixel art is real pixel art and not just drawn stuff with the resolution lowered.  The story isn't anything too special but it was interesting enough that you wanted to keep going.  

I definitely recommend it on sale, but for a one day game you might not want to pay the full price of 15 dollars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003807413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1844, 'last_played': 1550720250}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995677279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 894, 'last_played': 1550594155}
review:
Fantastic Point and Click Game, set in a Bladerunner'esque World!

Pro's:
+ well written Story, told from multiple perspectives
+ beatiful cyberpunk'ish artstyle
+ interesting and unique characters
+ very good Voice-Acting and Music
+ puzzles are clever and not too complicated
+ roughly 14 Hours of immersive Gameplay

Con's:
- only english language and subtitles
- sometimes problems with dissapearing text/speech-boxes (restarting the game fixes this)
- weird screen-resoluiton-choice, looks like the game was made for 16:10 Aspect-Ratios
- max. 51 Savegame-Slots (which is honestly more than enough, no need to save that often)
- the Setup-Window (outside the game) has no "Ok" or "Save Settings" Button. You need to press enter to save your settings, which is a bit irritating.

Had a blast playing this Game and are very interested in the upcoming successor (which will be a 3D Game).

author: {'steamid': '76561198095204875', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 936, 'last_played': 1550473991}
review:
よくあるタイプのポイントクリック型のアドベンチャーゲームです。
この昔ながらのスタイルが好きな人は楽しめると思います。
章仕立てで、その都度、操作するキャラが変わります。
場面によってはキャラを切り替えなが進むところもあります。
ストーリーは、中々よく出来ていて、
主人公の過去にも何かありそうな感じを出しており、次が気になります。
近未来で、人工知能による管理に身を任せている管理社会での話で、
80－90年代のSFのテーマっぽい感じの世界観です。
大きな欠点もないけど、このゲームならではの売りもないですね。
一応、解決方法が複数あるものがあり、実績に関わったりしてきます。
実際に80点くらいの出来で、無難にまとまっています。
世界観とアドベンチャーが好きな人なら買いですね。
英語は、やや理系的な単語とスラングがありましたが、
基本的な話を追うのには問題なかったです。

クリアまで12時間くらい掛かりましたが、
初見でも早ければ8時間でも行けると思います。
あまりに理不尽な謎はなかったですが、
どうしてもアイテムとポイントの総当たりになってしましました。
普通からやや難の難易度で、よく考える必要はあります。
雰囲気も出ていて、ドット絵が好きな方にもオススメです。
しかし、基の解像度が低いのは残念ですね、
FHDでプレイしましたが最初はドットの粗さが気になりました。
しばらくすると慣れましたが、もう少し解像度を上げて欲しいです。
あとはドット絵なので、グロな場面はないですが、
倫理的に厳しい場面はありました。未来感を出したかったのだと思いますが、
自分はあまり気持ち良くはなかったです。

実績も一度のプレイで6割くらい取れましたが、
全部取るには、2-3週必要ですね。
セーブしていれば章ごとのやり直しで取れるものもあります。
実績名から取り方もわかり易いのが多いですが、
全部取るのは少し面倒なタイプです。
基本的に一本道ですが、解決方法が複数あったりして、
細かな分岐はいくつもあります。
エンディングも選択肢を変えたところ少しだけ変化しました。
コメンタリー付きでプレイできるのは、ドラマや映画ではみたことありましたが、
ゲームでは珍しいですね。
SFとアドベンチャーが好きな人はbundleでまとめて買うのが良いと思います。

author: {'steamid': '76561198056750415', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1117, 'last_played': 1550093733}
review:
Brilliant game. It feels more like a crime-novel or movie than a 90s-style point-and-click-adventure:
Well-written characters, who come really alive thanks to some excellent voice-acting, a rich and complex story, with some quite unexpected twists, atmospheric and convincing world-building - and a pitch-perfect balance between dark, dystopian themes and light-hearted silliness at just the right moments. Definitely recommended :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197986406741', 'num_games_owned': 3234, 'num_reviews': 913, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1549571902}
review:
I mean.. the voice overs are pretty cool but..

- it cannot detect a valid resolution like 1440p. There are no graphical options in the menus..
- there is a "speed" setting that accelerates both mouse and character speed on screen.. wtf..
- there is ALWAYS a very weird acceleration on the mouse pointer..
- the fonts used in the game are very bad for reading..

Really avoid this unless you are mentally prepared for the above.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967307161', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 839, 'last_played': 1546226935}
review:
If you're curious about this game, try out the free demo, it should give you a good impression (If you're put off by the door and food dispenser AIs in the first section, don't worry, they don't or barely show up in the rest of the game. I found them kind of funny but I can imagine some people not liking them).

Good story with a few dips, puzzles can be a bit frustrating every now and then but are not impossible to figure out on your own. 

Definitely worth buying under 10 euro's and even full price if you like this kind of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074772798', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 496, 'last_played': 1546206747}
review: Los de Wadjet Eye demuestran que saben hacer un buen point n click. Este, a diferencia de Resonance, es mucho menos simplón a nivel político, y eso era lo que más suspicacia me daba al jugarlo, ya que suele ser por donde Wadjet Eye pierde gracia.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989807190', 'num_games_owned': 2276, 'num_reviews': 599, 'playtime_forever': 408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1490555387}
review:
Technobabylon is a pretty curious title. On one hand, it feels like a slight revisit of the classic Beneath a Steel Sky, albeit in a different version of the future. This future is much more bio-technological, with cloning, DNA experimentation and “wetware” nanomachines being an everyday norm. Which opens up the chance to talk about some very interesting topics, a lot of which game handles very well. Some… well, some feel forced, inconsistent or put in just for shock value.

Which is, really, the only big downside of the game. It’s story is solid, if predictable after the introductory chapters. The characters are interesting, if sometimes saying completely out of the blue lines. And puzzles are mostly well done and feel “natural” to the world they are in. But from time to time there’s this strange feeling of pulp, really tonally inconsistent moments and pretty banal twists. For a lot of good storytelling and charismatic world building there are always moments of really bad writing. Which doesn’t let the game down in the end, I do think it’s worth a check, but definitely sours the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007502435', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 1034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1034, 'last_played': 1546138418}
review:
[h1]Solid all the way through[/h1]

The art is nice enough, the setting, the atmosphere, all fine and dandy.
Gameplay wise, the puzzles are easy enough to not get stuck.

There are a fair number of cool characters and interesting puzzles along the way, which make this game very fun at times.

But of course, like so many adventure games, the main attraction is the story.
It's ok. Not terribly generic, but not terribly original either. Not super confusing, (which is a BIG problem for many games, especially sci-fi games) but also very predictable. You can pretty much guess all the plot twists and endings about halfway through.
Thankfully, the game doesn't take it's plot twists too seriously, so it doesn't make you cringe or anything, it's just pretty lame. The endings are a bit lacking as well. They're ok, but still some things don't seem to make sense, and the endings are basically cliffhangers. So you don't get a lot of closure.

There are 1 or 2 moral choices in the game, but none of them affect the ending. I like that personally. The endings themselves are also just a choice between switch A or B in the final level, like in deus ex:HR for example.

[b]IN CONCLUSION[/b], you have a game with an ok story, ok atmosphere, great gameplay as far as point and clicks go, and some decent humor along the way. A game in which you don't have to worry about anything you do, because it is very linear, and you simply decide what ending you want at the end. Overall it's a very smooth and pleasant experience, with no real amazement, but no disappointments either.

The game also offers a commentary mode.


TL:DR it's a good game, worth the price.


ONE LAST THING,
this game has some problems with the mouse acceleration, causing the mouse pointer to move too fast. To fix this,

1) Create a file called "allegro.cfg" in the games folder (create a .txt file and change it to .cfg)
2) add the following lines within the file:
[mouse]
mouse_accel_factor=0

thanks to Space Cowboy from the community for the fix.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018926688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 1184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1184, 'last_played': 1546046029}
review:
Un très bon point & click. 
Les enigmes sont toutes très simple, un peu trop peut-être. Mais l'histoire est vraiment très intéressante. 
Dans un univers cyber-punk, plusieurs groupuscules tentent de prendre le contrôle de l'IA omnipotente qui dirige la ville de Newton. Vous contrôlez trois personnages différents au cours de cette aventure, qui mélange réalité réelle et réalité virtuelle.
La trame principale est la même, mais les manières de résoudre les puzzles ne sont pas unique. Et cela influencera un peu la fin de l'histoire.

On peut noter la possibilité d'écouter les équipes de développemement, tout au long du jeu. Cela rajoute une bonne durée de vie, et c'est plutôt intéressant. Savoir pourquoi telle musique a été composée, pourquoi ce tableau a été designé de cette façon, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044127578', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 930, 'last_played': 1488558171}

author: {'steamid': '76561198108456087', 'num_games_owned': 597, 'num_reviews': 395, 'playtime_forever': 1709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1709, 'last_played': 1543874134}
review:
Все слишком камерно и поэтому не воспринимается всерьез до конца. Хотя "Gemini Rue" эта камерность не мешала. Атмосфера как-то не очень удалась. Концовки какие-то сумбурные и противоречивые.
