author: {'steamid': '76561198051204305', 'num_games_owned': 630, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'last_played': 1484754186}
review:
Le avventure targate Wadjet sono ormai tra i migliori prodotti del genere e Technobabylon non fa eccezione.
Ambientazione cyberpunk splendida, storia e tematiche ottimamente scritte e gestite, per nulla banali (forse giusto il twist finale è abbastanza prevedibile); lato gameplay, i puzzle sono ben congeniati, perfettamente integrati, tutti logici e mai inutilmente complessi.

Un Must per gli amanti del genere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126241299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 662, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 662, 'last_played': 1484623046}
review: There is great sci-fi writing here, and the game themes are among the most interesting questions about our future.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970369196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 519, 'last_played': 1484602716}
review:
Solid old-school adventure game. The first point&click adventure I've played I think where many puzzles have more than one solution. Storywise it's reminiscent of classic cyberpunk - Neuromancer et al. This is what I wanted Beneath A Steel Sky to be back in the days.

One minor recurring bug - sometimes pop up windows (like when you examine something) instantly closes again. Saving, quitting and reloading fixed it though.

All in all, highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198212769343', 'num_games_owned': 466, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 1169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1169, 'last_played': 1484427296}
review:
A point and click adventure.

These kinds of games rely on the story. The game takes place in the future, where the city of Newton is controlled by a central computer and the internet is now multiple virtual worlds that you can access with your brain. Most of the time you control two characters, Latha, an internet adict, and Charlie, a police detective. That's pretty much the introduction to avoid spoilers.

I found the story interesting but as always it is often hard to figure out what to do. However if you're not fond of searching or figuring out random puzzles like myself, you can just check a walkthrough on the internet. Still, the puzzles aren't hard to figure out and I did not get stuck that much.

Recommended if you like point and click adventures.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981811422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 782, 'last_played': 1484147686}
review: Very well designed, deep story. Reminded me of the old point and click RPG from Sierra, but with a twist.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970534934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 613, 'last_played': 1484132396}
review:
Fantastic game, well written, cool music, cool world. I never finished Beneath a Steel Sky, but I completed Technobabylon. I'm telling all my friends about it.

There are 10 chapters in total, which I completed in about 10 hours over as many evenings, and it felt very well paced. The experience was much like reading a novel, but one which I was a part of. A prime example of computer game as literary form. 

Reviewer: Male, 38, Computer Scientist, grew up watching Blade Runner and Aliens.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116378582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2328, 'last_played': 1484085968}
review:
The visuals, the characters, thematic context and music.. it all comes together nicely.

There are only 2 difficult puzzles (and only 1 of them, would I consider truly "unfair" - the double conduit one near the end). The rest are not only quite logical in context, but makes you feel intelligent for considering such options, even if the game is actively dropping hints about it.

The ending has (I think) 2 possible outcomes, not sure how much the dialogue changes, though. I went through the "good" one.

Overall, once of the best Cyberpunk games out there.  
Genuinely enjoyed it. Hope there is a sequel soon.

Extra: Enable the Director's comments. They all come up as very likeable, and their interjections where pretty insightful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027159275', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 927, 'last_played': 1483949680}
review:
I enjoyed playing through this cyberpunk point & click adventure game. I liked the  story and the setting and the puzzles for the most part made sense. I only had to look for help on how to proceed at a couple points.  I really like that at several parts in the game you have more than one option for solving the problem at hand. It took me about 12 hours to beat the game and the extra time logged has been  me exploring the other story options. 
The AI splitter tool they have I found  to be entertaining. I liked how they simulated the AI acting as a different personality than its own by having the voice actor imitate the other character's voice. 
My big complaint might be because I have dual monitors, but a common problem I had would be the game not constraining mouse movement to the primary monitor, so it would click on the desktop of the second monitor and minimize the game  until I click back on the game in the taskbar to bring it back up (until it would happen  again later). 
Overall though, I found this game to be entertaining and recommend it to anyone into cyberpunk & adventure games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971119411', 'num_games_owned': 695, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1483944615}
review:
One of the best Point & Click adventure games I've ever played. The puzzles are challenging, but not impossibly hard. It's a great story with some twists and turns, and also filled with some memorable characters.
I can't recommend it enough!

author: {'steamid': '76561198108529605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1081, 'last_played': 1483847128}
review:
Definitivamente, uno de los mejores guiones que he encontrado en juegos indies desde hace mucho tiempo. Me encantó esa mezcla de historia de ciencia ficción basada en la idea de una red de interconexión de realidad virtual en una ciudad controlada por una IA, que en combinación con la estética 8-bit y el entorno de metrópoli llena de rascacielos con luces de neón, le da un aire retrofuturista que me hace sentir nostálgico, como si estuviese leyendo una novela de William Gibson.

Mi única crítica, es la dificultad de algunos de los puzzles: aunque en su mayoría son bastante sencillos, en al menos 3 ocasiones tuve que buscar walkthoughs para poder llegar a la solución, y en cada uno de esos casos sentí que los pasos que había que seguir eran demasiado rebuscados, llenos de condiciones excesivamente específicas y no muy coherentes que hay que cumplir para completar la acción.

Fuera de eso: disfruté todas y cada una de las casi 20 horas de juego que me eché.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027954343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1483932677}
review:
[b]tl;dr[/b]
Technobabylon has an amazing narrative setting and will impress you with its very down-to-earth take on cyberpunk philosophy, technology and social themes. On the other hand, the game itself is only average for a point-and-click adventure. Fortunately, it lets its narrative parts shine through it.

[b]Full version[/b]

Being a cyberpunk fan, I bought Technobabylon hoping to experience a good cyberpunk story, and in that regard, I was more than satisfied. The game's strongest point is definitely how clever, well thought out and realistic its narrative setting is. Throughout my experience, I kept thinking that if I was transported 50-100 years in the future, I'd be hearing about exactly these issues on the news. I particularly enjoyed how social issues and ethical decisions in technology are at the forefront of this story, in a way that is completely believable. This game is definitely a love letter to the cyberpunk genre by someone who has reflected a lot on it, and that person has my warm thanks for it.

As a game however, Technobabylon has its share of drawbacks.

In terms of atmosphere, the art is not so appealing, although the portraits during conversations are really nice. The overall art direction is functional and supports the theme. Voice acting is ok. Music fits, but is not inspiring.

The story is really great, but would be more appropriate for a book/movie. I find it loses some of its luster here because it's really convoluted. It showcases multiple protagonists, antagonists and secondary characters, goes back and forth between past and present, and jumps from one character's perspective to the next all the time. This could have worked very well if it had been delivered more gradually, but because this story only coalesces at the very end, you spend 80% of the game quite confused by it.

And this is made especially a problem because of the difficulty of the puzzles. They are not difficult in the sense of requiring great intellectual feats to solve, but rather in the sense of "how on earth did they want me to guess I should do this sequence of things to reach this scene's not-even clearly stated objective". Granted, I consider myself a casual in terms of point-and-click adventures, in the sense that I want the story to unfold with a good flow and the puzzles to be easy and intuitive. This is how I generally felt with Gemini Rue for example, another cyberpunk point-and-click published by Wadjet Eye. But here, in every single scene, I found myself stuck, not knowing how to advance to the next part. I had to make generous use of a walkthrough to move through the game. After reading the solutions, I often found that there was no way I could have thought about doing that, and so it reduced greatly my enjoyment and desire to even try in the next scene. The other downside of this difficulty was that all of my brainpower went into trying to solve puzzles, which made it much harder to focus on the strengths of this game: it's atmosphere and story.

To conclude, if you are a fan of cyberpunk stories, you should definitely try this game; you'll be greatly rewarded narratively for it, especially if you don't mind using a walkthrough. If you don't care for cyberpunk and are primarily a point-and-click adventure fan, there are definitely better games out there for you. I guess hardcore point-and-click fans who love difficult puzzles might enjoy it.

Thanks, Technocrat Games, for a great story!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048854247', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1012, 'last_played': 1483915828}
review:
Ez a játék azért keltette fel a figyelmemet, mert egyrészt klasszikus point and click kalandjáték, másrészt, mert sci-fi, harmadrészt pedig, mert a kiadó a Wadjet Eye Games, akiknek a Blackwell kvadrológiát köszönhetjük, ami egyik kedvenc kalandjáték-sorozatom. A játék 2087-ben játszódik. 3 karaktert irányítunk. Egy CEL (rendőrségszerű) szervezetnek dolgozó fickót, a társát, valamint egy csajt, aki munkanélküli és trancefüggő (virtuális valóságszerű valami, ami egyben olyasmi is, mint az internet). A játék igazából minden ponton erős. A megalkotott világ érdekes és részletes és nagyon kidolgozott mind technológia, mind a társadalom szempontjából. A karakterek érdekesek, sztori jó (néha vicces, sokszor komor) néhány meglepő fordulattal, hangulat jön ezerrel. Játékmenetben hozza a hagyományos point and click receptet, szal dumák, tárgyak összeszedése, használata, kombinálása. Van pár nehezebb rész, de mindenhol sikerült magamtól rájönnöm a megoldásra. Ami a játékmenetben érdekes, h sokszor a virtuális valóságban kell valamit megtennünk, előtte rákapcsolódva különböző gépekre, tárgyakra, amiket MI vezérel. Ami még tetszett, h vannak benne döntési lehetőségek és több befejezés közül választhatunk. Grafikára nem sokat lehet mondani, oldschool pixelgrafika, jól megrajzolt hátterekkel, karakterportrékkal és meglepően jó animációkkal.

Szóval összességében nagyon bejött. Nem nagyon tudok kifogásolnivalót találni rajta.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991457449', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2859, 'last_played': 1483919113}
review: If you like the style of old fashioned point-and-click adventures, definetively get this one! It has a really immersive, rich story. The puzzles are not to easy - it's not just a story you click through as is the case with a lot of too easy adventures these days. They did a great job!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970965461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 724, 'last_played': 1483527391}
review:
[h1]A Great Sci-fi novel[/h1]

Technobabylon is one of these games that I bought on sales and let in my library for weeks, asking myself if I will ever play it. I finally did, and it was one of my greatest experience in point-and-click.

The one thing that makes this game GREAT is the vision of future it embraces. It isn't yet another utopia/distopia, it's a blending of plausible, mature extrapolations of nowaday's tendencies in technology and social life. You will find many things to think about, dream or fear about, in this game's vision of our future. News and secondary characters strongly participate in creating this wonderful atmosphere. 

This game acted on me like a wonderful book, when you appropriate the author's universe and make it your own, thinking about it for the rest of the day, talking about it with collegues, friends and family. If you like science fiction, you'll LOVE Technobabylon.

One more thing: beyond the incredible story and atmosphere, the point'n'click mechanics are great, and the puzzles are always logical. You don't find solutions by trying - like - the potato on the ceiling, you know what I mean, point'n'click players! And it is very well balanced. Go play it now, the developers deserve it :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197992128537', 'num_games_owned': 183, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1483530884}
review: The writing and vocal work are pretty good, all things considered. It was an interesting take on the cyberpunk setting. The gameplay is pretty standard point-and-click adventure, though, and it's fairly short. Worth a playthough if you can get it on a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970539509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1007, 'last_played': 1483290638}
review:
Excellent production values and story in this, cyber punk, sci-fi, point and click game. They did a good job of defining a world beyond just that of the story. The art direction is top notch. I really appreciated the throwback aesthetic. The voice acting is very well done too.

In terms of game play, this is pretty standard stuff.  I was pleasantly surprised that for large portions of the game I was able to figure out myself what needed to be done ... but like all point and click games, it suffers from obtuse puzzles that, at least for me, don't seem solvable without a walkthru. However, I only had to resort to those less than a handful of times.

I wouldn't mind seeing more of these characters in another adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110548913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 851, 'last_played': 1483261921}
review:
Absolutely loved it.

I'm someone who doesn't do well with games that require reaction times, coordination, or patience, so basically I don't really expect any games to be totally fulfilling to me. But shit, I guess I didn't see Technobabylon coming. I'll admit I had to refer to walkthroughs for a lot of the second half of this game, but honestly I wish I hadn't because all the puzzles are actually completely achievable if you think about them long enough (again, patience isn't a strong point for me).
All of the gameplay aspects totally hooked me right off the bat - I started this game right on the cusp of Christmas and the New Year, and I spent a lot of moments that probably should have been spent celebrating playing this game instead. I have no regrets. Awesome start to 2017. This game gave me clear skin, cured my depression and inspired me to achieve more. 

Anyway, that's before we even get to the characters. Honestly the characters in any game always make or break it for me, and in this case they totally made it. Charlie is incredibly sweet and easy to relate with, Latha is simulateously adorable and the coolest protagonist ever, and Lao is a fucking boss. This is the point where my stupidly in-depth review that noone is gonna read gets more spoilery and much more contentious, but it had a massive impact on my experience so I'm just gonna have to go there...
A large problem people seem to perceive with minority characters is this idea that they only exist for the creator to show off how 'socially aware' they are. I mostly see people who aren't part of the minority groups at hand talking about this, and honestly, the only way you could make any kind of insightful critisism of a minority character is if you ARE that minority. I know we all like to think that we can think through every puzzle in the world whether it's race or gender, but I've had to learn over a long time that it's definitely not as simple as just thinking objectively. 
As a white person in New Zealand, I do all I can to advocate against racial violence, because I'm never going to experience having my rights as a white person being subtly exploited on a grand scale, via laws implemented by other white people back when you could sell human beings. 
Any opinion I have on Lao's writing or characterisation as an East Asian character are never going to be as good or in depth as those of any given Asian person, because I just don't know what it's like to be Asian. Even just under the general title of 'transgender' I'm sure you can hear a million different feelings and interpretations on Max Lao, from people with massively different experiences and perspectives. With this in mind, that's why I roll my eyes when I see people who aren't transgender talking smack about the presence of trans characters in media. If you want to help keep damaging or stupid characterisations out of games, any of the people writing those reviews will probably give you lots of stuff to look out for (see: the trope of being outed against one's will).

WITH THAT BEING SAID. I loved Lao. I love how her backstory is revealed, I love how she is the one who CHOOSES to reveal it to Charlie on her own terms, and I love how for once I got to play a game that doesn't decide to have a protagonist who can probe the trans character with invasive or demeaning questions *cough Dragon Age Inquisition cough*. Obviously those interactions have their place, but Jesus, we get it already. There are more interesting conversations to see about a character being trans than just that. The world will not suffer for having one less game where a character gets interrogated on why she chose to be a girl. 
As anyone who's still reading has probably guessed at this point, I'm transgender myself, but I don't know what it's like to be raised as a boy and then try and carve my way from there. It's a hugely different experience and there is a lot to Lao that I honestly can't really say whether it's done right or not, I just wouldn't know. 
And I mean even aside from all this, it's really a pretty miniscule plot point, so I don't know if I missed anything but there's not really a whole lot of room FOR a problem. This makes it seem like it was a humungous part of the game and it really wasn't, as with a lot of other minority appearances, re: the interracial gay couples I've seen someone get massively upset over. As well as a robot that they claimed to be gay, with no supporting evidence. But that's none of my business. 
There's not really much I can say about the other minority appearances in this game, other than 'they were there'. It would've been a really cool opportunity to have a disabled character that wasn't a villain, but again, I don't really know much more about that - maybe we'll see that in the next installment from these guys! 

I LOVE this game. It wasn't perfect, but I definitely didn't see this review coming when I bought this game and had I known I would've happily paid more. I'm definitely going to be recommending this to people in the future, and keeping tabs on the team behind it because they were the ones who DECIDED for make such bold claims for this game, and it paid off. I'm excited for even bolder games from them in the future - more self-loving transgender characters, please!! :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198271962473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1480439158}
review:
This game will not dissapoint you. I had a lot of fun playing it. 
Graphics and music are good. The plot is solid and the characters are well constructed. Also, puzzles are not silly. They are well thought to fit inside the story, and they are hard (some of them), but they are far from be impossible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058695291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 856, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 856, 'last_played': 1482560605}
review:
Technobabylon looks very polished for the engine it was made in. The visuals are the first thing that draws my eye. It's futuristic landscape and location both in the physical world and virtual are incredibly eye catching. In this adventure you play a detective on the trail of a serial killer and a net junky who has been suffering a series of unfortunate events if you will. 

Starting off you aren't exactly sure how these two character's stories seem to connect and that's an underlying mystery as they both have missions of their own, crossing but for the most part independent of one another. The story itself while is not hard to follow does have a lot of science and a bit of technical jargon mixed in but nothing too hard to follow. Each chapter is great at giving you a piece of the bigger picture without completely confusing the player and I appreciated when I got to experience past events that helped explain our main detective's state of mind. This all leads to a natural progressions of things and events that come together so smoothly. When you have that "aha" moment it just fits and everything makes sense. 

As with most adventure games you have your fair share of puzzles. The beginning is where I was most frustrated because it confused me how I would take a physical object into the internet realm but after that initial segment puzzles were a bit easier. They required a bit of thinking. A lot of moving my mouse over random stuff to see if I could click it and a lot of paying attention to my surroundings and conversations. There's various puzzles in each chapter and usually you're putting your detective skills to good use. I found the final set of puzzles particularly clever and fun to figure out because you had to utilize all 3 characters to solve it. 

This game by far has the best representation of online interactions, even a torturous little mini-game by the name of Gravball, which happens to be human Pong. I must have spent the better part of half an hour trying to beat the computer legit. Even with the game being linear I never felt like I was stuck in an area for too long. Things never got stale or boring. It's rare that an adventure can keep my interests straight through. And I didn't think it suffered any of the pitfalls that other games seem to possess. 

So in short you've got a beautiful, fast paced game with intelligent varied puzzles. Decent voice acting and music which never gets stale. I think Technobabylon is one of Wadjet Eye's better games and if you're a fan of futuristic, science-y detective games then you should definitely put this one on your "to play" list.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018809375', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 823, 'last_played': 1483198187}
review:
+ Strong story telling
+ Well voice acted (apart from one or two lines from Dr. Lao)
+ Puzzle difficulty seems about right in order to keep story advancing and not to bog it down
+ Some puzzles have more than one solution
+ Choises Matter (tm)

- Pixel art looks a bit wonky with larger monitors!
- Clunky inventory and options menus. (Nitpicky of me)
- Really not much.

In short. Get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027176913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1685038196}
review:
Halfway (or so) through the game, I can only recommend it for everyone who loves the classic Lucasarts Adventures. 
Technobabylon can hold its own! A brilliant game with a good storyline, likeable characters and nice, fair puzzles. 
I love it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197961709443', 'num_games_owned': 139, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 771, 'last_played': 1482151666}
review: Really a well crafted game. The music is great, the voice acting is superb and the game's setting will satisfy anyone who enjoys cyberpunk stuff. It can be pretty difficult at times but I recommend to use a walkthrough if you really get stuck. It would be a shame to miss out on the whole game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024611733', 'num_games_owned': 921, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482945978}
review: Pro milovníky sci-fi atraktivní příběh s pěknou grafikou a výrazným hudebním doprovodem. Zajímavé alternativní konce a za tu cenu výborná herní doba. Další adventurní nářez od Wadjet Eye Games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065838286', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1482771388}
review: Fantastic game. Great setting, great story. If this would be a movie, I would watch it every month!

author: {'steamid': '76561197980111608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1482762202}
review: What's not to like. Great story, great voice acting, great art and engaging puzzles that drive the story. One of the best point and click adventures to come along in a while. Here's hoping for a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060086876', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1482786645}
review: Immaculate writing combined with nostalgic graphics and interface. For any fans of the old-style quest games, I cannot recommend this enough! Get it now!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992551560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1482706235}
review:
Too much of the puzzle solutions feel like they require knowledge you don't have access to.  Sometime even the goals of a particular area don't seem particularly clear.  Half the time when I gave up and checked a walkthrough my feeling were "how was I meant to know to do that".

Some sort of 'hint' system would be nice, like when the agents contact Central.

author: {'steamid': '76561198196444306', 'num_games_owned': 1155, 'num_reviews': 438, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 585, 'last_played': 1486386326}
review: The gameplay is standard point-and-click detective stuff but the futuristic city is beautiful and makes the game very memorable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013698729', 'num_games_owned': 372, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 932, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 805, 'last_played': 1482680221}
review: Bardzo dobra przygodówka w starym stylu point'n'click osadzona w cyberpunkowych realiach. Ma wszystko co gra tego typu mieć powinna. Przede wszystkim wciągającą fabułę, ciekawe postacie, dobrze podłożone głosy, bardzo klimatyczną muzykę i grafikę w stylu retro. Zagadki są bardzo przystępne i w większości przypadków logiczne, choć bywały momenty, że trochę eksperymentowałem z przedmiotami w ekwipunku :P Parę mniejszych błędów w grze znalazłem, ale nic co warto by wymieniać. Fajna odskocznia od gier zręcznościowych.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151506632', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1480127840}
review:
This review will be coloured by the fact I love a) Cyberpunk and b) Point and Click games. The story is well thought out and brilliant, and the voice acting consistantly excellent. The atmosphere is wonderful


The game is pretty story heavy, and I would have liked more and more diverse puzzles. The art style is one that people will either love or hate. Personally, I liked the pixel art style, and found it really worked with the atmosphere of the game, but others might not find it as impressive. 

Overall, I found it a great game with well written characters, wonderful voice acting, good and consistant atmosphere, and a great story. Would recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198069163676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 653, 'last_played': 1481149242}
review:
This is a great game for the people who like:
      - Pixel art,
      - Adventure games,
      - Games with topics related to artificial intelligence, neural-interfaces and futuristic ethic discussions, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071844660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1482264246}
review:
I liked it a lot, until a gamebreaking bug near the end killed it for me. The story was relatively interesting, and I liked the characters well enough. They follow stereotypes a bit too much for me and sometimes some actions are unbelievable for me. However, it wasn't that bad, and I still liked the game. 

Then, I spent about an hour and a half trying to finish the last chapter, but it just didn't work. [spoiler]I put the grenade in the drone and tried both ways; I sent it toward the power supply - machinery ate the drone. I sent it underneath towards the Mindjacker - machinery still ate the drone. I tried it multiple times with a little variation. I put the grenade in with each different character - even Latha. Never worked. Tried reloading to the end of the last chapter, but still couldn't get past this part when I got to it. Totally frustrating since I really wanted to finish the game and see the end.[/spoiler] Good game, but that bug just utterly destroyed my enjoyment.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972372546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1482285749}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000157319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 869, 'last_played': 1482389851}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993355584', 'num_games_owned': 138, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 692, 'last_played': 1559053974}
review: Solid adventure with memorable characters, good story and several engings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027994280', 'num_games_owned': 510, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1482000643}
review:
Technobabylon is a great point-and-click adventure, with puzzles being exactly right in terms of difficulty. It's sometimes a little hard to keep up with the story, though.

[h1]Pro's[/h1]
[list]
[*]Has a good story, explained from various points of view that inevitably cross paths, of course :)
[*]The game throws a fair challenge at you and doesn't give too many hints. I felt that it was balanced just right.
[*]Great cyberpunk theme, being slightly ahead of us but not thousands of years.
[*]Great voice acting by various characters. 
[*]Branching choices, and multiple endings
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]The graphics. Don't get me wrong, I love nostalgic pixel graphics, but the game initially ran at a 640x800 resolution and after bumping that up the sprites became so awful I decided to scale back down, but that didnt look so great either. Not acceptable for a game of this day and age.
[*]The whole game's universe doesn't explain itself well enough sometimes. With various technical jargon thrown in between it just gets a little confusing sometimes. This also goes for the mainstoryline - Though it was good, I sometimes had the idea that I was missing things.
[/list]

Want a nostalgic point-and-click adventure in a sci-fi setting? Technobabylon is a great game for you!

[i]Was this review useful to you? [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/26849460/]Please check out the Izzy Reviews Curator page[/url] for regular updates on reviews for other games![/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197979417908', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 822, 'last_played': 1481144494}
review:
Very good game ...

... immersing you in a big universe, 
... telling an interesting, twisting story,
... offering a lot of riddle and storytelling gameplay.

What was the best for me: This world is full of things to discover. Basically in every scene you get hints about bigger things going on outside of the actual story. This universe is full, complex, seducive.

As in "Germini Rue", the story is serious, grown-up and complex ... with separate storylines getting entagled. The concern then is (and it is not fully ruled out) that not all details of the storylines add up or are fully covered. But this times, in the last chapter, they do a lot to add one and one together and to explain the big plot governing all the separate stories. 

And here, in this last chapter, is my single point of critic about the storytelling: They do too much! If you want you can get expansive explanations by three or more characters. For one, if you really go through all the dialouges then, the final loses its pacing (so much time for talk when danger is imminent?). And secondly, not all of the dialouge options then add up in a sensible order.
But that is a bit "splitting hairs". The story is good! I enjoyed my hours in the city of Newton, in the year 2087.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977229444', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 692, 'last_played': 1481668949}
review:
Over the years I lost my interest in point and click adventures. Technobabylon rekindled my enthusiasm for this genre.
It's very well written, story and characters, which after the first chapters you really start to care for. The game has a very dense atmosphere, which feels quite realistic, even for a sci-fi game - even though it's somewhat dark and gritty, it doesn't it forces itself to come across as such. Another great thing about it is, that throughout the games there are some decisions you have to make as a player. Not many, but they do matter for the story.

It's not very long and most of the puzzles are relatively easy to solve, though there are some challenges. With this game, it's more about the story and its characters, anyway.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968427953', 'num_games_owned': 1047, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 609, 'last_played': 1481661139}
review:
Otra pequeña obra de arte distribuida por Wadjet Eye Games, desarrollada por Technocrat Games. Con un estilo pixelado a la vieja escuela, brindará la posibilidad de jugar otra aventura gráfica a aquellos que añoramos las aventuras tipo SCUMM. 

Aunque esté completamente en inglés y todas las líneas de texto "habladas" tienen su voz grabada en el mismo idioma, se hace entender bastante bien.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034108667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 877, 'last_played': 1481495313}
review:
Trois personnages partagent une histoire commune. 
Cette histoire se déroule dans une ambiance "cyberpunk" très réussie.

Le scénario quant à lui évoque l'usage de "substances technologiques" afin de fuir la réalité (analogie avec l'utilisation des drogues), appuyé par le contraste des deux environnements "réel/irréel".

La difficulté des énigmes est bien dosée, donc on ne se retrouve jamais réellement bloqué. Et elles relèvent de la logique (pas de combinaisons chelous).

Durée de vie estimée à 10/12h si on prend son temps.

[u]Conclusion :[/u]
Un bon petit point'n'click avec une ambiance qui lui est propre.
Je recommande :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198038625342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 629, 'last_played': 1481339174}
review:
Sigh, Technobabylon.  A game that many people call one of the best new adventure games.  It's really not.  It's very nostalgic and a great call back to the adventure games of the past, but that's where it belongs in the past and not now.  First off, this horrendous pixel style needs to stop.  It's bad, real bad.  It looks ugly, trying to copy the pixel graphic style of games older than Kings Quest 5 is just not something I want to see.  I assume some people do, but I have no idea why.  At worst it should have the clean visual style of the Moneky Island remasters games.  I know this studio loves their pixel graphics, but harenking back to the terrible graphics of the past is not the way to go. 

You play the game as 3 different characters.  A senior detective on the police force, who is kind of this old curmudgen who hates technology and dislikes the direction the future has taken (also he is from Texas...apparently in the future Texans have no accents).  His partner, a young female detective who is a computer expert and is very much on board with the direction the future has taken and all set to accept her AI overlords.  Finally, a young female hacker, who is addicted to the internet and spends her entire life in the internet...hacking?  Of these three i liked the female detective the most and really just wanted to play the game as her the whole time, which is unfortunate because she probably has the least amount of time in the game. 

On the up side this game is far better than Gemini Rue.  The voice acting is better, the puzzles are better, the environments are better.  I really thought the voice actors did a fine job, certainly not the best job, but a fine job.  The puzzles are a lot less pixel hunty than Gemini Rue which is great.  However, the puzzles also aren't very good. They certainly don't take a lot to figure out.  I only found myself stuck on the very last puzzle in the game which involved a wrench and I had to eventually just give up.  I'm pretty confident i would never have figured it out as it required me to do something that I didn't even think was possible.  The rest of the puzzles are mainly easy, because their are very few items in the environment to click on, so most of the time i was just stumbling into solutions without even thinking.

Really, though I can forgive basically anything so long as the story is good, which is also where this game fails the most.[spoiler] I certainly like the world the game created.  This idea that after countless wars cities start to use AI to govern and administer is intriquing.  A wonderful cyberpunk setting.  Sadly, i thought i was getting a detective story in this setting, what I got was kind of a mishmash government conspiracy story and although you are a detective the story really just flows without you doing much detecting.  Oh sure the plot makes your main character out to be one of the best detectives...which is nonsensical considering you are also the greatest scientist...who i guess felt a career change to detective was a better choice?  It doesn't make any sense.  The plot moves along with your detecting mainly being stumbling into situation after situation without ever really figuring out or discovering anything.  I figured out who was behind the murders in the first hour of the game, but not due to any clues, simply because they came off as super evil and there were no other characters in the game.  The motive is revealed in an info dump near the end of the game...but you never had any clues to figure it out beforehand.  I find these types of mysteries maddening.  It shows a great lack of ability in the writing, they don't understand how to lay out a trail of clues or introduce nuance.  They just tell you the story as you go introducing one rediculous reveal after another.  

The final reveal that the AI is basically your child, and the person behind the murders is also your child, and the internet addict is also your child is just obnoxious.  Although I did enjoy my ending that the AI wants to govern the world to be a very fun cyberpunk ending.  Also because i found the AI the most likeable character in the game, i think the writers wanted the AI to come off as worrisome if not evil, but the whole game i was like man people should just do what this AI tells them it's master plan is clearly the best.  [/spoiler]

So yea, that's Technobabylon, another mediocre adventure game from the studio dedicated to making classic nostalgia adventure games.  Sigh, I feel if they just embraced the modern developments and story telling techniques games like Life is Strange have made they might be able to accomplish something very special, but instead they like to just lie back and copy what has already been done and like the main character in this game they shall always be stuck in the past.  Still, I enjoyed my time with it, just get it on massive sale, or you know just buy Life is Strange the best adventure game ever made.  So #worth $3

author: {'steamid': '76561197975760979', 'num_games_owned': 1241, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 1260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1666681103}
review:
It reminds me of a early 90's Lucasart Game mixed with Bladerunner.
If you like the Lucasart games and your a fan of Bladerunner you will love this game, the graphics aren't brilliant but the rest of the game more than makes up for it with clever and interesting storyline and some interesting if not complex puzzles to complete.
A definate wise purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047117921', 'num_games_owned': 820, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1481324123}
review:
Good point&click adventure in a very cool setting.
Lots of voiceovers (but not full) make it feel high quality.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001345346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 587, 'last_played': 1481085358}

author: {'steamid': '76561198062599735', 'num_games_owned': 4834, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1299, 'last_played': 1481117282}
review:
A great ride from start to finish, 'Technobabylon' hits all the right notes both in terms of being a great scifi/cyberpunk tale and as a point an click adventure. The story is tight and paced well, the characters are engaging and well written and the puzzles blend into the plot with general seemlessness.

Not everyone will be on board with the pixel art style and AGS engine (which is frankly starting to show its age even in 'faux-retro' titles like this) but it's hard to complain about stuff like that when it suits the storytelling style so well and there's obviously so much love put into these environments and characters; it's really remarkable what the developers have done within the constraints of the tools they're working with.

I found the difficulty of the puzzles somewhat on the easy side and there was never a point where I had to reach for a walkthrough, but then I'm a genre-veteran. The game pretty sucessfully (and organically) limits inventory and number of spaces to explore, and the characters around you are usually dropping subtle hints in dialouge as to how to proceed which keeps things moving. There's more than one way to solve a number of the challenges too which is a nice touch.

So, if you're looking for something that'll keep you busy for 10-15 hours and maybe spark off a few neurons as you wonder where technology is taking us as a species then you could do a lot worse than take a trip to Newtown in 2087. I feel there's a lot more exploring to be done in this world and I'd love to spend more time with these characters too... sequel? Please? 

On a side note, I'd like to give this game extra-special props for being one of the few games (or pieces of media period) to do representation of minorities in a really great way; two of the PCs are female non-caucasians and a major character is trans. The game and dialouge never hammer any of these points or use them as cheap ways to stir controversy and all come across as individuals. It's really great to see people from many different racial backgrounds and sexual orientations in roles both heroic and villanious and to be able to interact with them without these identifiers being the defining aspects of their characters. Many writers and devs could learn a lot from Technocrat in this area.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058097742', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1657052001}
review: Great point and click game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197989163736', 'num_games_owned': 910, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1480999663}
review:
Contiuning with their previous work, publisher Wadjet Eye Games contnues to impress me, with their excellt story, art, and voice overs throughout all of their games. This title is no diffrent.

Set in the near future, a father who works as a a biological engineer must fulfill a task while being blackmailed. In doing so, his family's history comes together, as well as his life's work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021189513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1480976582}
review:
This is an entertaining retro point & click adventure with slightly harder than average puzzlers. If you are a fan of this genre, then this is a definite worth-while pick-up. Major strengths are the writing & plot and a good balance of difficulty. Weaknesses are a lack of variety in puzzle type (a few too many based on "hard to spot object) and not getting to use all main characters in the game at once until the last chapter. 

On the while, I definitely enjoyed it for the low price I paid (under $5.00).  If you like this type of game or think you'd be interested in trying it, it's a good buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007513026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 433, 'playtime_forever': 954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 909, 'last_played': 1480988314}
review:
A really terrible adventure game. I will be avoiding adventure games from this developer in the future.

I've been playing adventure games since the Apple II days and I'm reasonably good at solving the puzzles. I found the first half of Technobabylon to be easy, mostly because there aren't that many puzzles.

The second half was a different story. Lots more puzzles and some  of them have very unlikely solutions. Pixel hunting becomes more of an issue as well. I don't mind getting stuck on a puzzle if when I eventually find the solution I think "of course, that makes sense". Too many times in Technobabylon I was thinking "what the heck?".

SInce I play adventure games for the puzzles Technobabylon was a big disapointment for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995082470', 'num_games_owned': 723, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1019, 'last_played': 1481303817}
review:
I am really a fanboy when it comes to cyberpunk.

This game really looks like it has been influenced by Neuromancer a lot. That was enough for me, in the first 15 mins, I was already sure that I was going to like it.

If you can't keep your hands off every piece of cyberpunk you can find like me, there is something for you here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007173337', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 867, 'last_played': 1480854598}
review:
As a fan of cyberpunk and PnC games, I enjoyed Technobabylon. Storyline is good, with some interesting turns here and there and some freedom of choice. Puzzles, however, are all very straightforward which, combined with the rather small scale of the scenes, makes them pretty easy in general. PnC veterans might find it too easy, even.

All in all - if you like a good cyberpunk story and are ok (or actually looking for) a not too challenging play, this is a good buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983545926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 348, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1480829016}
review: This game comes off as way too contrived from the get-go. The art style is nice and the voice-acting is tolerable. But unfortunately, I'm making comparisons between this game and Gemini Rue, which was an excellent adventure game in the same genre. This game just isn't interesting enough to warrant my time or attention.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075958965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1546368053}
review: At the beginning the game is slow, but in few steps the game starts being addictive. Give him an oportunity if you like a depth stories :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198109883351', 'num_games_owned': 1814, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 973, 'last_played': 1480759415}
review:
Wadjeteye knock it out of the park with an ambitious PnC. Possibly the best adventure game I've ever played for a memorable story and  great characters.

[ Fun: 9 | Plot: 10 | CTRL: 8 | GFX: 8 | SFX: 8 | Stable: Y | Replay: 6 ] = 9/10

+ Superb 8 bit graphics and animations
+ Best voice acting in a wadjeteye game yet
+ Story is incredibly well thought out and cohesive
+ Multiple ways to complete some objectives
+ Great mechanics and puzzles
+ Great save system, both automated and user driven
+ Audio is spot on.
+ Commentary and multiple choice outcomes adds replay

~ Pretty story heavy and not massively puzzle diverse
~ Gets incredibly talky in the last chapter.
~ Occasionally too much information with redundant and repeated conversations
~ Not always clear when there are multiple outcomes until after you complete a task

- Can sometimes get bogged down, unable to work out what to do next

author: {'steamid': '76561197989961895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1480750439}
review: Great story. Tricky puzzles. Cool idea. Recommendo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028123272', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 588, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1483575433}
review: 게임성은 괜찮아 보이지만 언어의 장벽은 너무나도 높았다...

author: {'steamid': '76561198059643100', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 921, 'last_played': 1480713411}
review:
I want to say that this is one of the best adventure games I ever played. It has a complex story, with enticing characters, good voice acting, and based-on-reality, or very plausible, scientific themes. The setting is new and refreshing, the game is pleasant but not too difficult to resolve. 

All in all this was the best use of my money for some time. I would certainly purchase a sequel, or sequels, should they decide to make new games with this setting. Thumbs up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022669942', 'num_games_owned': 255, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1016, 'last_played': 1592750110}
review:
Ésta es una aventura inteligente y balanceada, aunque por desgracia no demasiado redonda. Tiene buen arte detrás, un buen guión, buenas ideas, buenos personajes... La historia tal vez deja algo que desear hacia el tramo final, al igual que algunas situaciones, pero nada que empañe la experiencia global.

Me gusta cuando un juego tiene los puzzles tan bien diseñados como para no tener que mirar una guía cada media hora y a la vez no te trata como un espectador de Barrio Sésamo. De hecho es probable que no necesites mirar guía ni una vez y no estés atascado demasiado tiempo.

A mí, me ha tocado la patata. Píllatelo, sobre todo si eres fan del cyberpunk y/o las aventuras gráficas, en cuyo caso es obligatoria. ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197972632885', 'num_games_owned': 936, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 448, 'last_played': 1479841131}
review: Wadjet Eye games knocks another one out of the park with this great, moody cyberpunk adventure game. Some of the puzzles are challenging, but nothing an old school adventure gamer will struggle with.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998118312', 'num_games_owned': 2100, 'num_reviews': 388, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 574, 'last_played': 1480303048}
review: This is a very biased review. I love the cyberpunk setting and I love point and click genre games. This game feels like a throwback to old school gaming. The story is interesting if a bit confusing at first but gradually makes more sense and the puzzles are well thought out. If you are fans of the genre then you must play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116211741', 'num_games_owned': 920, 'num_reviews': 220, 'playtime_forever': 1262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1262, 'last_played': 1500771083}
review:
A lot of love and care went into this game.  It's the real deal. It's a genuine, no-flash, no-frills, no BS point-and-clicker.  The writing, the puzzles, the design, all rock solid.

Do I recommend this game?  I do, oh my yes.

One Year later edit:  I Can't stop thinking about this game.  I've played through two more times, and it never gets old.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118372991', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 933, 'last_played': 1487116990}
review:
UPDATE: Upon finishing the game, I've changed my review to a reccommendation. Yes, some of the puzzles are annoying, but overall this game has some fantastic characters, a well-developed setting and great characters. If you like point-and-clicks, this is for you.

________________________________________________________
My old review:
I love adventure games, but sadly I found this particular title to be extremely slow, hampered by a clunky UI and full of unintuitive, frustrating puzzles. I had to give up after a few hours because of the number of times I needed to consult a walkthrough for puzzle solutions that were essentially just trial and error. The concept is strong and the writing is largely very good, I just found the gameplay itself to be lacking.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969601029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1480422431}
review:
I have to say, Technobablyon is the first point and click adventure I've really enjoyed.

All of the puzzles are SMART. Not just "click random thing on random other things until stuff happens". You can actually THINK about the puzzles, think about what could actually solve them, then work towards those solutions, making for satisfying gameplay!

The characters are also smart! They're different, wrong sometimes, make mistakes, but they actually try to think and understand what is going on. I enjoyed all of the protagonists.

I'm happy to say that every time I got stumped on a puzzle (with one minor exception, mentioned below), it wasn't because the solution was bizarre or counter-intuitive, it was just that I hadn't thought about the actual facts of puzzle the right way.

The major downside is the ending (spoilers).

A minor flaw is it sloppily scripted (lots of weird bugs that you can cause, nothing game-breaking but obviously not been through thorough QA, like the door lock lights disappearing (not turning off - literally disappearing) after you go through the door and return, or Lao being able to hand her wetware to Regis but not get it back).

It's also unclear that there is an entire third floor in the Trance, making the final part of the puzzle a matter of luck or blind guesswork.

But the big part is the endings are unsatisfying. Either you force a person into slavery, or you force them into being someone else's agenda and to go through an invasive mind-altering procedure without their input. I would have been much happier if there was a third option, where you can actually respect the autonomy of the AGI and let it free without compulsion. Or at least if you can ask Central what she thinks of her options.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087134039', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 890, 'last_played': 1479351749}
review:
Genial aventura gráfica, con dialogos bien actuados (en ingles) y una historia muy interesante.
Es un buen acercamiento a las aventuras graficas que funciona con hardware muy modesto.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150578315', 'num_games_owned': 1034, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 753, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 753, 'last_played': 1480385050}
review:
9/10 what cyber punk is supposed to be imo, some might say a little cliche.
the story will take you from neon-noir streets to heavenly cesspits. 
the aesthetics have 90's charm with modern polish for that nostalgia hit and it hit.
enjoyable level of difficulty, i did look up a guide for one puzzle and that's pretty good for me 
took me 12 hours i think its definitely worth getting on sale or full price at £1/hr

author: {'steamid': '76561198026458592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 530, 'last_played': 1480312761}
review: I've played dozens and this is my favorite point & click adventure on steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992715385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 827, 'last_played': 1480259898}
review: It's actually a realy good game with a lot of subtle worldbuilding, interesting characters and a really nice looking artstyle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032690787', 'num_games_owned': 564, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1480254771}
review: One of the best adventure games I've played in a while. Clever, but not overwhelming puzzles, great writing, and focused characters, all in an extremely consistent cyberpunk setting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198312746645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1480248125}
review: played this game twice because it's SO good! super interesting ideas of a new world & once you got used to the items and setting you won't stop playing ^_^ every character is very special and you get a grip of them. what i found awesome too, was the representation of trans ppl and that there are so many poc who play a main role. so in a political aspect, it's one of the awesomest games i came across so far. i would recommend it to ppl who like point & click, pixel graphics, technologies (obvsly) and detective elements. :3 (great soundtrack btw, can't stop listening!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198048962859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 436, 'last_played': 1537630739}
review: Realy good story line

author: {'steamid': '76561198177916517', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1480228208}
review: Great characters, dialogue, plot, music, and voice acting. I really like the setting. Despite the cyberpunk label, the world is not the done-to-death hardcore dystopia. It's a place with serious problems, but also good aspects, so the player's success never feels meaningless in the grand scheme of things. This also makes the world feel more plausible. The subject matter (artificial intelligence, genetic engineering) leans heavy, but the game finds the right balance of seriousness and humor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000296031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1690862346}
review:
I came to this game having previously played Gemini Rue, and think this game is even better. The sci-fi world is very well realized touching many interesting ideas and concepts, and more than once making me think about a certain character's attitude towards the internet and the fake online world called "The Trance" and the real world commentary it makes with that analogy.

Puzzles are not totally obtuse, most are obvious but getting stuck is not impossible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061771304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 846, 'last_played': 1480190976}
review: One of the best cyberpunkt stories I ever played - maybe not the best game but the best story...

author: {'steamid': '76561198000105112', 'num_games_owned': 865, 'num_reviews': 216, 'playtime_forever': 960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1566447127}
review: A good cyberpunk adventure game that has a good story. Characters at times frustrated me, but overall an enjoyable game.

review:
Great story, great characters, great writing.  Fantastic voice acting.  Charming pixel art.

I'm stone cold and this game made me care about what happened to both the main cast and the side-characters.

Puzzles were good too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063013389', 'num_games_owned': 1076, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 519, 'last_played': 1484518308}
review:
Awesome, meaty (gen-enhanced, natch) piece of cyberpunk! 
Great writing, intriguing story, competent and likable voiceacting, stunning pixelart - what's not to like! I love all the Wadjeteye games, and allthough this isn't from it's main developer/artist Joshua Neurnberg, Wadjeteye have once again demonstraed their keen eyes for traditional P&C adventures. Half way through and can't praise it enough!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011197107', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1706719985}

author: {'steamid': '76561198033995360', 'num_games_owned': 2161, 'num_reviews': 441, 'playtime_forever': 857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1479974903}
review:
Technobabylon est un bon jeu d'aventure, visuellement très aléatoire. Le meilleur du cyberpunk et du pixel art, les panoramas les plus dingues et quelques tableaux esthétiquement très ambitieux réussiraient presque à nous faire oublier les autres décors ratés, le banal et le cradingue. Un bon quart du jeu se passe d'ailleurs dans une simulation informatique qui nous est décrite comme un deuxième monde fascinant, un Eden de gigaoctets, un univers parallèle fantastique dans lequel des millions d'utilisateurs gâchent leur vie. Un paradis virtuel auquel on a du mal à croire : desservi par des idées vusuelles datées, ce [i]web 3.0[/i] fait peine à voir avec son interface désespérément vide et ses allures de Minitel sous VR.

Le scénario n'est pas si emballant que ça non plus. Le stylo est un peu trop lourd, l'écriture un poil trop facile pour nous surprendre. Technobabylon exagère des rebondissements glauques pour avoir l'air cool ; ses théories correspondent si bien aux peurs dictées par les meilleurs romans d'anticipation qu'il n'a rien trouvé de mieux que de les dépasser dans l'excès pour s'en distinguer ; Technobabylon oublie d'être autre chose qu'un Game of Thrones du futur, une oeuvre qui, à force de vouloir nous montrer à quel point elle peut être sombre, donne l'impression de n'être qu'un adolescent un peu intelligent qui montre à tout-va des captures d'écran du [i]deep web[/i] pour impressionner ses camarades de classe, un récit immature qui ne cherche à choquer que pour choquer. C'est pourtant au milieu de cette débauche souvent inutile que Technobabylon est paradoxalement le plus intéressant : cette vision [i]forcément![/i] dystopique du lendemain a le mérite de confronter les élans d'aujourd'hui aux chutes qui les attendent, met le doigt sinon sur les excès, sur la dynamique de notre société qui ne cherche à violer ses tabous que pour le simple plaisir de se féliciter d'avoir pu le faire. Les justifications morales qui nous encombraient disparaissent, la bêtise et l'égoïsme peuvent briller de tout leur éclat. Comme dans un concours de pipi télévisé où on jubile jaune d'être regardé par le monde entier, la seule satisfaction est d'être allé plus loin que les autres.

Technobabylon n'est pas un bon thriller ; il raconte une enquête dont on comprend les aboutissants trop vite. Mais il est un bon point & click aux énigmes logiques quoi qu'un brin inattendues. Divisée en dix actes, l'aventure claque et verrouille chacune des portes que l'on vient de traverser ; impossible de revenir sur les tableaux des chapitres précédents. L'aire de jeu (et donc des puzzles) est limitée et évite ainsi les écueils d'une progression labyrinthique. Les rares énigmes farfelues sont compensées par cette progression parfaitement délimitée. Parce qu'il nous pousse toujours en avant, Technobabylon est un chemin sans impasses.

Technobabylon est parfois maladroit, souvent trop absolu. Mais il n'est avare de rien ; le background est documenté, le gameplay tire profit des trois héros à incarner, tous les dialogues sont doublés et le sont très bien - si on accepte d'oublier un personnage français qui ne sait pas parler français. C'est une histoire aux grosses ficelles qui arrive quand même à être touchante ; c'est un récit bavard qui dit tout ce qui lui passe par la tête, une aventure qui a beaucoup de choses à montrer et à suggérer. Les conséquences d'un monde où les enfants ne s'amusent qu'à dépasser les lignes rouges tracées par leurs parents. L'une des destinations potentielles d'une logique qui veut aller toujours plus loin, toujours plus haut, toujours plus vite. L'accident possible d'une civilisation, comme ce train sur le point de dérailler ou cet atlhlète aveugle qui fonce à toute allure dans une vierge de fer. Un jeu qui fait déjà passer les végétaliens et les [i]genderfluids[/i] pour des vieux réactionnaires.

(Mais Gemini Rue était vachement mieux)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025184583', 'num_games_owned': 1977, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1074, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 991, 'last_played': 1463883960}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030931935', 'num_games_owned': 942, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1129, 'last_played': 1479494456}
review:
This is another great game like always from Wadjet Eye!

Graphic is nice, a well known pixel art related style. It features great cyberpunk atmosphere and feel. I really liked the story in game, it has a few twists that will make you think what really happened and why.

I recommended this game as must have to all fans of adventure games, especially with cyberpunk theme.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052404116', 'num_games_owned': 3045, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1200, 'last_played': 1480823770}
review: A TRUE GEM of the modern-classic graphic adventure. Great characters, great pacing, excellent art and voice acting, good puzzles and even some replayability. An absolute must for anyone with an interest in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013792101', 'num_games_owned': 629, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 697, 'last_played': 1469217948}
review: One of the coolest point-and-clicks around. It's smart, it keeps BS adventure logic to a minimum, the graphics are tight for an AGS game, and it's got a good cast of characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066302788', 'num_games_owned': 408, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1479942082}
review: If you are a fan of the old point and click adventure games, this is for you.  It's very well done and the story is interesting.  There are some good twists in both the story and the characters.  It is meant for more mature audience due to the story and the situations.  I really enjoyed playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198220981708', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 518, 'last_played': 1478055266}
review:
看到赛博朋克果断买买买
很良心的小团队，无论从剧情，音乐，CV，画面来说都可以打9分
多主角叙事，故事讲得相当完美，赛博朋克的世界观也呈现得很完整

author: {'steamid': '76561198027971952', 'num_games_owned': 1797, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1479928431}
review:
The story plays out like a "best of" compilation of science fiction tropes. It's done quite well, but I can't help wondering whether one idea too many was thrown in the mix. At points I felt whether they went overboard with the world-building without any payoff - at least it gives hope that a sequel is coming (or a series like Blackwell, even). 

Interesting and intuitive gameplay mechanics with logical puzzles (I only had to cheat like, once). 
Gorgeous old-fashioned Wadjet art. Great voice work and music. No bugs found.

All in all, a great game worth its full price. Although I got it in a bundle, being the cheap person I am.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201493055', 'num_games_owned': 75, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1408, 'last_played': 1478360399}
review:
La mia prima avventura grafica... incredibile esperienza che non mi sarei mai aspettato. 
Storia matura, che poggia le basi sui clichè del cyberpunk.
Comparto artistico ottimo, che permette di immergersi nei futuristici meandri di Newton, la città in cui si svolgono gli eventi.
Enigmi complessi (soprattutto per un neofita come me), ma mai impossibili.
Che dire, acquistatelo ora!!!!!!!!!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987721402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1565588262}
review:
TLDR: If you dislike  point-and-clickers for their endless backtracking, vague or even nonsensical puzzles, and/or "jokes>story" attitude, give Technobabylon a shot. 

The game is almost constantly moving forward, with little need to return to areas previously visited; puzzles are logical and straightforward yet challenging, and your goal in any given situation is clear; and excellent writing means you experience an engaging story with developed characters while still getting to enjoy a traditional sci-fi setting, with more than a little humour thrown in. Technobabylon proves that the problems asscociated with most point-and-click adventures aren't an indelible part of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972040704', 'num_games_owned': 1844, 'num_reviews': 725, 'playtime_forever': 844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 844, 'last_played': 1479797162}
review:
So when I finished Kathy Rain, I was left feeling greatly dissatisfied with the story and only liking maybe 3 characters from the entire game. The mechanics were good enough, though, so I figured I'd give Technobabylon a go since it had a similar "look" to it in terms of having the appearance of a '90s adventure game. When the game loaded, I saw that the same publisher made the game, and I immediately felt my heart sink, because Kathy Rain put me out so badly, and when Technobabylon started, its gameplay mechanics were obviously not as streamlined as Kathy Rain's, having less interaction options, less stuff to interact with on each screen, less mandatory dialog, and interactive stuff did not show on the screen when pushing a button like in Kathy Rain (spacebar). Technobabylon was going to be a techno-turd...or so I thought.

Instead, I found a game with far more relevant characters, likable characters (for me, at least), legitimate antagonists (screw you, Crimson Man from Kathy Rain!), and a story and world that were quite intriguing. It's a cyberpunk setting where a large city has had an AI put in charge of all of its civil services, and a couple of your characters you control are officers of the law, who report to the AI, dealing with manhunts, homicide, etc. The guy has a nice character arc, the gal is just plain likable, and another female you play as gives you the impression in her first 30 seconds of self-narrated introduction that she's going to be one thing, then you really see what's going on right after and realize her opinion of herself and the reality are quite different, and makes for an interesting character.

As a cop of the world, you will be mostly dealing with physical things in the world, with a stun gun and standard adventure game puzzle-solving. However, as the one girl, you enter the "TRANCE," which is basically The Matrix/TRON. Users have digital avatars and can interact online with one another. Due to the plot, you'll do very little of interacting with other users, except at one point in the game. Most of the time, however, you will be rubbing blue gel on machines to establish a connection between them and you, letting you interact with comical artificial intelligences to try to resolve problems that would otherwise be impossible for her to overcome in the real world. It's a nice spin to have the game change things up in this fashion.

The introductions of characters are informative and there are a fair number of surprises in terms of certain characters showing up again who seemed like a one-time thing, much to my delight. My favorite character was practically a gag character, but was in the game sporadically until the end. No amazing villains, but they're pretty decent; one's a bit of an eye-roll-inducer (for me, anyway). This world is just pretty cool. It "borrows" a lot from stuff like TRON/The Matrix/Shadowrun (a character even calls the real world the "meatspace," but it still felt like an original story, with plenty of dressing of things that weren't crucial to the main plot but did wonders for world-building. 

The puzzles made me think much of the time, though there were times I was clicking on things at random if I got stuck. I managed to avoid using a walkthrough except ONE time. It was literally the final puzzle I had left to solve in the game (involved some glowing lights on a wall that I couldn't find). The difficulty of the game was nice and had less rage-inducing puzzles than Kathy Rain did, and it didn't feel so "anal" as Kathy rain in regard to having to go through every piece of dialog to proceed (though I did because the world, story, and characters interested me).

I would love to see more games in this world, but in different cities and with new and returning characeters. Heck, I'll just admit it: I loved Cheffie. I think we're suppose to hate her or be annoyed by her, but man was she fun for me. Anywho, I think sequels or prequels set in different parts of the world not strongly connected to each storyline could be excellent, and I would love to see them get made. I definitely recommend this game to fans of cyberpunk and/or point-and-click adventure games.
