author: {'steamid': '76561197971828592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1433577068}
review: Really good writing, excellent sci-fi/cyberpunk theme, and sensible puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019651249', 'num_games_owned': 1407, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1432794774}
review:
Greatly enjoyed this game. Good writing and excellent narrative structure - a story where all the threads take wing in unexpected directions and come back together just the way they ought to. Liked the blend of noir with humourous, endearing characters and the 'wetware' approach to technology.

Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561197997152026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 809, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 809, 'last_played': 1433448510}
review:
- 8/10 - рекомендую! (oh my, yes!) :]

- под не самой привлекательной на свете мешаниной из пикселей на движке AGS тут упрятана вечная, но при этом не особо противная история "самых обычных Отцов и генно модифицированных Детей" - и все это без упора на традиционное стремление point-and-click-аттракционов вечно все усложнять - в виде на удивление компактной и, кажется, безошибочно дозированной детективной истории о мире, который погряз в кибер-генно-ядерном-и-постъядерном-панк-трэше - эта sci-fi-вселенная удивляет тем, что уже сама не способна чему-либо удивляться ... плюс к этому - неплохо переданное, будоражащее кровь ощущение от стремления затеряться в Глобальной Сети ("тут" ее называют "Транс") - даже ради намека на такие чувства - хотел бы рекомендовать! :]

author: {'steamid': '76561197962302493', 'num_games_owned': 1567, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 680, 'last_played': 1433437454}
review: I'm glad I bought this. The writing is really good, the soundtrack fits perfectly and the execution is spot on. Technically it's your typical Wadjet Eye Point&Click Adventure (including the limitations of the Adventure Studio engine) but in a Cyberpunk setting. The puzzles that need to be solved to progress the story aren't artificial and make perfect sense. Also props for investing in a sheer endless amount of non-important "wrong number" responses.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002784244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1434320211}

author: {'steamid': '76561198046627974', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1536309788}
review: Great adventure game reminiscent of classic point and click games of the late 80s/early 90s like Monkey Island. Well written dialog and voice acted, interesting character motivations and history, and a really cohesive cyberpunk future theme. Puzzles are easy to medium difficulty, but nothing incredibly hard. The environments are especially well done, especially for the art style. A few pretty suspenseful moments, too, which speaks to how immersive the game gets. Runs approximately 8 to 12 hours depending on how fast you figure things out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985371264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 826, 'last_played': 1450785070}
review:
[b]Однозначно[/b] рекомендую эту игру. 

Конец двадцать первого века. США расколоты на два государства гражданской войной, большая часть Азии страдает от еще даже не закончившейся ядерной войны, Европа давно объединилась в одну большую страну, чтобы спасти себя. 
Прогресс тоже не стоял на месте. Люди смогли создать наномашины, которые позволяют мозгу напрямую интегрироваться с электронными системами. Так был создан Транс, виртуальное пространство, в котором огромное количество пользователей может быть тем, кем/чем хочет. Там нет законов и правил. 
Добро пожаловать в мир будущего. В [i]Техновавилон[/i].

Эта игра - история трех персонажей, которые оказались в (не)нужном месте в (не)нужное время.  Место действий - город Ньютон, которым управляет ИИ нового поколения Цэнтрал. 

Доктор Чарльз Риджис и доктор Макс Лао работают в Центре Экстренной Логистики - CEL -, по сути являющимся полицией города Ньютон. Вооруженные своей смекалкой, тазерами и помощью Цэнтрал они должны расследовать череду странных преступлений, совершенных Майндджэкером, человеком, который крадет разумы людей. 
Лата Сезам - безработный аддикт Транса; она не может и пары дней протянуть без виртуального пространства. В один момент она, будучи в собственной социальной квартире, теряет соединение с Трансом и влипает в такую историю, что техподдержка ей точно не поможет.

Каждый из них - действительно личность, и за них действительно сложно не переживать. Эмоции героев чувствуются, реакции закономерны и логичны. Несмотря на то, что многие придираются к голосовой озвучке, мне она по нраву, хотя местами чувствуется несколько любительский подход. 

Музыкальное оформление совершенно безупречно. Над ним работал тот же композитор, что и в небезызвестном [i]Gemini Rue[/i]. По его же заверению, ОСТ игры можно будет купить в Steam в ближайшее время.

Графическая составляющая достаточно неплоха для подобной игры: демонстрирует интересные анимации, персонажи делают какие-то свои дела. Но, если по справедливости, какой-то невероятной графики Вы тут точно не увидите. 

Геймплей схож с тем, что можно встретить в любом другом квесте: классический наведи@щелкни. Охотой за пикселями, впрочем, вас заставлять заниматься не будут. 
Паззлы достаточно сложны, в нескольких местах, скорее всего, придется действительно крепко призадуматься, но нигде не нужно догадываться, чего же от Вас хотел разработчик, все решения логичны, хоть пусть эта логика и работает в рамках самой игры.

Если Вы сомневаетесь, стоит ли покупать [i]Техновавилон[/i], и Вы не играли в [i]Gemini Rue[/i], могу посоветовать начать с последнего. Он стоит дешевле, но по стилю и духу эти игры очень похожи. 

К сожалению, у игры есть один серьезный "минус" - полное отсутствие поддержки русского языка. Мне трудно сказать, будет ли когда-либо сделаны русские субтитры или даже озвучка, но пока их не предвидится. 

В любом случае, игра потрясает глубиной своего мира и сюжета. Искренний Вам совет: не торопитесь. Читайте каждое письмо, проведите каждый диалог и обязательно прочтите свежие новости. 
Да, даже спортивные.

網文

author: {'steamid': '76561198029056133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1433051359}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971695417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 3210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1868, 'last_played': 1441492819}
review: I hate point and click adventure games. I do like sci fi though. This is good stuff, solid recommendation, approx 9 hours well spent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078340165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1436899793}
review: I've been playing point and click adventure games ever since the days of Maniac Mansion, and I can honestly say that Technobabylon is one of the most satisfying experiences I have ever experienced in the genre.  The dark cyberpunk setting of the city of Newton sets a perfect stage.  The puzzles are intuitive and very creative.  What sets this game apart however, is its amazing story and voice acting.  This has some of the best voice acting I have heard in an adventure game, and that really adds to the overall experience.  I highly recommend this game and commend all the folks who worked on it for releasing such a stellar product.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994794568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1404, 'last_played': 1582063097}
review:
I cannot think about anything in Technobabylon I particularly did not like.

From the awesome score, to the witty dialogue, creative and complex puzzles and engaging cyber dystopian atmosphere, Technobabylon opened on a high note, and up until the credits, damn well held out on a strong stellar beat.

It's the type of game that if you're not a long term follower of Wadjet Eye Games (like me), you'd be like "how did I not know of this?" and then seek them out for more.

But on Technobablyon, lets discuss the pros.

On gameplay, the simple style of "one room but a hell of a lot to do" is fun, yet brain taxing. It must be me and my diet of modern hold-your-hand grade 5 logic puzzles, and shoot-pointblank-don't-think FPS's, but it took me a while to figure out a few of the challenges. That's not really a bad thing, as the puzzles are (mostly fun) and very creative in thought and execution (the CI program on the synths ensures hilarity), and overall, it's a refreshing experience for cerebral activity in their gaming. Just be prepared to use the noggin! ;)

Characters are mostly cliche-free ridden, with talented but vulnerable Latha, transgender protagonist Max (a minor but still notable detail), and "old-man" technophobe Charlie, a Texan who finds himself caught in a situation he doesn't want involving his deceased Sri-Lankan wife. In fact, very noticeable are the diverse and different ethnicities and characters; again it's something new and different in media. (Heck, the setting of fiction Newton city is India, not "New York," or even LA!!)

The music sets the world mood excellently. From the calming sooth and placid feel of escapist Trance lobbys, to dour, gritty feel of investigate megacity murder, the audio matches the setting, tone, and pace mirroring the on screen action.

The writing is wry and writty; sardonic Max makes one sarcastic quip after the next, and Charlie has his own way of handling things, as does Latha, but really, so do all characters, major and minor alike, with a writing humorous style in  constant flow. On note of the characters, the voice acting is quite impressive, with characters carrying the wit and humor far, and giving some mostly convincing dramatics. The narrative engages, and the plot catches, though listen and pay careful attention to the narrative earlier than later, otherwise you'll miss a few things, as well as some "oh wow!" story revelations. 

I can tell that it was a small studio (probably very small actually) that made TB, but there was a lot of love and care put into it and it shows. The game is very charming, and in the days of 4K res, 60fps, blah, blah, it at least gathers an unhealthy, grimy ambience to the entire cyberpunk setting. One other thing to appreciate, despite the small studio size, Technobabylon retains from feeling like a tiny indie game with peesy commercial value. Give or take a few noticable modern things, if this was back in the day and you'd said a big studio made it, I'd have swallowed it in one go.

Some minor gripes: one puzzle involving a crime scene you stumble into is particularly hard to solve because of a particular items lack of visibility. I quite stumbled onto it by accident, but this could have been spelt out a little better. Another thing, at times the narrative and plot convolutions are hard to follow. Truthfully though, since when was cyberpunk known for ease of rite, accessibility, clarity and understanding? TB's narrative clunks are all intentional right? XD

So where does that leave us?

If you're a cyberpunk aficionado, love classic pointers, and like engaging logic puzzles (relative to the brain drizzle on today's market), you'd be a nob to ignore Technobablyon.

This was my first Wadjet Eye Games game, and I'm definitely checking out the rest of their catalogue. 

Final verdict? For general gamers, 9/10, but for point click adventurers/cyberpunk fans, a definite 10/10.

Buy this game, and enjoy!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971450042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1085, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1085, 'last_played': 1432686044}
review: Im an 80s kid. I love Monkey Island. Beneath a Steel Sky. Police Quest. Blade Runner. You name it. If its 80 Sci-Fi or Cuberpunk then i am the happiest guy you will find for miles. Games like Technobabylon are not only scarce, they are worth gold. I knew when i saw the Title of the game it would be exactly what i wanted. And after installing the game and seeing the menu for the first time, hearing the music, i knew that GTA V would have to wait. All my games would have to wait. It's been an amazing 18 hours.  Even if i tried i couldnt praise the game enough. The Art and Music direction already puts this apart from most Adventure Quest games.  But the story just makes it unforgettable. It pulled me in and kept me fully immersed in the City of Newton and it's inhabitants. Just please, do yourself a favour, and get this game if you are serious about old school quest adventure games with a good plot, full voice acting for all characters you get to play and meet, yes, you play multiple people, a great sound track, well written dialogue, and clever puzzles. The world and it's characters are believable and unforgettable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013158726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 877, 'last_played': 1432741820}
review:
Technobabylon is yet another terrific title on the books of WadgetEye Games that offers a deeply engrossing story combined with challenging gameplay set on a stunningly atmospheric, retro and futuristic 2D backdrop. It is one of the most complex and captivating games I've played in a long time and if you're a fan of point and click games or just love the Cyberpunk genre; it's an absolute essential purchase. 

The game takes place in 2087 in the City of Newton -  an AI run City where genetic engineering dominates humanity and an online Trance craze has taken over society where human interaction plays secondary to online communication. The City is also ran by CEL - the Police, who see and control everything. The conspiracy-driven narrative follows the story of three playable characters;- Charlie Regis a CEL agent and his case officer partner Max Lao along with Latha Sesame; a jobless Trance addict who spends her time fixed in a fantasy online world as opposed to the heavily controlled Newton. After a spate of bombings in the city and a criminal on the run who steals people's memories - the 'Mindjacker'; the game flourishes into a sublime and depth-ridden tale of corruption and intrigue. Elaborating any further would be a huge spoiler but it is simply an incredibly well crafted narrative that is extremely thought-provoking and powerful. 

The general gameplay is similar to that of classics in the genre and modern titles alike such as Blade Runner and Gemini Rue. It's a puzzle-oriented point and click adventure with some very difficult and well-designed puzzles. Some have been very smartly implemented and can often leave you feeling confused and hapless. The satisfaction when you solve a problem and progress a wonderful feeling though as well as earning achievements. Voice acting is also present and is supported by some very appropriate music that adds to the amazing atmosphere. The writing is also very impressive with many clever fictional futuristic aspects being added that brings intrigue and understanding what happened in the past. Some of the script terminologies are very complex though and users sometimes have to decipher and guess what the game is talking about as some things aren't explained clearly. You will gradually understand everything as your progress though, as the narrative begins to fall into place and terms are elaborated in greater detail. 

Overall; Technobabylon is one of the best games I've played this year and another massive success for WadgetEye Games and Steam debut developer Technocrat. The game is complex, challenging, engaging and a remarkable experience throughout. It will take 12-15 hours to finish and with plenty of achievements on offer; there is certainly replay value here also. A must buy!

author: {'steamid': '76561197978976857', 'num_games_owned': 4698, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 967, 'last_played': 1432301022}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970399082', 'num_games_owned': 1803, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1432604702}

author: {'steamid': '76561198057341505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1432585653}
review:
If you like point-and-click adventure games, don't waste more time reading reviews and just get it. It has a good story, pretty art, and solid voice acting, so what more do you want?

If you find point-and-click puzzles frustrating, you will probably still find them frustrating. There are several puzzles with multiple solutions, but in this kind of game there is always the chance for logic to escape you. However, there's a walkthrough video you can rely on, and hints will get more and more common as more people play the game, so you can push through even if you're terrible at solving these things.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007221241', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 798, 'last_played': 1432571749}

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198001780421', 'num_games_owned': 612, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1432565447}

author: {'steamid': '76561198002560288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1609127391}
review: This game is excellent. I've played a LOT of point-n-click's and this is one of the best. Story and voice acting are good and particularly like the mini-games & effects they've built in to keep it interesting. A degree of care has gone into painting the picture of the future too, with it seeming a plausible progression from where we are today. Puzzles are logical enough without being too obvious to solve. The only way I'd improve this is by making the transitions between rooms/scenes instant when you double-click but it's a very minor point.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029376712', 'num_games_owned': 567, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 968, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 968, 'last_played': 1432578069}
review: The game is very atmospheric and has a great style - a mix of Blade Runner, Beneath a Steel Sky with some references to Neuromancer. If you're a fan of one of those, I definitely recommend it to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990858140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1432767425}
review: Technobabylon has an amazingly intense story, stunning voice acting, and exciting and mind bending puzzles. I have played it from start to finish multiple times and each time I play I find something I didn't find before. I find myself deeply involved with the characters and their situations, which is my favorite type of game, something that makes me care. The commentary is informative and exciting, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves Cyberpunk or adventure games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198065086910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1432450061}
review:
Regret purchase. This game relies on you understand what everything in the future world is without explaining what it is. This makes for annoyingly frustrating puzzle solving that counteract the normal ways of solve problems. Doesn't help that everyone seems to have a shrill and annoying voices.

One example early on is getting the food dispenser to print a metal fork. Apparently your anti-virus is kept inside the keypad to your door, not your computer. I can't be alone in say "what the fuck, how does this make sense!?" Other puzzles seem as counter-intuitive, some even seem to be there for no reason as the solution they place in front of you seems to be the time consuming and ultimately pointless options. I speak of the keycard door, you don't need the code despite all indications pointing to the fact that you do, the girl you're with just shoots the lock if you mention the lock to her, which negates the reason for trying to find out the code to begin with. Game padding at its most annoying.

Do not buy unless you like guessing out your ass all the time and just praying shit just works.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120373730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1653837638}
review: One of the best games of 2015. Really enjoying this game. It's different, but a really good different. Old school, new school with a twist. Has a Euro / UK futuristic techno cyberpunk feel to it.  Cant stop playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961769014', 'num_games_owned': 402, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 762, 'last_played': 1432434747}
review: I played all of the Blackwell series from Wadjet Eye Games and loved them all. They create some very personable characters along with great voice acting. When I heard they were releasing a new game, I preordered it as soon as I could. This game did not disappoint. Though, quite similar in gameplay to the Blackwell games, that did not make it any less enjoyable to me. In fact, that is what I was hoping for. A new world with a new story, but same gameplay I enjoyed. Thanks for another great game WEG!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994666064', 'num_games_owned': 3746, 'num_reviews': 611, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1432421874}
review:
Isso sim é um cyberpunk estiloso!

Quando se pensa em uma história do gênero cyberpunk, uma ideia comum é a de ligar o cérebro a um computador e um futuro sujo com edifícios gigantescos cheios de luzes. E aqui você tem a oportunidade de experimentar uma maravilha assim! É simplesmente fantástico demais poder entrar em transe para acessar uma área virtual e resolver problemas por lá, depois desconectar e voltar ao mundo real. Se o que você está procurando é atmosfera, aqui está um jogo que certamente te encantará! Análise detalhada dessa obra fantástica aqui:

http://www.nerdmaldito.com/2015/05/technobabylon-jogo-cyberpunk-muito.html

author: {'steamid': '76561198077179782', 'num_games_owned': 1807, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1432397877}
review: Not particularly difficult, but enjoyable. Wonder what they would do with Broken Age's budget.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971164646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1432412894}
review:
Technobabylon exemplifies what's so often lacking from adventure games  - great worldbuilding. The design stretches beyond the main story to fill out a fascinating version of the future. The switching between characters, reminiscent of Wadjet Eye's equally impressive Resonance, gives you multiple perspectives on the city of Newton, which comes alive through implicit storytelling - filling in history and culture without dense exposition. Well-written dialogue develops naturally from the characters and is often very inventive, with no opportunity for embellishing the world squandered. 

The puzzles are well integrated into the story and fun, sometimes offering multiple paths to the solution - and eventually multiple endings. Artwork is more exceptional pixel-mastery from Wadjet Eye regular Ben Chandler, coherent and consistent design with great use of teal/orange colour scheme. Sound is a weaker aspect, with the music being competent but not memorable, and the quality of voice acting dipping significantly for some side characters.

All-in-all, another reason to give Wadjet Eye your money: 9/10

Pros: Creative puzzles, interesting and diverse characters, great artwork, immersive world, top quality writing, great value for money  

Cons: Uneven voice acting outside of main cast, a little buggy as of writing this (had to restart game occasionally to fix problem with instantly closing description boxes)

author: {'steamid': '76561197994782386', 'num_games_owned': 983, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1432444172}
review:
Отличная игра! 
Запутанное детективное расследование в атмосфере киберпанка - с параллельной виртуальной реальностью, тремя игровыми персонажами, множеством загадок минимум на 6-10 часов прохождения и тщательной проработкой всех деталей игрового мира.

Приятно видеть, что каждая игра от Wadjet Eye Games оказывается едва ли не лучше предыдущей.

Более подробная рецензия: http://itc.ua/articles/technobabylon-divnyiy-novyiy-mir/

author: {'steamid': '76561198025124053', 'num_games_owned': 610, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 748, 'last_played': 1432307884}
review:
Technobabylon is a point and click adventure that isn’t afraid to get deep into some complicated themes while remaining well written, consistent and above all fun to play.

The sheer number of ideas running through game is amazing, and the fact that everything gets pulled back together to give a satisfying conclusion with no loose ends is nothing short of a masterstroke from Technocrat Games. Characters are deep, with real personalities, secrets, desires and resentments. Even the ‘synthetic’ characters are better written than many supposedly human characters in other games. The forces of good in the game have dark sides to them, and the antagonists are not simply evil for the sake of it; there’s no moustache twirling and maniacal laughter here. Everything happens for a reason, and the reasons are damn good ones!

The art is really nice (it's Ben Chandler), and the voice acting is better than average too, with some great personalities in there. Definitely worth it if you're a point and click enthusiast!

Full review here: http://www.goplaythat.com/2015/05/22/technobabylon/

author: {'steamid': '76561197967185145', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1432355617}
review: Wadjet Eye Games has never let me down yet. If you are a sucker for a fully-voiced cyberpunk point-and-click adventure game (like I am), then you should buy this game. The voice acting in this one is fantastic and the story is very original. You couldn't do a story like this in other genres. Once again Wadjet Eye knocks it out of the park.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052127204', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1432242753}
review: Nice cyperpunk game.  Enjoy the throwback to the point and click game play.   If you enjoy the older classics like Kings Quest, Legend of Kyrandia or Adventures of Monkey Island then you should check this title out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968211886', 'num_games_owned': 567, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 3761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1445003922}
review:
An excellent adventure game for both newcomers and experienced adventure games fans!

As this is being written I am 9 hours in, but I cannot account for the whole games length, as I like to play in doses and take my time with the games. 

The story is solid and engaging so far, as usual with Wadjet Eye games (even though this is an semi-outside production!), and has some very nice Neuromancer vibes to it - which should be a huge plus for sci-fi fans, but also highly accessible for people with no background in cyberpunk novels. Fret not - the game explains things well enough without holding your hands.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965583985', 'num_games_owned': 765, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1433260534}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018799277', 'num_games_owned': 1171, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 627, 'last_played': 1431888154}
review:
Technobabylon is one of the best adventure games I’ve played in recent years, if not ever. The best way I can describe how good it is, in terms of world, plot, music and gameplay is this: It’s Deus Ex (the original) The Point & Click Adventure game. And you should play it. So far, it’s won my best adventure game of 2015, even if it’s only May.

Read the full review on The Mental Attic: http://thementalattic.com/2015/05/21/review-technobabylon/

author: {'steamid': '76561198025722208', 'num_games_owned': 2578, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 730, 'last_played': 1437260866}
review:
Another game from Wadjet Eye Games, I really looked forward to.
So I preordered it like other games from Wadjet Eye Games.
Then I waited for the release, so as soon as I saw that it's released, I started playing it.
The story instantly got me hooked, because I like stories, where you have to chase a target. 
Also the setting in the future is a great plus for me, because the future is one of these things we can not predict, so it's a really interesting setting to do things in it.
So you are playing different character through out the game.
There is Lao and Regis, who try to hunt a mindjacker down, and there is Latha, who was trapped in her home and was nearly killed and now tries to find out who and why he wanted to kill her.
So the story follows these paths and it's obvious that their ways will cross some time through out the game, but I won't tell more about it, because it would spoil of the game. :)
All in all the story was very thrilling and I wanted to find out what will happen next and how it will end. Also there were some points in the story that was really unexpected for me, but if you will play the game you will see what I meant. :)

The game is obvious a point'n'click adventure, so it has puzzle to progress and overall they aren't that hard, but sometimes you probably will get stuck, because you overlook some thing like I did.
Also at some points of the game you have more than one option to accomplish your goal, which also results in a point, where your decision will change the end of the game. 

So if you like point'n'click adventures with a good story, you won't make a mistake for buying this game. So buy it and play it, there is no reason not to !

author: {'steamid': '76561198044839188', 'num_games_owned': 3384, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1431636580}
review:
http://www.gikz.pl/artykuly/recenzje/technobabylon-recenzja-ona-patrzy/


[...] Nie mam Technobabylon nic do zarzucenia. Byłem pochłonięty rozgrywką bez reszty, spijałem fabularne zawiłości niczym dobre zimne w upalny dzień, ciesząc się jak wtedy, kiedy przygodówki były moimi grami numer jeden. Nostalgiczne nuty, grające 10 godzin. Wniosek jest prosty. Wielbiciele przygodówek – absolutnie doskonała perełka dla Was, cyberpunka i klimatów sci-fi – łakomy kąsek, a jak lubicie oba warianty, porzućcie Wiedźmina. Technobabylon, absolutnie koniecznie, rewelacja.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007680382', 'num_games_owned': 344, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1432456376}
review:
I wanted this game as one of my first reviews. So I was provided a review copy.
I really recommend this game to any cyberpunk or simply SF fan. I couldn't wait for Technobabylon because Resonance and Primordia are part of my favorite point & click adventures. I am aware that all of these games are made by different teams within Wadjet Eye, but it's still tempting to compare them. 

The conspiracy that gets untangled slowly hooked me up very quick. I also loved how the characters, when you play with each of them, don't really know each other, so you get to see quite different sides of the story, even different ways of mentality. I expected mature themes and I wasn't disappointed. Political corruption, criminality, blunt violence. Yet, all of these are depicted in a serious manner and they are not gratuitous. It's hard to achieve that.

For those who wonder about difficulty, I say that it's not hard for veteran adventure players, but the creativity of the puzzles ideas will keep you going.

Overall, even though the soundtrack isn't as amazing as i expected but still good, there is no real minus for this game. It would worth every cent for such a strong storyline-gameplay bond. It's also replaylable because of the achievements that are only unlocked by taking different choices in the plot or solve a few situations in another way. You get at least 15 hours of fun from this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983824885', 'num_games_owned': 743, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1709849129}
review:
I played this game from start to finish in one sitting. It definitely gave me vibes of the classic Lucasarts or Sierra point 'n click games. It was a well written, and well thought out story, with plenty of challenging puzzles. I ended up stuck once, but a bit of lateral thinking later and I was back on track. There are a couple of different endings, so I have yet to see the other, but I'll be playing again soon to find out what I've missed. 

A big hand to Technocrat on his maiden release. I hope to see more in future!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970901066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1431834682}
review:
Technobabylon is a great example of the modern pixelart adventure game, bringing along with it a great story that’s just oozing futuristic tones. It might not be the most revolutionary games, playing it safe by keeping the mechanics simple and the puzzles accessible, however the experience it provides is above many of its competitors. If, like me, you had been left wanting for a good adventure game for some time then you really can’t go past Technobabylon as it’s sure to provide you with many hours of enjoyment.

Read my full review here: http://www.therefinedgeek.com.au/index.php/2015/05/22/technobabylon-the-singularity-we-deserve/

author: {'steamid': '76561198006653128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1432281499}
review:
Point & click adventure game. Production value is very high, comparable to Resonance and the final game in the Blackwell series. Story is gripping and interesting all the way through. Puzzles are nearly as tough as those in Resonance, including a few that require some action skill. Game length is pretty decent - plenty of optional dialogue, and lots of different scenes. The only Wadjet Eye game that's longer is Resonance.

When it comes to character chemistry, your mileage may vary. The voice acting direction feels pretty loose - as if the majority of it was intended for a Blackwell game. The intensity and focus of character from Gemini Rue is not present here, unfortunately.

One good thing about the story is that there's no cartoony bad guys. Each of them has a realistic motivation. No multiple endings like Resonance though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969340468', 'num_games_owned': 861, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 845, 'last_played': 1432267536}
review:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=446383963

The future isn’t quite as progressive as it should be. People can’t find jobs because most services are automated by a singular computer system named, Central. Humans are raised by the city and molded by it, they can either become successful or sponges trapped in the thrall of the internet.  There are some high notes in there like acceptable gene manipulation from man to woman, and racial hatred seems to be a thing of the past. However zealotry, hacking, government spying, war, and terrorism have all gotten worse than we can ever imagine.

Technobabylon bounces between many distinct characters similar to the film “Crash.” The story revolves around the actions of a shady group of criminals who manipulate a police officer into making some questionable choices, and the attempted termination of an otherwise uninteresting woman living in the slums. The mystery goes beyond those two and slips into the lives of other citizens in the city, as each layer is peeled from this clandestine group.

High points

Deep and engrossing – Technobabylon is a well-written cyberpunk adventure game with a knack for fleshing out its world via descriptive storytelling. For a game that looks like it was made in the early 90’s, it comes to life with witty dialogue, interesting characters, and believable explanations of technology that would impress William Gibson. It easily articulates the impact of humans allowing technological advances to get out of control and effectively rule them.

It paints a picture of a future full of genetic-manipulation, synthetic love, curable diseases, news outlets corrupted by corporations, and wars that are waged not just on the ground but also in the mind. If this were a novel, it could easily be a best seller among the Science-Fiction crowd.

Fun characters and puzzles – Charlie and the gang, will interact with some interesting programs and synthetics in the city. I thought I had accidently turned on Discworld or Monkey Island after interacting with the various wacky programs in and out of the Trance. Most of the characters can be outright hilarious amongst an otherwise grim world. The interactions are only highlighted by intelligent puzzle design that refuses to force us into spamming random objects. The title gives plenty of hints to allow us to look at a situation logically, understand it, and complete the puzzle.

Latha can interact with terminals and drift into the Trance to use programs and manipulation to hack the internet. Charlie and Max will find reasonable ways to discover clues, and hack into the brains of synthetics to twist their personalities to something more helpful. As much as I love The Walking Dead, I think this game properly demonstrates how to create meaningful gameplay, while also providing us with a stimulating tale.

Hard Choices & Cold Outcomes – While it’s nothing like Mass Effect in terms of sheer volume of decision making, each of the available choices are not to be selected on a whim. No matter how well intentioned a choice may be, it is always countered by a consequence. You may not feel the immediate sting of what you’ve done, but eventually the game will let you understand the weight of it. This game doesn’t mind making you feel like a terrible person after your judgment calls.

Visual Discrepancy – In the early build that I’ve played, I’ve noticed that the visuals take a jarring leap between clean 16-bit graphics in the trance, and grimy looking pixels in the “real” world. I’m sure this is a stylistic choice by the development team, and I respect them for it, but it comes off as a bit jarring. I also noticed that characters are always speaking in the Trance, but in the real world their lips will only move in special sequences. It’s a small issue that dilutes the atmosphere of this otherwise immersive world.

Low Points

Technical Issues – There are a few bugs in the build I played but nothing that negatively affected gameplay. I did notice that the game crashes trying to Alt-Tab, or refuses to even start if you have a multi-monitor setup. I did notice that the game stopped Auto-saving on some levels, so be sure to manually save when you can. Hopefully all these issues will be ironed out by the time the game releases.

Conclusion

Technobabylon may not be a visual and technical marvel, but the story and immersive dialogue creates a believable Science Fiction world. If you’re a fan of cyberpunk books or the classic Blade Runner film, you’ll absolutely adore the detailed and brutal storyline of Technobabylon. I recommend that you buy this game at full price if you’re an adventure fan, or even if you’re a person that just loves great storytelling. Technocrat and Wadjet Eye Games did a fantastic job, and I still can’t believe these are the same people that made a game called “Nancy: The Happy Whore.”

*A review copy was provided to us by the publisher*

author: {'steamid': '76561198055041003', 'num_games_owned': 1360, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1440380412}
review:
[b]DISCLAIMER:[/b] This review is based on a review copy provided by Wadjet Eye Games. It is completely true and unmanipulated, yet highly subjective from someone who loves adventure games in general and the WEG adventures so far in particular.

Technobabylon is, depending on your preferred taste in setting, the best Point & Click adventure Wadjet Eye Games ever put on the market. It can only be surpassed by the complete Blackwell experience if you like the ghost story more than Cyberpunk. Technobabylon easily snatches the summit of adventure games away from even the highly praised Gemini Rue, and a welcome release for everyone disappointed by Broken Ages final release.

With this out of the way, I’ll try to get into the positive points without destroying the experience trough spoilers. Technobabylon takes place in Newton, a cliché Cyberpunk City in the 21th century. It’s controlled by a sentient AI called Central who not only manages electricity and water but also the police. In this town, a between-jobs internet addict and two high-ranking police officers get sucked into a mass murderer case that seems to rip the information out of their victims brains. In the end, one might find that the whole cliché Newton presents is not quite what it seemed, and Technobabylon might have played with your expectations all along…

The graphics are superb – if you like the characteristic artstyle of Ben Chandlers, who’s responsible for all of Wadjet Eyes graphics. The game, while not being developed but only published by WEG received much help from Ben in terms of style, that is for certain. The animations are a little stiff while walking, but the gestures and animations of characters in dialogues are great and really set the mood. The music is alright – nothing fancy, but fitting for the black-and-neon world Newton provides.

Gameplay is very classic, but in a very refreshing way, especially for Wadjet Eye. While most of their earlier adventures have a focus on dialogues and riddles to progress the story, Technobabylon has a huge amount of item and inventory puzzles.This depends on the character you are currently controlling – the old techophobe police officer depends more on the good old use-fishing rod-with-magnet style of play than the internet addict who just hacks all systems she can get her hands on. This really helps differentiate the characters and is, plainly, really fun. The puzzles are very intuitive, though – no Grim Fandango “How the f’ would I have guessed that moments” in here. 

Overall, if you have the slightest interest in adventure games, go get Technobabylon. It’s one of the best out there developed in modern times. 

My German Review is found here: [url=http://www.gamingpoints.de/reviews/technobabylon-police-quest-am-adventure-gipfel/]Gamingpoints[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198014035044', 'num_games_owned': 1457, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1432183437}
review:
[url=http://techraptor.net/content/technobabylon-review-cybercity-adventures]TechRaptor Review[/url] 

While its gameplay is classic point and click, Technobabylon’s writing, characters, and story are presented with a 21st century focus. The cyberpunk city of Newton is well-fleshed out and does an excellent job of providing coloration even on the parts you don’t see. There are some relatively unique ideas, as well as some good implementations that help make it stand out in different ways.

When it comes together, Technobablyon is a very nice adventure game with only a few flaws – the graphics sometimes don’t quite work, the puzzles on a few occasions get away from logic, and the story has only a few points that make you frown on minor bits. However, it bears the trappings of its genre in many ways and that makes it a difficult game to score because if you aren’t interested in adventure games, if you don’t have patience, and you don’t want to experience a well-written narrative where you solve puzzles on the go, it isn’t something that will interest you.

I will say though, if you like Adventure games, this is something you definitely want to check out!

--- 
Final Score: 7.5/10 Very Good
Read the [url=http://techraptor.net/content/technobabylon-review-cybercity-adventures]full Review[/url] for more!

author: {'steamid': '76561198016432675', 'num_games_owned': 1503, 'num_reviews': 483, 'playtime_forever': 595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1451262330}
review:
Game was looked at from a key obtained from the developer.

Technobabylon brings the experience of the old LucasArts games to the new day with updated themes and more modern social issues. The game hits themes of the Internet and the social stigma behind it, governmental control, and the human condition. The writing is pretty well done with strong work done in terms of the dialogue between characters, as you have reasons to actually listen to everyone and talk to them. The games puzzles are hit and miss. Some puzzles will make you feel like a real detective in how you solved the problem, and rewarded paying attention. Some puzzles on the other hands suffer from the old point + click adventures basic problem of not knowing exactly what it wants from you, and contextual item use. In the end, those who like sci-fi+control plots will really enjoy the experience that's here.

+:
[list]
[*] Great dialogue work done here as the writing isn't forced, and flows naturally. Dialogue between characters plays to their personality strengths, and makes you want to find out what they have to say.
[*] In addition, secondary dialogue and repeated dialogue options in particular were pretty fun to listen to, especially with the elements of the Trance in there. 
[*]Good variety of environments and made me appreciate the art style even more. Despite being set in the future, there was a great sense of difference within the world controlled by the AI.
[*] The strongest puzzles in the game give a reasonable sense of accomplishment and a feeling of a real detective when completing them. 
[*] Some heavy themes are hit here, and some character depth really is brought to the forefront in terms of those themes. Emotional connections were strong in this game, especially if you have someone IRL you can relate to. 
[*] Solid voice acting all around (with an occassional misstep).
[/list]

-:
[list]
[*] Some puzzles are really suffering from the old school point and click adventure syndrome. You will get stuck if you don't pay attention specifically to the contextual clicks. 
[*] Too many subplots at time really muddy the water in terms of the overall story, and could have maybe eliminated one or two to focus on the bigger plots.
[*] Felt like hint system in terms of dialogue sometimes sent you in the wrong direction. 
[*] A personal point in terms of games that crash when you alt+tab.
[/list]

Completely unrelated to overall review list but is worth a mention:
[list]
[*] For some reason, Nvidia shadowplay's recording icon decided to show up for some reason, maybe with the weird way that the resolution is put on the screen.
[/list]

For More First Impressions and Edited Gameplay: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TPUpNmZc_-g
